Bangor Oct 2 1855

Dear Brother Issac
I have just returned from Hampden, whither we felt obliged to go to see about our girl, as soon as we found Ellen was really going to leave us Thursday-was much disappointed to find you gone - you had only been gone ten minutes, Ellen said - and you forgot your little pail, I was sure of seeing you again I had ever so many things to say. 
It is well that you did go Tuesday isn't it? Now won't it be so bad going that we can't go to Milo?
Ellen left us for good yesterday p.m., expecting to start for Minn. today, but I hardly think the boats got in yesterday. The poor girl cried sadly. You should have seen her hold Percie away & look in his face as if she

never meant to forget him, then hold his hands in both of hers and look at him again, without hardly speaking at all.  It seemed to distress her that he wouldn't feel bad about her going.  He would say over after her "Nellen going away -never, never see Percie any more", but he didn't feel it as she wanted him to. We shall never see her like again in many aspects- I couldn't help crying myself- From all accounts, we are likely to be fortunate in the next girl- I suppose she cannot come till next week, Little Charlotte Chalmers is staying with me a few days - she is nicely helpful & very pleasant. I gave Percie catnip tea yesterday & S. cut his gums in eight places without his making a word of objection  Three great double teeth just ready to come through & very much swollen - He slept much more quietly last night - I felt so anxious

two night before, that I didn't sleep much - he was so very restless & constantly starting & straightening his limb. Do you see how faithfully you are whipped in the first piece in this week's Mirror, by our brother Rider, for writing letters sabba' day? He wrote & sent that while he was here. See also Sam'l's hats & hairs, and how he did'nt let the dirty that "todder man" threw,  hit him a bit.

                 You and I did'nt settle - You gave me six dollars & I got two caps,    1,00
                                                                                                     1 1/4 yds thibbet 1.56
                                                                                                     7 skns silk              14
                                                                                                     lining silk                 14

can't possibly remember how much I paid because I don't know how many yds there were - It was 75 cts a yard. Please tell me next time you write without fail, as I want to keep all straight. The things I got before came

to four dollars & something - I am careless to forget so, but there have been so many ways to think lately. Sarah Harlow is to be married next week - They have great times making cake this week - Her fitting out is on a large scale, I imagine - I was troubled because you didn't get any dinner, Isaac - you ought to have gone into the the store soon before you went down town & again after you came back. Wouldn't it be nicer if Lizzie was here now? What a big rain! Mr. Bradeen took tea here last night - well good bye - write soon & often - love to all from Sister Lucy.
Two o'clock, P.M. Sam'l has come, says that Gertie has cried without cessation since yesterday morning - has been carried all the time - Maria is sick abed today - vomiting &c. Samuel is sick so he has not been out today - They do have a very hard time - they will have

Bangor Sept. 5 -1855

Dear Sister Nettie

                      I don't know as it is hardly right for me to inflict another letter upon you Milo people so soon, nonetheless, I think I'll venture it. 
                  Your nice letters were received a little time since. Many thanks - wish I had another one to read tonight. Sam'l has not come up - Ellen and Lizzie have gone to bed, and I must write to keep myself company. Mond. night, when as I was 'spectin' nobody, Hattie Ely came up just before tea, then about ten minutes after we were through tea, came Mr. Conglass to tea. (we were a little earlier than usual, as I had been to Old Town). While I was waiting on him at table the bell rung & Miss Harkness, Lizzie's old teacher, came in to make a call & to press most importunately her request that

[left-hand side and top] flower without asking me  - will stand & hold one carefully by the stem ever so long waiting to be told whether he may take it.  He helps shell beans bravely, does not eat so raucously as a while ago, & is very well so long as I keep him on bread & milk. If Mother can send me some comfortably fine yarn for Percie's stockings I shall be extremely glad. Send it white. Wish the people would save me some fresh, loft rushes for his bed. Sam'l has come. good night to all from Affectionate Lucy.

we would like her to board, saying she could find no other place, that here she could be "benefited morally & intellectually," &c. &c. But I persisted in telling her "nay" and her high sensed expectations were dashed to the ground! I divided my time very impartially between talking with her in the parlor & pouring Mr. Conglass' tea in the kitchen - Before she had gone, or Mr. C. was through supper, Mr. Harlow called to see Samuel, & immediately after Miss H. left, Mr. & Mrs. Sewall from Brownville appeared, bag & baggage, horse and cart, to spend a spell with us. They have gone tonight over to Mr. Littlefield; are coming here to pack up and start in the morning. They came on a shopping expedition. We have enjoyed their visit nicely & I guess they have. Mr. S. is the seventh minister who has eaten here within five or six weeks. Hattie, Mallie & self went

shopping this forenoon - quarterly maternal meeting this P.M. but we were too tired to go. Marie walked up here & back yesterday I walked down street today but rode home. Hattie brought me some nice plants & bulbs. She is a whole team - I feel perfectly easy about Maria now. Gertie is improving daily. I want to hear very often how you all are - do let me, won't you? How very very sad about Mr. Rider - Why did he let those bungling doctors do it for him? I have not had a letter from Almeda for a long time. I have written to send by Mrs. Sewall. I neglected to get it into the Office yesterday. What a sad, sad prospect for them. Have you heard of Mary Pomroy’s death - She had been sick a long time at her father's, but was considered better & had gone to her husband at N.Y. She was exceedingly nervous & childish during her illness. You have undoubtedly heard of Dea. Adams

ams' sudden death last week - walked to the Institution perfectly well, was taken with heart disease there & died immediately after getting home. You recollect what Mr. Thompson said of him in the Independent - He hardly would expect to hear of his death so soon - a good man has gone - his life was almost irreproachable. Please read the enclosed clip and return it or save it for me. Sam'l goes to Searsport or Oldtown or Stillwater almost every day. We are feasting on shell beans & sweet corn - We have a few of the Lima beans, or I suppose they are. Lizzie picked the corn yesterday for both families & by mistake, picked 21 ears of pop corn - as chippy as you can imagine. It is astonishing how Lizzie can work when she is at play. Percie is just as good nowadays - two of his swollen teeth are through - he very "glad at nothing" all day long, especially if he can get plenty of flowers to "make botay for Mover." I let him be out doors almost all the time, now the weather is so cool. He very rarely picks off a

Bangor Aug. 7 - 1855.

Dear Brother Isaac

             I will write a few words this morning to tell you how disappointed we have been every day not to get a letter from you. We supposed of course that you were cured by getting to Milo, so we could not think sickness prevented your writing - though seriously I have worried some lest riding in the hot sun might have harmed you. Why did'nt  you get inside when you started?
      Last Friday P.M. Mr. & Mrs. Francis Shepherd of Portland came here & staid till Mond. morn. Sat. night by cars from Boston came Mr. Packard with his bride. Samuel saw him on board the boat - he said he had no place provided when he returned, so S.

[left-hand side and top] really. I have to be extremely careful of him. Do please write very immediately affectionately sister Lucy. Tell my Mother I want a letter from her very bad.

as is his wont, invited them to come right here. He is to preach at our church four Sabbaths, during Prof. Shepard's absence, & the contributors he would look to provide a boarding place are out of town, so you see how we "entertain strangers". He finds it difficult to get a boarding place, & I think very likely they will stay here the three weeks. Mrs. Harlow invited them quite cordially to a to spend two or three days with them, but in her smooth way let them know very plainly that they mustn't stay all the time. It would seem rather natural, as he was in the family for about ten years that he should be asked to make a home there now. They are extremely pleasant people Mrs. P. another Mrs. Wm. Bennett, only younger and better looking - she has been a teacher of Seminaries. She is lively and very witty, runs about

bout the house for Percie to catch her, has a very winning, pretty way with her, and so good & sensible. I should love to tell you some of the nice things Mr. P. says about Mrs. Harlow - He reminds me much of Joseph in his dry wit - He says, "I'm afraid of Mrs. Harlow." He says she will crowd just as hard as it will do on Mr. Harlow, to accomplish some purpose of her own, making him think it is solely for his happiness & well-being, is exceedingly shrewd to see just how far it will do do go, and if she finds it can't go, "she will back out the handsomest of anything that ever I saw." I hope you take good care of Mother's precious tomatoes &c. I do think you ought to go up & see Almeda again. We have tomatoes as large as a hen's egg. Mrs. Shepherd sent ever so much love to everybody, Mother in particular. Ellen has decided to wait &

go with her other brothers in two months - so I shall have a little more time to find a girl, but I don't know as it will do me any good. By special request, Mr. Leo is going to deliver his course of lecture a second time. I want a letter from you all amazingly - I want Nettie to write me all about herself and Mayo. I enclose a letter just rec'd for you, also two documents which I thought might serve to interest Mother & keep her out of mischief, of which dire mishap I believe she is in imminent danger (there you have an Irish-ism) You will please return them without fail the next time you write. Poor Mr. Robbins throws such missives in at the doors all over the neighborhood. I forgot to tell you that in the midst of the rest of the company, Mr. Wilder the choir leader came in to tea. I have not been down to Maria's since she got home. Eliab has gone to Boston. Gertie is getting better, but she may grow worse again. P.P. has ups & downs contin

Lucy. Bangor July 31. 1855
Milo Aug 1. 1855

                                                                                                                                                                                                       Bangor July 31 - 1855

Dear Sister Nettie

         Isaac did intend to go to Milo today, as he will tell you, but the rain and his bodily feelings prevented. I have been quite fearful that he would be really sick. He will tell you what nice letters and daguerreotypes he brought me, to say nothing of an elaborately wrought collar from Theodore's wife and a double handful of agates from the little folks. Percie is asleep and I take my time to write. he has not been quite well for a day or two - last night I feared the real old bowel complaint - bad discharges with the same sickening smell. He is better today. Lizzie has just returned from Maria's whither I sent her for tidings of Sister. She has been better & worse alternately for

some days - better today - They still hold to the Homeopathic treatment, but it seems to me that Gertie is very much as Percie was last summer, - a little better now and then, but every ill time a little worse than the one that preceded it, so long as Dr. Payne attended him. Tell Mother I don't know where she finds strength and smartness to Gertie - She seems to me an unusually delicate, tender child. It seems to me that she could not bear a tithe of what Percie did last year, but I don't know. I believe I wrote Mother about the Commencement. I wrote it to somebody at any rate - I wish you could have heard Rev. J. P. Thompson's lecture. Mr. Leo took tea here last night - Samuel was away at Searsport for which I was sorry, and has not returned yet, for which I am sorrier. I fancy if you knew that Isaac was here all the while since Saturday, you would

feel a little more uneasy then you do! You are very good to tell me of Mayo's sayings and doings - please do so every time you write - I love to know them dearly. Percie don't say so much, but he seems to understand pretty well about matters and things. He is very fond of flowers, wants them all the time, will handle them over & arrange them for an hour or two at a time in silence, only now & then saying to himself, "Per make botay for Mamma". It is very warm and sultry today. Things in the garden do grow wonderfully. I have a lemon shrub growing nicely, one that Mrs. Page rooted for me, however. One slip of the monthly rose lived. We got several varieties of verbena slips, about half of which are alive now. Isaac can tell you how famously my verbena has extended itself in the garden, notwithstanding I have given away four large pieces from

the root. If it keeps on, it will overwhelm everything before fall. The Fuschia is nicely budded also. Your remarks in relation to the "propagation of Thrift" by Mrs. Harlow amused me very much. I have bordered two of the four middle beds with pansies, one with Iceland Moon and the fourth partially with Thrift. I did feel a little sorry that you and Mother should leave Almeda so soon, - and now Isaac will not want to go there, as he will be daily looking for a message from Chicago. Why did not Albina keep the girl she had? Please tell Mother that I put in two slips of Albina's in the bundle, (or rather sent them to Eliab & he said he put them in) which were all I could find. Did she give me more than two? Percie talks a good deal about all of you & seems to remember everything he saw & did while there. I asked him one day who made the flowers - "Mamma." I did not wonder at his answer because I work in the garden so much. Next I asked who made Percie, & his answer was, quickly, as he looked up in my face, "Papa." Well, good bye - with much love, Sis Lucy

Lucy
July 6 1855
Bangor July 6 1855
Mine dear Brother
Your most acceptable letter of June 29 was rec'd last night. It is now quarter past eight P.M. Samuel is at the store as usual, little P.P. in his crib asleep, Lizzie eating pea-nuts on the lounge & Ellen in the kitchen knitting. I have been in the garden watering and tending since tea. I do great business there, I can assure you. I wrote you latterly directing to Du Quoin, telling you all about the garden and how the labor of your hands is prospering, but I think it doubtful if you got the letter before leaving.
I am quite a husbandman these days and my out door labors are decidedly beneficial to me. I have thoroughly wed my posy patch, so there is hard by a weed to be seen in the paths or 
Template:Left side of letter
brother. Good night - your loving sister Lucy.

or elsewhere, have transplanted and arranged nicely, and besides have almost wholly weeded the beds & parsnips, tended the vines to keep away the bugs, digged about the tomatoes & watered all things most faithfully- I like to stay out there so well that I forget to come in when I am tired frequently. The Okra is doing finely and two plants of Mrs Page's  "Martanns" are up & looking well. Mr. Moran has been here and hoed the garden fixed gravel walks etc.etc. The little rose bushes down by the fence are prospering & the Prairie rose looking beautifully, I have ripped off half the buds for the benefit of the bush. I want you here to look at things with one, though doubtless you see many things every day better worth looking at than anything here. Samuel has been to Searsport three times this week to see about his lumber. He has

many rafts of boards taken down there and filed up to season, thinking there may be a sale for their next winter when it would be difficult to get them from here. This lumber business, as it is at present, is a sad perplexity. I presume you have heard from Nettie all about Percie's illness at Milo & how I came home with him sooner than I intended. He was quite sick two or three days after I got back- discharged a good deal of blood- but I think that & the fit all occasioned by eating three beans swallowed without sufficient chewing, as he passed one almost whole two days after eating it. He seems a little too much relaxed all the time & I am obliged to be constantly careful in regard to his diet, otherwise he is well now. Eliab thinks of going to Milo for Maria next Thursday. I suppose they have all gone to Brownville now. I guess I shall let Lizzie go up

and come back with him - just to stay one or two nights. Samuel was going to Hampden on business this P.M. so I rode down to Mr Crosby's. They hear about once a week from William and Rufus. Their address is Atchison, Kansas Territory. They have bought a claim, built a house and store, got their spring crops inward when William wrote last, he was just going to St. Louis to buy goods, they seem to be doing well, but their parents are intensely anxious about them, as is very natural. William is ready to leave & intending to do so I believe so soon as engineering business can be obtained. They are only ten miles from Sarah Parker in Misouri, I have just written to Theo's wife, so I don't know as I have any message to send to the Minn. brethren, but I wish you would pick up some nice little curiosities now & then in your travels. May our Father have you in his keeping through all your journeyings, my

Lucy. Bangor Dec 9. 1855
Dunbarton - Dec. 1855

                                                                                                                                                                                              Bangor Dec. 9-1855

Dear Sister Nettie
I am weary with reading and lonesome with thinking, and I don't believe it will be naughty (brother Rider to the contrary notwithstanding) for me to talk a little with you, if it is Sunday. It is quarter past six P.M. but it seems as if we have had a long evening already since dark. It snows tonight and was dark early. Snow turned to rain speedily. Percie had his supper of bread & milk in a tin dipper, & went to bed, then in the same dipper I ate my bread & milk, "topping off" with a bit of apple pie - lastly, Caroline took her turn at the porringer ate, as did her betters (?) before her & carried out the supper dish to be washed in the morning when there is some hot water- The above is the order of exercises most every night - You will wonder if we get the milk across the street - No - by a

"stroke of policy" I left "cabbage juice" & engaged milk, which is really very good, of friend Jordan - Mallie's milkman was unwilling to come so far for one customer. We do have strangely long days in Dec. this year! Can you account for it? Particularly (& wickedly, doubtless) the sabbath day, when we must "neither work nor play", can't go to meeting & get tired of thinking. I had a nice letter from mine Samuel last night, else I should have been utterly homesick - He wrote from M.Y. and the last from Cleveland - eight days between the time of receiving them. I have been reading today in the two last Independents two more lengthy articles by Bucher to the N.Y. Evangelist - I want to know if you have the paper, if not, I must send them to you. It makes me both glad & sad to think of your stay here - glad that so many of us could meet at Thanksgiving, & sad that I did'nt enjoy you all more

on the Independent course two evenings, the latter on the Mercantile, one evening. I heard Mrs. P. one evening on antislavery and did'nt like him (except his smooth & beautiful voice - Mr. Taylor, on the Arabs I was much interested in - Incidents & bits of personal experience made it interesting. Mrs. Rose I shall not trouble myself to hear. What a length of letter I have written. I am fairly ashamed of myself - Tell Mother to take this as to herself too, till I write again to her. Please present my reverential respects & loving affections to your own parents & tell them I want amazingly to come & see them while you are there! There, I am afraid they will think I'm not particularly respectful. Please do write all of you to your lonely & loving sister
Lucy
Percie is so good all the time now that one could hardly believe he could be so ugly as he sometimes was to Mayo. I think he repents of his misdeeds - he is very loving to an imaginary Mayo now.

but really now I have made Percie's dark calico apron & got it on, it seems true I never liked any one better, notwithstanding my former preference for light ones - but then they are getting to be so large now, & dark ones do look more boyish. I have not made any other dress for Percie - think I shall not make the plaid till towards spring, as he will not probably go out at all - I have made a little cross way cape to his cloak, which is a manifest improvement. Mrs. Martin is having a party tonight - the whole house illuminated as on the eventful night of Ella's marriage - chairs, coffee pot, cake plates, spoons, lamps & what not borrowed here - Tell Isaac that as the last promptings of my benevolent heart towards naming the babies, I propose Eliashife and Elisanna. I can do no more. ('ceptin' that I just thought of Clement!) Wendell Phillips & Bayard Taylor have lectured here - the former

She has some notions, but then, she's a good girl - invaluable, to Eliab & Maria - She ought to commit matrimony. Among all the names they have thought of, they say they shall decide between Merton & Caroll - They have given Earnest the "go by," notwithstanding Mallie's fear that she should be supplanted in another quarter! She never thought of Caroll to go with Carleton - wonders you did not take it. The little fellow is a cunning little round head with quite a pretty phiz even now, & really a high forehead - grows fat every day - cries very little, sleeps most all the time - Eliab fidgets if he coughs or sneezes or wrinkles up his nose! If you were here, would'nt Mallie & I have some fun with you about various things? Did you ever notice, when you were here & the Camp stove on the flower stand, the shadows of the different plants on the ceiling overhead? They are very beautiful - I never saw

them till a day or two since - that shows how much we lose by using the muckrake so much and looking up so little, does'nt it? I have had little bits of letters from Mother & Isaac, which I intend to answer soon, but thought I would first answer the one which I knew you would have written if you had not "so many babies", as Isaac says - How men do dislike this having so many babies, don't they? Ask Isaac! Mother charges me to go out, with Percie - I don't know as I ever went from house so much in the same time in my life as in the last two weeks - I don't know but the neighbors will think I am using my liberty while I can get it, now Samuel is away - have been down to Eliab's almost every day - Caroline & Percie walked down one day. He is very much interested in the baby - generally calls it his "brother" or his "thither", sometimes says 'tis Gertie, or another Gertie. He

frequently says Mayo has gone to Gertie, sometimes to Dunbarton - Has almost all his play arranged as if Mayo was with him - says "here's my team and Mayo is coming behind me with a load of wood" &c. Eliab sent Mr. Chapman up for me the other day - After I went away, Percie said, in his hesitating way, "When - my - fever - turns home - I - will - tell - my fever - that - my - Mother - went away - with - a man". I thought if I was to be reported in that way, I might as well "fess" at once, so I wrote immediately to Sam'l. Today he saw somebody coming up the street and said "There's my waf," meaning "wife". Have had a letter from Milo; they know nothing of the bundle, except that it was left at the P.O. & the P.M. says he sent it. I am so sorry the little pink apron was left - had I not better send a bundle by express - that, the aprons for babies, rubbers &c? I have spoken a velvet bonnet just to my liking - plain, with a fold over the top & a

bow of velvet behind, trimmed with a narrow edge. The pink ribbon that I have put inside with black velvet, for $3.50 - Very reasonable, we think - Mrs. Crosby & Rufus were here Sat. P.M. (by the way I forgot to say that 'tis Mond. eve now - I would'nt have you think I wrote all this letter Sunday.) Rufus just from Kansas - very much out of health - has suffered much from fever & ague bloated & pale, with some cough - He reminds me very much of Margaret - Mrs. C. very much disappointed at not seeing the twins - did not know they were here till they had gone - Mr. C. had not been to Bangor for a good while - Poor man! he is coming down with the hypo again. Another year of wretchedness for him & his family. The last time he had it, he started off to Boston one day. (Rufus gone away & Mrs. C. could not prevent him) was found next day lying on a wharf in Boston drunk - perfectly insensible - by a Hampden man - he took him on board the boat, fixed him up & saw him home - When Mr. C. came to himself he was so mortified that the man could hardly restrain him from jumping overboard - Mr. C. told him if he would never mention it, he would give him his horse - Caroline told me - it was just before Margaret died, when he was so bad with hypo & have crazy with grief. She thinks the man has never mentioned it. Can we imagine what Mrs. C. has to suffer? Miss Pease fitted two dresses for Caroline one day & fixed the sleeves to my cloak so that I could finish them - I did not have it otherwise attend. The girls have had letters from Binghamton saying that Sammie appears better. I imagine you will call me a strangely changeable animal -

while you were here - There seemed to be all the time so much going on, so many things to be said & done, that there was no time for us to stop & love one another. I always think afterwards of so many things that I might have done but did not do, for the comfort of all of you that I always feel bad after any of you go away. The fault is all in myself - I am & always was so much given to being "careful and troubled", that I do not give myself up to the enjoyment of things as I go along, half enough. I am so glad for you, Nettie, that you are safely anchored in port with the little ones, & got along with them so nicely on the way. Mrs. Harlow would call it a special providence that the weather was so fine. I don't know but she is right - that in our many daily blessings, we ought to consider the special love & care of our Heavenly Father to us, more than we do. Our maternal meeting came last Wednes. The passover was the subject - rather a hard

one to interest little children upon - Mrs. H. The catechism - wished me to help her with questions again, but I declined. I think some historical subject would do better, don't you? I did not attend - ? with Mallie while Hattie went to sewing school - It is truly wonderful to see how well Maria is - better than before, though at our desire, is not going down stairs so soon - no pain afterwards, no trembling of the limbs, no backache - good appetite - just the same as ever, but considered it prudent to keep quiet a few days! The nurse arrived in town two days after the baby was born, called there, & Mallie told her she might stay if she had no other place, though she did not need any one but Hattie, as herself was so well, & baby slept all the time - Miss Carpenter was very pleasant & reasonable (we all liked her much) said it would be folly to stay with nothing to do, & so they saved the fifteen dollars. They have not even a stitch of sewing - they say all in the world they have to do is to knit some cotton stockings for Eliab, which they are both doing, as they have opportunity. Hattie is a smart, sensible girl -- good hearted, too,

Lucy, Bangor Jan. 30. 1856
Dunbarton Feb 2 - 1856

                                                                                                                                                                                                                     Bangor Jan. 30 - 1856

Dear Sister Nettie
I really intended to write to you long before this, but Mr. Rider & Almeda have been here & you know when we have somebody to talk to, we don't think so much about writing. They have been  here a fortnight - have gone this morning to Eliab's to make a visit - perhaps to stay the rest of the time. Dr. Mc Ruen thinks he may need to keep him a fortnight longer - Does not like to reperform the operation as it would be difficult & dangerous, so he's trying, by the application of caustics, to destroy the remainder of the gland. It is not painful. The other spots look better than last fall. I am afraid you are feeling very anxious about Isaac and I am sure it is not strange if you do. What an escape! How can

we feel thankful enough that our dear one was preserved. I am astonished that the fright & anxiety did not make Mother quite sick. Surely "goodness & mercy have followed us all the days of our life - Hattie and baby uninjured, our dear Isaac so mercifully saved. As a family, how much cause we have for gratitude to God for the gracious manner in which he has dealt with us all along our way. Percie was quite sick two or three days last week, as probably Mallie mentioned in her letter - Croup two nights, though it did not get bad as before, and very feverish and miserable for some days - He is getting better, but tongue badly coated & not much appetite yet. He is sleeping in his crib by my side while I write, 11 A.M. His continual desire is "tell me tory" - I thought he would have given it up long before now, but it seems to grow upon him, rather.

He has been very well all winter till this ill time. It almost seemed as if nothing would hurt him - has been out about every day - When it is pleasant I often let him ride down with Mr. Martin at noon & back with Sam'l. He talks a great deal about Mayo - has most of his play arranged with reference to him. How I want to see Mayo with his tanned cheeks - Give him a good solid hug and a shower of kisses from Aunt Lucy. We are greatly amused with his funny speeches. Percie was on his knees the other day, I did not notice him particularly, but told him not to get on his knees - he looked up & said "I helping Faver pray to Dod," His grammar is almost precisely like Mayo, he uses the possessive case "in the same way, & the other day as Caroline was combing his hair in the kitchen, he came in saying, "ther is tombing ther hair." Words beginning with "h" and "r", he is very apt to begin with

"th." One day he ran to me saying "I talking about you Mover," then ran to Caroline very roguishly & said "I've dot a Mover & ther name is Thusthy." One day Samuel killed a mouse in the bedroom with his slipper & threw it out doors. I don't know how many times Percie has told me, "Faver killed a mouse tap in the bed'oom wiv his sipper & ven frew it out do doors & it was fozen to def - ony fink of 'at." He was looking at the bundles in my bag & finding several which were pieces of his garments, he exclaimed, "ony tink how many desses I have dot". Looking out the window very thoughtfully for some time one day, he said "Dod is out do doors up in theaven." I write you so much about his sayings & doings because I love to hear every one about Mayo. He learnt Percie to play a great deal while he was here. I am so glad you like your dress. We had no letter from Mother & Isaac till they reached Elyria. What did you say & how did you feel when you read of that dreadful night at Albany? It is such a strange thing for Isaac to have anxiety and

presentiment of evil. You know he rarely worries about anything beforehand. Stephen Kittredge died rather suddenly at Milo of typhoid fever, sick only a fortnight - had been but three weeks home from Europe. It is a sad blow to the family. Fevers are very prevalent up country - scarlet fever & measles are about here. Walter Rider cut his knee badly thanksgiving day - It is now a bad scrofulous sore. He has suffered very much - The Drs. are fearful that he may lose his knee, though they hope it is a little better. Dr. Mc.Ruen is going up to see it if it is not decidedly better soon. How dreadful the scrofula is! How thankful I am that Almeda does not have children! Samuel went to Searsport last week Wednes. to load a vessel with lumber, back Saturday because Percie was sick, away again
[left-hand side]Your loving sister-Lucy.

Monday to be gone a week or more. Eliab went this morning to Sedgwick, Blue Hill, Deer Isle &c. to be gone three or four days. We have the Life of Douglass to read. Have you read it? Very interesting - Hattie sent up the Watchman, a sort of sequel to the Lamplighter, I believe, but I thought I could'nt afford time to read it. I went to see a certain book to be forthcoming sometime from "Derby's." He told Sam'l it would be published this month. Mr. Rider bought two books that I shall try to read - "Inside View of Slavery" and "The Refugee". did you see in the papers, or hear of the times we had at Bangor about Mrs. Rose's lectures? A "War of the Roses" in good earnest. I fear you thought strange that I did not send Mayo's rubbers, but Sam'l weighed them & found it would cost just as much as to buy a new pair. I shall tuck in the little

pink apron into a letter sometime, unless Isaac runs down to see in the spring before going west, as we expect he will. Your little cradle quilt came in the bundle, but no little shirt. Albina could find none. I wonder if you will be astonished when I tell you that I have worked the collar (stamped) that Hattie gave me. It looks very handsomely. Was not a very great deal of work. I should have enjoyed seeing your face when you read Mallie's last letter! I wrote to Mother but don't suppose I could cheat her. The poor little creatures are both dead. We have had a little extremely cold weather, though nothing to the cold & storms west of us. Today it is very lovely indeed. We have had a few good lectures this winter, particularly Mr. Storrs' of Brooklyn. Most of them rather poor I have been to several. I imagine

the [unclear] for lectures is nearly over. S. & I have been out two afternoons making calls - have several more names on my list. Called on our new Prof. Harris & his wife. They are much liked, Hattie, Mallie & I were all at home for seven sabbaths after little "Wilmot" was born - I don't know as his name is Wilmot, they have spoken of it. I never did see such a good creature as Hattie is. She keeps the baby in her bed till one or two o'clock, then carries it to Maria & at five makes a fire herself, bathes baby & keeps it till 8 o'clock so Mallie can sleep. Mallie hardly knows what the care of a baby is. They both seem almost like our sisters to me. I like Hattie every day more & more - She has a large heart. Sammie is slowly & steadily improving. I should love to see you keeping house. I think it an excellent arrangement every way. You will know what it is to have a home once won't you? I do not wonder you cannot find time to write, but do try to favor us as often as you can - With much love to your parents & kisses for the three

Bangor Feb. 25. 1856.

Very dear brother Isaac

                    Most glad and thankful were we to hear, by your letter, of your safe arrival at Dunbarton. We have felt unusually anxious about you on this journey, since the dreadful night at Albany. I want to see you, to know how you look after it.  I think it is a great wonder that Mother was not entirely prostrated and unable to go on the next day. How wonderful in goodness to us is our Heavenly Father, & how thoughtless & unthankful we are in vain of all his mercies - what poor returns our hearts make him. I imagine that each bookseller in Bangor had one copy of "Home." Eliab succeeded in getting one, which we have all read. Duren sent a copy to the store for Sam'l the same might he get your letter

[left-hand side and top] Carpenter of Portland lectured here last week - amazingly flat. Burritt comes this week. The lectures have not amounted to anything hardly - only two of them good ones - J. G. Saxe a perfect failure. Mr. Storrs & Bethune good, as I presume will be Mr. J. P. Thompson's. Please write soon. Much love to all- There is a kiss in here somewhere for Mayo & the babies. Percie smacked the papers. I think Mayo's catechism
[upside down at bottom of letter] Lucy Feb. 25 1856

saying that you had forwarded some copies to us. We, in our partiality, think it a nice little book, certainly, it seems to me, of a better tone & tendency than many lately written books - Whether it would interest strangers as much as it does us, I dare not say! Maria was very much pleased with it. the "Bangor Journal" gave it rather a sneaking notice - saw, among other things, that there was "nothing very killing about the book." I have seen it noticed in the N.Y. Observer & Evangelist. Shall I lend it to Uncle Natty? I am confident it would go better with a different title - something more taking. I fear Anna & Miss Coleman won't both (nor either) of them make a fortune out of it. We had a letter from Mother the same day we got yours. It seems all the cold weather has been south and west this winter. We have had 
Written up the left side:

quotations very apt!  I shall never dare to tell any of Percie's

but very few days of severely cold weather, though a long time without much warm. For fifty consecutive days, ending the eleventh of February, the snow did not thaw at all in the streets! Twenty-seven below zero is the coldest weather we have had & that only one or two mornings. John Furber wrote that for the fortnight preceding the 25th of Jan. 10 below was the warmest morning & most of this time it was from 30 to 40 below - The last time Father wrote, the mercury was frozen up - by spirit thermometer 40 1/2 below. Sam'l has been at Searsport about three weeks in all, loading vessels - only a few days at a time, however - expects to go again soon - You wont, of course, think of going west to stay, without just popping down here to see us first. I long to peep in upon you & see how you & Nettie look keeping
[left-hand side]sayings hereafter - Affectionately - Your loving sister Lucy-

house! I don't doubt you feel quite as well as you look! By the way, will you ask Nettie - (Maria wrote her last almost on purpose for that, but in the weighty commencement of her letter she forgot everything else) if she thinks it would be possible for us to get two of those black girls she told us about, to come here next summer, to stay always or less. We thought if two came (one for each of us) they might be more contented. Mary is going away because they don't let her cook enough - wants to go where she can do all the work - They will do without for a while. Caroline will stay with me till Apr. or May. Then I want a good smart girl, so that I can strengthen myself in the garden if I wish. Please write us the prospect in that quarter in your next. Mr. Rider & Almeda went home the 16 - his face nicely healed at last. We have not heard from them since. Lizzie is coming the first of Apr. to go to school. Have you seen Bucher's piece in the Independent on Kansas, an extract from a lecture, I believe. Mr.

Written over the top:
Lucy Mar. 4, '56

                                                                                                                                                                                               Bangor, Mar. 4 - 1856

Dear brother Isaac
Your good brotherly letter was rec'd a few days since & refreshed me greatly - It had been a long time since I had since I had been so favored before. You had probably not rec'd mine when yours was sent. The books and money arrived safely, as I think you have been informed. Samuel says that Eliab wrote to you, directing to Elyria, in relation to the grain speculation, &c. I am sorry you feel in such a quandary about business - wish I knew enough to advise & help you out of it. Why would'nt it do to come right to Bangor & open an office, as you spoke of - you know Uncle Natty said there would be found an abundance of business here - I dare say he would have his "real estate" all surveyed over every other week if necessary to
[left side]
With much love to Nettie & kisses to babies - ever your loving sister Lucy.
[Written sideways across the top]
One night last week a few hours old baby was left in a basket at the house of Isaiah Stetson - He being out of town with his family, Mrs. Hathaway in the other tenement procured a nurse & has the care of it till they return - I wrote to Mrs. Stetson and said it was of good parentage. Capt. Pendleton is comfortable, but his recovery is very doubtful.

keep you employed! Really, I am serious - I can't see why it would not be a fine plan, till railroading business starts again - when not otherwise occupied, you should have employment at good wages in our garden, which would be good for your health & spirits, you know! Any way, we would all have a nice time & enjoy ourselves. I think you have staid at Dunbarton about long enough for once - It is time for you to comfort your friends in these parts with your presence. We do all want to see you & Nettie & "Mayo - the smart-spoken" and the crowing babies. If you don't speedily find a better opening, I desire you to consider seriously the matter of a removal to Bangor. I should not suppose you could even think of taking your family to Southern Illinois, & it is too hard for you & for them to be separated so much. Nettie, tell him he had better take his wife & children

three and come right down to Bangor & find a home till engineering comes into fashion again. Think about it & tell me your think, won't you?
Two copies of "Home" have been forwarded to Milo & Brownville - I am quite delighted that Mr. Putnam likes the book so well. I imagine that Charles & Almeda will hardly recognize "Engine Harlow." How we laugh at the name. I think 'tis a nice book. The "Bangor Journal" said it was "perfectly safe for anybody to read - there was nothing killing about it." The notice in the Evangelist reminded one of "damn with faint praise." I like the chapter on the death of Alger & the last in the book particularly. I have had letters from Matthew & Anna & Almeda lately. Mother seems to enjoy herself finely, as she says notwithstanding Anna & the Dr. are the "biggest toads in the puddle." It seems Anna has had two parties & is going soon to have another of 20 or 30

Mr. Rider's fever seemed entirely healed when he went away, but Almeda writes that there is a place no larger then the point of a pin that runs a little. I believe I wrote you that after much perplexity as to the cause of its not healing, the Dr. succeeded in extracting from the would two small bunches of clotted blood the size of a pin head - When Dr. Shepperd performed the operation, it began bleeding after it was done up & he did not, as he should have done open it again & cleaned the wound - It healed immediately after that was removed - If there is more there, how can it ever get out at so small a place? Dr. Mc. thinks the other cancerous places decidedly better than last face. You would laugh to see Percie play in the snow this morning an hour or more, till his coat & mittens were completely plastered with it. I never shall dare to mention any of his speeches again, after hearing of Mayo's. I am very glad you sent the Independent to Mother - I send the "Schoolfellow" to Charlie this year. We do take the Maine Evangelist & like it much. I am glad Dr. DeWitt has somebody to agree with him, though he is so stiff. I should despair of effecting any change in him. Sam'l did like their place much, tho it was much cluttered with rubbish when he was there. William Crosby is still in Kansas - Rufus came home sick the first of winter - is soon going back again. I should love dearly to go to Elyria with you, but have waited so long, I rather than I had better wait now till Sam'l is ready to go to Minn. & go together & have a real good visiting time. Please do write often & think seriously of my plan of coming here to "settle."

Bangor Apr. 16 1856

Always my loved brother & sister 

                       Do not think it is neglect or forgetfulness that has kept me so long from writing. I think you must have had letters from Nettie? before now (she sais she would write some days ago) telling of my sickness. I had not been able to sit up  sentence ?  for three weeks before this attack of pleurisy, a week ago last sabbath. Am much better, but a good deal of pain lingers also in my side & shoulders - to laugh troubles me considerable & very little strength - sort of slow lung fever now, but slowly getting over it - best day I have had today. Your letters rec'd of last night. Do, I ?, just come & fix up my garden, else it will have to go without love I fear - cannot write more - much love - from sis Lucy

[left-hand side] I do want to write you great long  letters - I do so want to see you all.
[right-hand side] Samuel & Lucy Bangor

              April  6 56
          Dunbarton

April 16th 1856 Brother Isaac Yours of the 11th inst. was rec'd last eve. Lucy tells you of her sickness we hope she is now improving and that as soon as she is able to go out that the air and a contact with the earth will build her up, we very much wish that if consistent with your other duties and obligations that you with Nettie and the young people would spend the summer here, we will make the best provision we can for your accomodation and comfort and furnish you with all the Employment we have in your line of business, gardening and Engineering. There has been a sort of Crisis in the affairs of P & Ross and the Maratime Bank, which to a considerable Extent affects our business. most particularly our Co. in Boston. The Bank, as you were probably aware was a kind of Family institution, owned principly by P & R & their friends and was run unto shoal

water by P & R, and was obliged to call upon the other Bks here for help who refused whereupon by the Exertions of P&R and Fath. and their friends, it was Enabled to redeem all its bills and sustains itself although it is of no assistance but a burden for the present. P&R secured the Bk by mortgage and some of their (P&R) Creditors have laid attachments upon their property. Prior to this (and perhaps the prime cause of it all) was the sickness of Capt. Pendleton, he was attacked with severe fits in Feby which still continue and he probably can live but a short time. has not had his reason since his first attack, we hope these things will not be the means of failing us and probably will not unless it makes our Boston Creditors afraid to trust as Eliab went to Boston Monday

to buy goods or fail, Mr. Raes says that we must not fail and it is in his power to sustain us if he so determines, of all their matters we shall know more in a few days, and perhaps we should be very glad to avail ourselves of the benefit of your offer. About two weeks since I deeded to you by waranty my house and lot for a consideration of $3500, for your and my security, not knowing for a few days but that we might all go by the board. The ice left our river this day and we shall soon have a fleet of vessels in our harbor. Am in hopes to give better account of our health physically and financially in a few days

                                                                                  Truly
                                                                                     S.W. Furber

Bangor April 24/56

Brother Isaac

                Yours of the 23rd just rec'd. Eliab returned from Boston to day, has bo't a stock of good on as he thinks favorable terms, our Credit being or Esteemed to be on a fair basis then, we trust that there are brighter days in the future for us.
               Lucy has been somewhat better since I wrote you. she took a little cold yesterday and is not so well to day, a good deal of head ache and a kind of neuralgia pain darting through her shoulders & neck we hope that in a few weeks she may be much better it being a

Nettie hopes a sickness not without hope. Percie is a very good boy and takes a pride in waiting upon Mover. I hope you will decided to come to Bangor we should all be very glad to see you and not laugh to see Nettie with you.

                     In relation to your $1000, we would be glad to use it for you for such time as you might wish to spare it, of course we would not take it with the least suspicion of not being able to pay it when you might want, whatever in any Event becomes of us we intend to protect and shall protect our friends our liabilities are almost

Entirely in notes which gives us an advantage in the Event of having to fail. We would like for you to take your money in your pocket and come and see us, Eliab is too tired and busy to write to night

                                         Good By
                                                    S.W. Furber

Lucy - Bangor May 6 1856
                                                                                                                                   Dunbarton
                                                                                                                                                                            Bangor May 6 - 1856.

Dear Brother & Sister

                All sitting up in my chair this most lovely May morning. I undertake the writing of a letter to you loved and long neglected ones. I am very much better, but my head is so weak that I soon get weary with reading writing or callers. I am getting along but do not gain strength very fast. I am obliged to be very careful of my side & shoulder. Last week Sam'l carried me to ride & when he came to take me out, I thoughtlessly put my left arm up over his shoulder. It hurt me very much at the time & brought on my pain & cough pretty badly for a few days but it is getting better again now. I sit up two or three hours & then

go on the bed as long, all day. Yesterday I stepped three steps up alone, but my back &limbs are very weak. With Isaac's short letter last sat. might came one from Mother and Anna - they think now of starting the middle of this month, stopping a day in Boston, visiting Dunbarton. please don't tease them to stay thee long - you can't know how I want & have wanted my Mother. Caddie is ever so good - a sister could hardly have been kinder than she since I have been sick, but when feeling so miserable so long, to have nobody else to speak to, sometimes I did "groan earnestly" as Mr. Macomber used to say - Mallie & Hattie came up often as they could, but having no girl & neither of them very well this spring, it is not very often. The great trouble with me now is that my food distresses me.

I suppose because I cough & spit so much that there is no gastric juice to help digestion. It seems to me that a person in consumption could never raise more than I have for the last two weeks. I believe the neighbors think I am in consumption! - They look it to me & whisper it to Caddie! We have been expecting Isaac every day for so long % he does not come. Percie's first question almost every morning is "Is Ucle Isaac here?"  He thinks Mayo is certainly coming when Isaac does. He is out doors almost all the time, brown as a berry, dirty as a pig & rugged - dear me- has worn out everything & I can't make any more nor even get the wherewithal to do it. I am fearful that my shoulder will not let me sew at all this summer. One day I sent him over to Mr. Harlow's with the Independent & instead of

coming home again, he started off leisurely down the street. By mere change we saw him when he got down bt Mr. Page's & Caddie started after him. When he saw her, he ran with might & main, turning every few steps to laugh & snap his eyes at her - she did her best but could not overtake him tell he had got away down to the new school house. He said he was going to Father's store, I talked to him about going away & being lost & then I should have not little Percie -whereupon he looked up with the greatest sincerity saying, "God could make you another." Like all other children, he says many cunning things, but I do not remember to write them. Caddie has concluded to stay here this summer - on the while I am very glad, though she tries us sometimes not a little by her slowness & inefficiency. With much love & great desires for speedy letters, your aff. sister

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                  Lucy

Bangor July 14th 1856

Brother Isaac

           I believe Eliab rec'd a letter from you about one week, since He went to Boston Monday last week, and got home Saturday to day he has gone to Randolph N.H. to look at some land. I will send you $50, this week we rec'd $400 from you via Manchester a few days after you left. Business in general is very dull. we are getting along as well as usual or as could be expected. In regard to Lucy's health I hardly know what to say some days better than worse it is impossible to tell what will be the

termination, we have some hopes and many fears. The hot weather effects her unfavorably last week she was worse than any time before, suffering a great deal from a cough since saturday she had been much easier, rode out this Morning. Charles and Albina were here last week also Almeda & Mr. Rider who have gone to Boston for Medical treatment & advice. Please write often. Your Mother's health is quite good. she had too much care which keeps her feeling dull and heavy.

                                                                                                   Good By
                                                                                                    S.W.F.

Bangor July 23 1856

Dear Brother & sister

           I will try to write a little this morning, because Mother has another spell of some ague & it is long since you have been written to. I cannot write much for my arms are weak & I am weak. I think sometimes that I shall never  ? writing more? have lost strength very perceptably within a few weeks, & continue to lose flesh - have constant pain in my side & shoulder & cough the same as ever. I have pretty much given up the hope of getting well - the doctor thinks there have sores formed several times on my lungs, which is the case of the spells of severe pain and hardly dare trust myself to think of leaving all I love here. It is now a bitter

thought tome that I shall not get well, but I hope I may be made willing if it is to be so - perhaps I feel too much discouraged just now. Mother may write something on the brighter side. We are feeling very anxious because we do not hear from Almeda - it is almost a fortnight since they went to Boston, & we have not heard a word. Only one letter from Elyria since Anna got home. Dear Nettie I have never thanked you for the beautiful cape or nice little apron which you so kindly sent me right in my great need, not yet for the picture so handsome & so beautifully done. It has been so admired very much, particularly the clouds. Dr. Witt admired it a long time through his closed hand. Mrs. Harlow inquired if it was prospective! Caddies has been gone home a fortnight, came back last night. We had a nice Irish girl while she
was gone that we liked much only she could not cook much. I shall try to get her when Caddies goes away.

Milo Jan. 1sr 1844.

Dear Brother Joseph

              I wish you a "happy New Year." My New Year is not quite as happy, I think, as it would be if I was perfectly well. I have been afflicted with lame feet as I was last Winter, only in a greater degree. Dr. Kimball called it "liver complaint again, and dosed me with Calomel and Nitric acid as before. I was pretty near sick a bed for a week or two, but am better now.
               I recieved your very acceptable epistle on Sunday the 24th Dec. the same long to be remembered Sunday when Thomas Tash A.B. was pleased to honor us with his presence.
              I was sick a bed, and Charles doing the work according to the best of his ability, when lo and behold! about 4 o'clock Sat. afternoon, Dec. 23rd Isaac and Mr. Tash came jingling merrily up to the door, intending to spend the sabbath with us. Well, so it was and we could not help it - so they staid, and as there happened to be no preaching in town that day, they posted over to Brownville in season for afternoon service, calling at Mr. Dennett's as they returned. They departed hence about 7 in the evening. You inquire respecting /Mr. Foss's health. I thought I mentioned in my letter that he died the Teusday after you went away. Charles watched with him the night he died. I condole with your honor stoutly with regard to your "meagre diet," and would gladly remit unto you one of my mince pies, had I a suitable opportunity. No flour bread is too bad. C. Killed one hog Teusday before Thanksgiving, and got the 1/2 from Stewart's the week after. He has fatted and killed three sheep, and salted them for beef. Mr. Gilman commenced

his wintery work here today .  C. has sold him the black horse, sleigh and harness for $100.00 to be paid in work- fifty days work this winter.  They have topped out the chimney and are going to have a stove borrow of Col Lee, to put in there.  Our Singing School is not.  They have an excellent school at the Mills-I have given up going on account of my health.  It is said that our "Village Master skilled to rule " is partial in his "little school" to Miss O.K. Furber  Mr. Gilman says that J.S. Bicker, who has taken Ms. Tibbet's school is not very well liked.

  When Charly goes to Bangor, which he intends to do soon, if you have got through with the Algebra, you may send it up, lest there should not be another opportunity; but if you have not done with it, keep it till you have, I am glad the folks like your school.  You must try to make them like better still. Mr. Keen's folks have moved into the old house. They have not elected a Rep. I believe they have had a multitude of town meetings and set up " Uncle Jimmy" once or twice, but couldn't make it go. Charly has let the oxen for two months to Mr. Monroe. By doing this and selling the horse he will save some hay to pay for lumber.  He has  not marketed your  hay yet I believe.  Aron Hill is to be married this month-- he has engaged James to construct some bedsteady, worktable, etc. and Theodore Furber desires two bedsteady send [unclear] tables. We received two letters, from Ann & from Mother last week. Ann way in Boston when she wrote but was going to Warwick the next day.  She had made a week's visit at Woonsocket, and Mother & Eliab had spent a week in Lowell.  Caleb has married a step- daughter of a professor in Yale College, and is now teaching music in Philadelphia-- he has applied for a situation in Boston as teacher of languages,  Isaac gets a living by teaching music; has two hundred dolls. salary for singing in the Episcopal church.  Enook, brother says, thinks it altogether too small business for him in a comm

room at only 20, per month, and has applied for and expects to get midshipman berth. Uncle Peletiah's, Jacob;s and Joseph's folks are all well. Josiah is teaching in Royalston Prescott Metcalf died of consumption a short time ago. Cousin Addison is at work with Hannah's husband. Humphrey is teaching school - boards at home. Mariah is attending the Normal School at Lexington - going to stay a year.

                     Mrs. Childs was smitten with a sudden fit of generosity; insomuch that she opened her heart and gave Eliab a broadcloth coat, pretty good, of Mr Child's, an old pr of pants, a nice comforter, a pr of gloves & a silver dollar as a remuneration for sundry errands done by him. To Mother she gave Calico for a dress, several yards of cotton cloth and a dollar in money etc. etc, to try to obtain a situation in Bangor again. You will please excuse the striking resemblance which this epistle bears to its Author, for I am hardly able to write at all.
Jan. 6th I sent a letter to Isaac yesterday, & intend to send this with one to Mother, to the P.O. tomorrow. C. had not got the hay home yet. I cannot tell you exactly about your hay, grain etc. but Charles will be down in the course of a week or two, and you can obtain all necessary information from him. Isaac and  Charles and, still higher authority, Mr. Tash, all think that you had better keep your school out, eleven weeks. Do you intend to go to Foxcroft in the Spring? I desire another letter from you soon, informing all about your school etc. great lubber you spake of. If I mistake not, you have a disagreeable sort of a girl there at Mr. Gibb's, that is unless she has "undergone a change" since about three years ago, when I saw her. You must give Isaac sundry items of advice when you write to him, for I conjecture he is sorely tried with so

many small scholars. Have you written to Mother yet? I wish you would write a good long faithful letter to Eliab, as I have directed mine to Mother. I suppose Isaac has written ere now. 
Remember and direct to the care of Uncle Joseph. Good night.

                                                                                                 Your affectionate sister Lucy.

Mile Me                                                                Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf                   6
Jan 16                                                                          Glenburn                  

                                                                                                    Maine

[right-hand side] Jan. 1st 1844

                        Lucy.

[bottom of page upside down] P.S. Important item.  I know not when the wild geese flew- another - I am writing compositions now-a-days for next Spring - I have one - an Acrostic which I am very desiring for you to scrutinize, criticize etc. A certain fellow came this way not long since & delivered two lectures on Astronomy and Natural History, 12 1/2 cts Admission. I was not well and C. did not go. What sort of meetings do you have at your place? I should think you might sometimes go into Bangor to meeting.

Wednes. 12th Mon. I believe

Dear Brother Joseph

           Mr. Washington Hobbs talks of going "corner ways," as little James says, tomorrow, and I desire to give you full and free permission, through him to come yourself, or send a hand, after me on Friday afternoon next, or Saturday Morning, just as suits your convenience. Should the weather prove inclement, or the travelling unsuitable, I suppose I could make up my mind to tarry in these parts another week or so, without crying, but you may depend upon it, I have a longing desire to see home.
   With regard to my school, I prosper nicely. My scholar are pretty clever, and so am I, if you'll believe me. I requested my oldest class but one (Introduction) the other day to learn the "Golden Rule" and repeat it to me after Spelling at night. Well, they studied upon it all the forenoon and afternoon and when I demanded it of them, said they, "Whatsoever men do unto you, do ye even so to them." If ever I wanted to laugh right out loud, don't you think I did then? 
      Yesternight I went by invitation to see the Agent's people. Tonight I expect to go to William Hobb's. I had a pleasant visit last eve, so reasoning from analogy I may expect the same tonight, may'nt I?
                                                                                                                                In wonderful haste
                                                                                                                                    Sister Lucy.

I understand you came as near being chosen third SS.Committee as the man did of getting his Pig. ha! ha!

Milo Apr. 17th 1845.

Dear Brother Joseph

           Here I am at home; - being released from my bondage in Hobbhood last Sat. night. 
          I saw nothing of any S.S.C. untill the last afternoon when Dr. Kimball came in. He had been there only about fifteen minutes, or so, when he was called out to go to Williamsburg on business, relating to his profession.
     I got along nicely in school till the last week, when a big boy fourteen years old, on account of some pique he had with another scholar, would'nt take his place right in the class, and when I told him to behave, he said "I shant" and doubled up his fist, so I ejected him from school. He was a very clever boy all winter before, and came to school next day shamed as a dog and good as a kitten and humble as you please.
    Don't you think I found a pretty girl up there about six years old and brought her home for Charles 'cause he has'nt any of his own. Her parents will give her away, if they find a good place. I don't know whether we shall keep her for good, and name her "Jane Rich" or not. What say? eh? Charles has hired a man named Samuel Hobbs, lately moved up from Frankfort for six months, at $10.00 for first month, and 11 or 12 for the rest, coming next week. 19 years old. Eliab went to Bangor

[top upside down]Charles talks of sending to you to go to Mr. Morrison and get an execution John Millbrock axle? trustee writ for Mr. Edler Lord but he don't know about his given name is Chs Gershorn. Charles says call and get them.

a fortnight ago to day, to take up his abode in Walter Brown's store, with Frank for a Calf, as he says. Had a bit of a letter from him last week. Mr. Brown will give him thirty or forty dollars the first year, and next year 25 or 30 dollars per month. He likes pretty well, I guess, sitting up on a high, three-legged stool. Why don't you write more all how you prosper, what you and every body else is doing.

          We had a monstrous long, great letter from Isaac last week on a great sheet of yellow fool'scap. You'd laugh to see it, I know. Nothing particular for news. About the same as usual. Hay is very scarce about here. Charles won't sell under eight dollars, and after two or three time more not under 10, he says.. Some people won't buy of him at eight, but go to Webb and get miserable poor stuff for six. They'll have to come to him when that's gone. John Livermore wanted to see you t'other day. Somebody said 'twas to buy your hay to speculate upon, but perhaps they did'nt know. He and Samuel Hobbs have been here for hay this week.
         Theodore Furber has sold his farm to Sam. They have taken a job at Great-works to raft five million of boards at eighteen cents per thousand this summer. Sarah is going there to keep house & take care of the men & in Sept. they are going to start for Wisconsin. They will make lots of money this Summer I expect. Ann and I were at Mr. Furber's visiting Teusday.
        Aron Hill's wife has been very sick - had violent convulsion fits - was given over by the Physicians. But

is better now. Think she will get well. Look ye here! "Sposin" Uncle Theoph. should be Agent in this District, had'nt I better just for the fun of it, apply for the school: I must have a space for Ann to fill; good bye. Sister Lucy H. Metcalf

                     Brother Jo if you hear any thing respecting my keeping school up there I went you should at once let me know it, if you call at Mr. Parker's you will hear. - I want to send word to Brownville whether I will go there, I have received letters from Yerusha Williams, Mrs. Pomroy, Mrs. P. and Miss Quincy. I have answered Mr. P's in phonography partly, and wrote a letter to Mary Barnes one page of which was in French. Phonography is very pretty. Sunday Uncle Henry's going to Dover tomorrow and so I will finish up what we want to say: We received your epistle Frid. eve also a letter from M. Stevens Esq. wishing me to let him know whether I had engaged a school, in case they should want me, their agent not chosen yet etc. I wish to send word to him through you that I am not now engaged, have been spoken to from Brownville, can have 2,00 per week, or in this town either I presume, rather an easier school but not so long. Tell Mr. Parker also that I should prefer that school on account of being longer employed and commencing earlier, but do'nt want to engage fully under a week or two - I don't know as they will want me yet - If I take it I should like to begin it early in May. As to your Memotechony I have forgotten how to spell it, - I can enlighten upon the science, as Parsons from whom I suppose Thurston learned it, - was at Bangor last fall gave a course of lessons at $3,00 a pupil, and instructed Mr. Pomroy gratis; it is founded upon the sentence "Satan may relish coffee pie,' those consonants in their order standing for the 9 digits beginning with t; se, te, ne, me, re, le, she, ke, fe, pe: so is the cipher there are combined with vowels in any way you please, and make words that stand for dares, thus Discovery of America 1492

te, re, fe, te, = to refute or two wry feet, or to rough tea - either of these contain the consonants and may be take to help remember the date by afroviation. Washington born 1732 re,he, me, ne, take man? no: other sentences might be made, them are what I have thought Mr. P. M. Metcalf  born 1823, le, fe, ne, me, too fine man, or two fine men; C.W. Roch 1808 le,fe, se, fe, = to feels off - you see the consonants may be doubled: I know but little about it but have heard it rather slightly spoken off by those that were good judges, do'nt believe it will be worth a dollar to you.
Apr 17. 1845
Lucy, Mother, Ann, 

                                                         Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf
                                                              Foxcroft
                                                                    Maine

[right-hand side] I expected you would have been home before now what do you do for shirt - yours are so coarse and worn that they'd disgrace you and me too. I have'nt any cloth to make any more but you ought to have some immediately if we had cloth L. could make them now as she is here & at leisure Don't kill yourself studying, it is said you know there is but a farthing, difference between those that work and those that play and those that play get it Mr. H. Sargent write by him if you can if 'tis ever so little & I do hope you have got something to wear on your neck that you had was so horrid July - you certainly must be more particular about your dress what are you going to do when school is done write to Eliab he earned away 18,00 likely as not he has spent it all for dress before now

Milo May 25 1844.

Dear Brother Joseph

                                 We rec'd your letter Thursday night, and as Charles is going to Bangor Monday, we will get your trunk ready to send by him.  You write for all you papers, books, manuscripts. etc. but I supposed you would not want your Temperance Tales, old Journal, Herbarium etc. So I have not put them in Nor any papers & books except those which were already in your trunk. I could not find the mate to your mitten, so I put in a pair of striped ones that Mother knit last Winter. They are rather small, - I am afraid too small for you, but I guess you can wear them. Charles says yours is dangerous business about cutting hands, and getting them torn to pieces by the machines. You must be wonderful careful. I will put in some finger rags as you requested, but I hope you will not have occasion to use them. Issac went back to Foxcroft last Monday. Charles had rather a serious time with his foot for a few days, but it is better now, although he cannot wear a boot. He thinks the nail will come off before it gets well.
              The same day you went away I believe, there came along an Englishman & an Irishman this way, said they had had no money since the Sat. before, were in searchg. work & could find none. Charles took them in, gave them a breakfast and set them to work.  They both worked the remainder of the week for two dollars in money, digging well, making mortar etc., which when they recieved, they went off to Bangor to redeem their clothes which they had pawned there for their board. The Irishman agreed to come back this week & work for C. at 7 dolls. per month, but he came not, I know not why.

[left-hand side] I forgot your other mittens, so we put them in.  I don't believe you will be away 7 months without once coming home. I suppose if you want anything, if you write, we can have opportunities, occasionally to send a bundle to you.

why didn't you write more particularly about how and when you get into business as well as where we are all afraid, that you'll get hurt as it is rather dangerous work for fresh hands and th'o you are pretty observing, you are not quite to alert or quick  in motion as Eliab. I charge you to be very careful. I shall send all your clothes that you sent for you sent for but I wonder that you should want so many things, for I should think that you had better come home perhaps in haying time as they don't I suppose keep the mill agoing all the summer. I don't love to have you work in a Mill and if you have not engag'd for any certain time I would not do it for if you can get in a situation where you can bring your powers of mind as well as those of your body more into action you can be more usefull to yourself and others you can if you please (and can find a suitable situation for it) make yourself of more importance in the work than a common - Millman therefore I would not engage for any particular time but have yourself in readyness and be on the lookout for something better suited to your taste and capacity. Theoph' Sargent jun. us very sick in Stillwater and his Mother is gone down to take care of him if you can make it convenient send a good long letter by her when she returns or by some other opportunity if you keep one or two written ready on hand you can have frequent changes probably to send but if you do not, Mail a letter as often as once a month certain and as much often as you have a mind to & do be carefull of yourself don't let a foolish vanity or foolhardiness lead you into danger especially don't go into the water ring often I beg of you not to practice diving and swimming so much as you have sometimes I can not but feel uneasy about you somewhat  and my son I charge you as you nature your usefulness your respectability your happiness or my peace not to place yourself in any situation where you do not attend meeting Constantly on the sabbath and wherever you are attach yourself as scholar or teacher to Sabbath school. I hope you will considerably realize that duty requires of you to use your influence which need not and ought not to be small in promoting the cause of your Redeemer in all the benevolent opperations & It is time for you - and nothing should hinder you - to take a stand in society and make yourself known and your influence felt - you know and feel all this but perhaps you are thinking you are nothing but a boy and a stranger and so it is - but tho you must creep before you can go tis not necessary that you hide yourself in a corner and remain inactive. As soon as you can get money enough for it, you had better perhaps get you a good handsome hat or cap a vest (and if it was not on account of helping Isaac if he needs) a new fashionable coat of velvet or something not very costly sometime before summer is out. I do think it is well for a young man as soon he can conveniently to dress himself fashionably and like a gentleman however your dress except the head is very proper and decent for the present.

I hope you won't spend your money foolish;y or needlessly but by no means, hold it so tight as to appear as mean or too selfish. I shall not cut off your suit? and you will not make much use of it this summer and it will do better as it is to make over into some other garment if we should want to - tis late saturday night ad I did not think if it till this minute but I think I shall send you Isaac's linnen jacket for he can't wear it and it will be very useful for you one looks and feels a great deal better Evenings, and any time hen not at work to have some kind of a jacket or coat on. I want you should write whether your work is very hard and linsome? what your company is what kind of a boarding place how many hours you have to work in a day where you go to meeting and everything else about yourself and your situation - whether you have any time for reading and study Isaac boards at Mr. Cochrans they have about 30 scholars

        G is going to B. tomorrow and must get some provisions but has not ? to get with you must get your pay once a month or so & if we can't get along without must borrow some of yours for live we must as long as we can  - unless something extraordinary happens we shall have considerable Oats & Hay to turn in the fall. it is a hard pinch this summer particularly hard for C to have to him help and provide and with nothing to do it with we could hoe along without buying much provisions if we did not have Gilman or any help but I feel very anxious to get the house done it seems if we could not prosper much till we can move down there. I am thinking that you have in thought at least magin'd Charles in thinking him selfish when it is not for himself where that he is looking out and contriving but for the good of the whole - you feel that your have a separate interest & so you have somewhat & I mean you shall have all your own but tis not so much matter where you have none any more than you want to use along. I feel that of we are all well we can all as a family be very comfortably off quite aboveboard even in a few years we shall have a good house and a god favor which will produce something more every year than we shall want to consume.
                     Mother says you can buy linen thread of any color & skeins for a cent & if you get out of thread, must buy some. I wish you would call on Miss De Wolfe some day if you know where she lives. She is a real lady & if I were you, I would call on her. I have sent her a paper this week in return for one which she sent me. I wish you would send papers often, as also letters. My advice to you is to be civil and friendly to Ricker, Furber, Butters, etc. who are there with you, and not live all by yourself, when you have friends & acquaintance all round you. It is getting late.
                                          Good bye - Your ever affectionate Sister

Be very very careful not to get your hands sawed off                     Lucy
or mutilated in any way. Also forget not to write often.

                                                     In haste, Lucy.

Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf                                May 25, '44
                                                                              Oldtown                                       Mother & Lucy
