                                                                                         Maine

[bottom of page upside down] Mother had not time to mend and fix your pants that you got of Isaac, and therefore did not send them. She has put in tho thin ones but she fears they will be too small for you.

  We emptied the ink mostly, out of your bottle, as there was a risk of spilling it on your clothes & we had not any in the house except that. Write often particularly.
   Don't cut your fingers!
   Be careful

Dear Brother

                 I received a bundle of letter from home last night by Mr. Livermore I suppose, though I was away making "parish calls" when he came.
            I'll send the letter to you and you can profit by the scolding about writing or nor as you please. I suppose your time is mostly taken up, with your business, but we must not forget Mother. You know how anxious she always is to hear from her children. I wish you would get me some pasteboard and send up as soon as you can. I should think 1/2 a shirt would be enough. Get very stiff and pretty thin if you can, & perfectly white, or as near so as possible, as my bonnet stuff is white. It must be stiff you know, to keep in place & the thinner it is the lighter it will be. Send by the first opportunity, won't you! In haste Lucy.
        Tell Eliab he must'nt learn to cheat in Brown's store & sell bad flour for good, especially when tis for the School'marm to eat. Mr. W. bought a bble there & 'twas so bad he carried it back.

Milo June 21st 1845

Brother Jo

                Why do'nt you and Eliab write to us. - I request an immediate and favourable answer to the two following inquiries as soon as consistent vis. Are you willing I should take up your order of $50. and pay you with Uncle Jacob's note to call upon him for any time you want it? & if you are not willing to do so, I must write to him immediately to pay the note at Boston at the time I am there; in that case I should only take yours till I get there, and then replace it with his payment - but if your do not want to use yours, I should prefer to let that stand. The other question is, have you transacted that business about me a school room, and if so what is the result? I want you to write soon, and relate some of the daily occurrences of your life and Eliab's too:  W. B. is just as happy as can be, and makes very little trouble, rides Pate? who has got a female nobby etc.etc.etc.  Drop the enclosed letter in the mail. 

buy some blue cotton yarn and some white 1/2 lb each and carry to Lucy to knit you & E. some summer stocking to wear with shoes and save boots.

Wednes. morn. 25th
Dear Brother
I have got your things done and will send them by the first opportunity. I hope they will fit and suit you etc. I rather think the bosoms will set well, they are hollowed so much in the neck. I could'nt fix them to match the shirts, not having you to measure by. It took all the tape for these bosom strings the way I put it on. Perhaps I did not get it right - measuring by myself, I could not judge very accurately. I have whitened the shirts some, but could not a great deal, as I could only hang them out on a line. They look pretty well however, considering.
I sent down by Mr. Dorr to get some starch as these people had none, & he got some miserable dirty stuff, very yellow & bad. I don't know whether it was made of carrots or turnips, or buckwheat. Per consequence of the badness of the starch, your bosoms don't look nice, but perhaps they'll do a day or two apiece. Sam'l Hobbs called at my schoolhouse yesterday to tell me that our folks asked him to take a bundle for me from Mr. Kittredge's and he forgot it. Great consolation to me, was'nt it? I hope twill come by Mr. Cutts today. I have 44

scholars in all - about 40 constant attendants. A lot of awful ugly boys came in this week. Oh, how I do have to "train round." The young ones here are ten times as uneasy, fidgety, fussing & flyaway here as they are in the country farther. There are some bright forward scholars and some terrible stupid things. I wish you could hear the Whitcombs & Graffams read once. They are past as much worse than Mary Fredrick, as she is worse than Tom Mitchell. One of 'em set out to spell sent 'tother day, thought of it a spell, & said t,h,a,d, sent. That is a specimen. However The Mowers & Garmans are bright enough to make up for their deficiencies.
My scholars do sing beautifully. I wish you could hear them, Though I don't suppose that would interest you as much as it does me.
A Student  - don't know his name - preached, or rather expounded, he used no notes, here last Sabbath, and organized a Sabbath School. Mr. Dodge is coming next Sunday. The people don't turn out a bit here. They don't seem to be "go to meeting folks." We might have quite a S. School if all the school children would go, but there were only fifteen last

Sabbath. Sam'l Furber was here at meeting. He is at work in Hampden, he said.
Why don't you write me a letter every few days. If you are not hurried in your business as you intimated. No matter if you haven't any thing to write. Make up something. I am going to write to Isaac about the first of July. You was a good brother to send me his letter. Send all the letters you get from home too. If I get any, I'll send 'em to you. My Mrs. Wiley is pretty clever I guess, but she is young and inexperienced. She'll lick her baby for crying & when if he feels bad about it she'll kiss him & say she never'll strike him again in the world. How some folks do train up children.
Mr. Wiley is a queer man as ever you saw. Some like your self, though. Always changing words every single time he speaks, like your "[? ?]" Thick thunderous talk." He can't speak without making folks laugh. There is another odd fellow here vis. Sam Bodge, son of drunken Bodge of Bangor. Some like his father regarding wit I guess, but of strictly temperate habit. Love to Eliab. Wite write write whenever you can & tell him to do the same. I suppose you are both pretty much engaged most

of the time, but 'tis a blessed thing to have a letter. Write if either of you want another pr of shirts, and how made. Also if you want any bosoms or collars send the wherewithal & I'll make'em. In haste Sis Lucy
Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf
Bangor
Lucy
June 25 1845

Dear Brother I have an opportunity to send today, I may not have another so good very soon, so I'll send your things. I would have done them up, but having this good chance, I thought I would not stop. Some of them will do to wear without. I've made one new one out of some linen I had left, and fixed the others according to the best of my ability. Hope they will suit you better. I'll finish the stockings as soon as I can for Eliab. You need not be troubled about the cloth Mrs. Wiley will take it & pay me money, as you gave. So you just send word as soon as convenient, the price thereof, cause she wants to use it soon. Also send up Pasteboard & whale-bone soon. I got sadly frightened yesterday. A man came down the road & sung out "School house afire." We all ran out and sure enough it was blazing on the roof. But they got water & ladders and soon put it out. Sparks caught on the roof probably. Then after school we went out in Mr. Sherburn's pasture for Strawberries, where there was a very vicious horse, unbeknown to us. As we were picking, he came at us, and I suppose that we actually ran a very narrow chance of escaping with our living. We would throw sticks & holler at him & make him shear off a little & then we would run with all our might, & he would turn & run too. Then we would throw another stick & run again, & so we did till we got to the

fence. He lopped his ears back & opened his mouth & snorted awfully. When I got fairly over the fence, I was too weak & faint, I could'nt stand, nor sit without holding on something. A real ugly horse is a dangerous animal. I expected Mr. Wiley would laugh at us and call us silly, but he said we were in danger & he didn't blame us for being afraid. 
In haste Good by Lucy.

                                                                                     Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf.                  5
                                                                                                                Bangor.

{At. Goss & Upham's}
Lucy
July 2d 1845
Written upside down:
Mrs. Dorr will board me cheaper than Mrs. Wiley and do my washing. I better change places or not? Tell me when you write. I don't know I am sure.

Dear Brother

                   Mr. Dorr goeth to Bangor& I will send a bit of note by him. I forget to take of you another  ,25 wherewith to get my dress cut, & having a good opportunity Sat. afternoon, I let it not slip, but borrowed a quarter of Mrs. Dorr.  I don't want to bother you, but girls must have clothes, not to mention notions, you know. When my school's done, I will repay this.
  So I want one of you to hand Mr. Dorr a quarter, to pay, if you will. He is going to get Lobster, Coconut, Halibut etc.etc. That's good, for us while he is gone to Milo. I want to enforce it upon you to write more to Mother, and more particularly. She is'nt very well, & anything that seem approaching to neglect troubles her , - & would any old person - very much. We all know how anxious she is for her children, & interested in them, & we ought to show her that we feel it. I perceive more & more every day, as I get acquainted with other people, in my intercourse with the world that our Mother is not like all Mothers. I suppose Mother had not in early life, very great advantages as regards Education, or opportunities to acquire polish of manners, but she has, unquestionably, what is far better, native talent, & true native

refinement, both of mind & manner. I am afraid we do not prize her as we ought, and do not realize her worth we shall if she should be taken from us. Do write to her and to Ann, affectionately & lovingly, as you both feel.
[left-hand side] Our Sabbath School depends upon the Minister of School ma'am almost entirely. There are two other classes besides ours, but the teachers are uninterested, absent half the time. Cannot stop to write more now. Good bye Lucy. If you have letters to send home, hand them to Mr. Dorr. I send a lot by him.

                                                 Mr. J. Metcalf.
                                                         Bangor
                 Per Mr. Dorr

Lucy July 1845
[bottom upside down] A Bostonian writing Master commences writing School in my dormitory tomorrow evening. Fifteen less. for 1.00. Lots of folks going. He came into my school today & invited me to attend. Mr. James (one Student) is coming Sat. to train my school on music.

Bangor Aug. 3rd Sabba day.

Dear Brother  

                 I hold to the practice of returning good for evil; and as you don't write to me, I will to you. I am worried because the Committee don't come to visit my school. I have only four weeks longer to keep, and by keeping one Sat. there, I need not, I have gained a day, so that I can close school Thurs. and go down to the city Friday & up here Sat. I want to have you understand that I must get my money before I go home, at any rate, because of paying my board & buying some things, and I don't know how I am to work it. Can I, by coming down Friday, after my school closes, present my order & get my money time enough to come back & go home in the stage Sat? You know I must pay up my board , & I shall not want to wait here two or three days after my school is done.
  I wish you could see the Com. and send them up here. They ought to come. I have got no certificate yet, you know. I am in want of a lead pencil, but perhaps I can get along, unless you have a convenient opport. to send , untill a week from next sat. when I intend to come down to see about purchasing some books for the scholars etc. a pen. Mr. Sherburne says I can go with him as well as not. I believe I wrote to you how I turned a big boy out of school tother day, did'nt I? I wrote to Isaac last week, and sent a letter home by Jo Sargent yesterday. Have you know that Hiram Thompson from Milo was drowned the other day at Bruce's mills, I believe. A man got his foot badly jammed in this mill yesterday. Had to have one or more of his toes taken off, I believe. Have you heard from home lately; if you have, pray tell me the news. I have not heard a word since Charles was down. Do write to me soon and tell me what to do about matters.

I think I shall be down in a fortnight; if I am not shall have to send to you to get me a few little books, such as I shall specify.


            Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf
                           Bangor

{Care of Goss & Upham}
Lucy Aug 3/45

Bangor Teus. morn Aug. 26

Dear Brethren:

       I am going to write this note to send by Mr. Sherburne tomorrow to tell you that you must make the Com. come up here. I have no notion of getting along without a Certificate from the great City of Bangor, if I can help it. I shall send my bill, signed by Mr. S. if he will do it, to you by Mr. Cutts Thursday. You must collect etc. take your own pay both of you, & pay to Mr. Dorr, when you see him, $5.00. I paid Mrs. Wiley & let Mrs. Dorr have $1.25. I very little expect to get my $3.00 per week. I will send your French Dictionary by Mr. C. Perhaps you may want it.
               Our Pic Nic came off in fine style yesterday about fifty present. We had several toasts, mostly mine. And Mr. James read my old Temperance Address, - new modelled, to rent it appropriate  - to very good advantage, and returned public thanks for "Miss Metcalf's able Temperance Address." The unsophisticated & unlearned population of this verdant and grass-green neighborhood called one party by divers names, as "Pig-beat," "Pig-meat" Pic Nit, Pit Nic, etc. etc. etc.

I hope if Eliab is going home this fall, if he possibly can, he will go up Friday, when I do. I want you should go too Joseph, while Isaac is at home.
Lucy                                                                                                                                               Cheese 380
Aug. 26 1845                                                                                                                                 Cracker 9.66

                                                                    Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf
                                                                      Bangor
                                               { Goss and Upham}

Milo Sept. 25th / 45

Dear Brother Joseph

         Eliab came home a week ago today and thinks he must return Saturday so I will improve this opportunity to write a bit to you, though very hastily.
    I have recieved several letters from you at divers times which I have not had time to answer, but I feel obliged to you none the less because I have not acknowledged the obligation. Your last contained much valuable advice combined with logical reasoning in regard to making my home at Kent & Cutting's the coming winter. My sentiments coincide with yours in relation to "Hog among Kings," but the question is where can I locate myself to be a "King among Hogs?" Taking a school in Hobshood. I might indeed be Kings among Hobbs, but would that answer the purpose? Seriously though I know not what is best to do, but after mature deliberation have partly concluded, if nothing transpires between now & then to alter my conclusion, to go to "The City" sometime in Oct. with the intention of staying as long as both parties are suited, but the moment the lady begins to put me down and make me "feel my nothing self," I'll come home or else "tart" her of the time when she kept school for a "livin"

opposite where I boarded, in a little old attic chamber with about seven or eight scholars from three to nine years old or so.

          I really don't know what to do. Shan't I put a "bit o' paper in the windy" and see whether it will blow in or out or stay still, and decide it that way? 
I must for something with myself. There is nothing of importance for me to do at home and I abominate school-teaching from my heart, especially in the Winter. By going down there, I can get my board and a little larnin in addition, besides obtaining little items of knowledge of various kinds which might be of use to me in after life, but I am aware that I should have very many unpleasant things to encounter. Mother seems rather to favor the plan than otherwise, and Charles says "I don't know."
         Ezra Barker commenced a high school at the Village last Monday with seventeen scholars will probably have twenty or more. I might stay here and go to school this fall to him & again in the winter (he keeps the school in our District) if "book knowledge" was all I wanted; but I ought to go away somewhere - to get a "knowledge of the world" as Mother says. I am quite "unsophisticated"  you know, as yet. They have a High School in Brownville this fall, taught by Mr. Harvey.
          I understand Foxcroft Academy commences this term with one hundred scholars. They expect

175 or 200 I believe. Tash is as popular as ever I guess. We have had a letter & paper from Isaac since he went to Turner. I wrote a long letter to him last week.

     I condole with you greatly whenever you are homesick. Rainy sundays after meeting is the worst time for homesickness to operate. I wish you could come home with Eliab, though there is nothing peculiarly interesting here except that 'tis home - where Mother lives. Milo is a miserable place, especially the Village. May well be named Sodom.
       Folks are going to work on the new road to finish it next week. Charles work is very backward indeed on account of his being sick & his man's leaving him. It has been almost impossible to get any help. Eliab will report the state of affairs.
      Mother says you don't know how much she wants to see you. You must run away a week as soon as you can possibly make them spare you.
     Eliab says you sent a Message for some books, but he can remember now only Barton's Poems, which I will send. I conclude Guthrie's Geography was another, wasn't it? However, I won't send it till I recieve further orders.
     Recieve much love from us all, & Mother says be a good boy yourself & watch over Eliab with a brother's care. Write often, especially to Mother for she will be very lonely if we are all away this winter, & I fear low-spirited too. Very affec'y
                                                                                  Sister Lucy.

Very much obliged for your brotherly care about getting my money etc. Good boy. Well done.

                                                                                                                                              L.H.M.

[left-hand side] If you sell your watch you must send home Almeida's guard?. She won't sell it.

                                                                         Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf                                               Lucy
                                                                                 Bangor                                                              Sept 25 / 45
                                                                                         Maine

Milo Nov. 30th 1845.

Dear Brother

              We rec'd the bundle in due season, as you will percieve by the letter I send to Ann; and Friday night last past, Charles brought home a "sheepish" letter from you. Very acceptable however, notwithstanding it savored considerably of Mutton. The business part of the letter I shall leave for Charles to answer, and attend only to the portion that concerned myselfl vis. "L. must write me a letter. I want it." Charles has been going to Bangor for the last fortnight & I have written a long letter to Ann to send by him, but don't expect he will go now before Thanksgiving. How I wish you "absent ones" were all to be here. Seems to me we could be more thankful if you were. Mr. Stineford was buried yesterday. Had been sick only five days, Lung fever. It was his request to have Mr. Averill attend the funeral, but he could not come so Mr. Rowell preached. Mr. R. preached here today. Has been hired 1/4 the time for a year. He has improved much since I heard him three years ago, and there still is room! Quite a full meeting today. I am glad if any preacher can call people out. Col. Lee has recieved a letter from Daniel Holman requesting dismission from this church and a Reccommendation to Hammond St.  The church voted accordingly today. How the Members if our little church are dropping away one after another. Do you & Eliab intend to ask a dismission from this Church?  I suppose

if you expect your abiding place to be in Bangor for some years, it would be proper & best, but still I don't like to think of it, that so many are leaving us, while the few that remain are seemingly so cold & lifeless and disheartened. It seems to me our prospects grow darker & darker. There are changes, but all for the words. All who leave Milo seem to be of the better sort & those who move in, of the opposite, or at least of a doubtful character. We very much need a few substantial, decided men. You must make haste and grow and be such an mane and come back here to live & renovate and regenerate this town!

            I maketh me feel sad when I think of my brothers. They are all gone away. They don't live here. To be sure, this is their home and they'll come home to see us now in a while, but they don't live here any more. We never shall be a family together as we once were. The approaching Thanksgiving remind me of it. Three years ago all were all together. One had been taken. We know not how soon others may be; and should we all live many years, we may never all meet again on earth. How "from love's shining circle 
                                                                                                                                                                                                                       The gems drop away."
 However it matters not so much, if we are prepared to meet in that "land from parting free"there to enjoy together a "long eternity of love." There is but a short time, comparatively to spend here, & but little enjoyment to be taken, ever could we have all there is.
     I want to write to Eliab, & shall by Charles if possible but you know it is a busy time Thanksgiving week. Why don't he write? It has been a long time since I have seen a letter from him. With regard to the School-house

business, I know not whether the plan was practicable or not, but as it has been put into operation, & you cannot now retreat, I would'nt let it worry me a morsel.

   You must'nt allow yourself to be narrowed. You'll injure your health by so doing. Do what you and the rest of the folks think best at the time and let that end it. Take all the comfort there is there in Bangor & wax fat; but don't "kick."
 I would like to have you purchase for me some kind of a little book, suitable for a pretty present. Not to cost more than .25. I will trust to your taste about it. A "Casket of Jewels" like Ann's, if the price is not too high, would suit, and if you find nothing better, a "Daily Food" will answer. I believe you said you had a few cents of mine in your possession; if not, I will "repay thee." I specially want it for a particular purpose. Will let you know sometime.
   We have had another freshet, though not as tall as before. Did'nt callry off Booby bridge, 'cause they have'nt got it built up again since the other. Charles' fence all carried off down to the woods, in Mr. Monason's field.
         I forgot to acknowledge the rec'pt of Isaac's letter sent with yours by Sevrance. Please also to accept my thanks for the Account Book & Mother's fir the Hankerchief. They are both very pretty & very useful. I wish I knew how to keep accounts right. We rec'd a letter from Aunts Conant & Esther by last mail. Aunt Esther send her love to "Lissa & Doda & Liba" & wants them to write to her. 

Mond. Dec. 1st Charles has waited so long he says he shall wait now for a favorable time to go to Bangor. Will not probably

go before next week if he does then. So we will send you a box of honey & a bundle of letters by stage. He'll Charles tell you about sheep, Rider money etc. Get the book, if convenient to send by. Charles when he does go. Affectionately, your Sister

                                                                                                                   Lucy.



                                                                  Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf                                                               Lucy
                                                                                   Bangor                                                                     Nov. 30 / 45
                                                                                           Maine

[bottom of page upside down] Write me a good long "correspondence" letter as you term it, and make Ann and Eliab do the same. I suppose it will not be worthwhile to write to Isaac for a fortnight or so, till he gets settled in Richmond. I don't see when he is going to have time to come home. He will have to hasten back to College in the spring as soon as his school is done. I don't know when we shall see him again.

Milo July 10th 1847

Very dear Brothers,

                    The spirit moves me to commence a letter to you, having, however, no very definite idea when it will be completed and forwarded to you. We prosper finely these days. Everything is beautiful and flourishing about here. It has been so very warm this week that things have grown astonishingly. Can see things grow in the garden every day. 'Posy Patch' looks finely. I have wed every bit of it, hoed up all the thistles etc. Strawberries are very plenty, though almost gone now. I have not picked any but once. Raspeberries & Blueberries are abundant in promise.
               Recieved a letter from Isaac yesterday. Nothing very particular except his great want of money. Poor fellow! what shall be dome for him? Mother sand Charles have talked about it.

Tuesday P.M. 13th July. Charles thinks of going to Bangor tomorrow, so I'll finish my letter and send it by him, though my pen and ink are both bad. The trunk and band box arrived safely yesterday. A letter from Samuel Monday, the day you went down.

       You will probably not be surprised when I tell you that I have at length decided the question and given him an affirmative answer to his proposal, now concluded it is right & best. 
    The time is not decided yet, but be it sooner or later, I suppose I am enjoying my last home visit, Is it always that this thought somewhat lessens the enjoyment  of it. A home, where all has always been sunlight and happiness, with kind friends who have ever

been tenderly thoughtful for my welfare, has this far been my lot; and I don't know as I have any reason to doubt the continuance of this happiness with another home and a new friend; still, I know not what may be before me. I can hope and trust. To both of you, and indeed to all my brothers, I feel that I owe a debt of gratitude which I can never repay. For all your kindness, and especially for the tender regard for my feelings which you have ever manifested, I most sincerely and heartily thank you. If I felt perfectly sure of recieving from another friend, the kindness, in every respect, which I have always recieved from my brothers, I would ask no more; - and even though I have perfect confidence in the sincerity and strength of his attachment, still, it is not without a deep struggle of feeling that I can look forward to the day when I shall forsake, as it were, the home of my childhood, and those loved ones who have ever proved true and kind, to such a new home, and entrust the keeping of my happiness to a new friend.

            In connection with this change, there is, mingled with hope for the future, a feeling of sadness in thinking of the past, which I can hardly describe, and which I know not why I should feel. As brother and sisters we have enjoyed much. When all at home together, years ago; and still later, though separated much of the time, our affection for each other has not been diminished. I have always joyfully confided and trusted in my brothers perfectly, fully. In return they have given me confidence, kindness and affection. In this, dear brothers, may there be no change in any of us. Change of situation need not occasion change of feeling.
               I tell Mother these are my "Halycon days,"

I never expect to enjoy so much again as now, and for a few years past. Not that I do not hope for, and expect a pleasant home - of course I do, or I should not have made the decision I have - but with it will of course come care and anxiety.

           Will you, my brothers, pray for me, for us, that we may be kept in the right way, which is the way to happiness and peace?
                                                                                                                                                                                                         Ever your affectionate Sister
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                Lucy.

I forgot to inquire after Miss Treat. Please tell me how she got home & how she is when you write. and do write soon. Another thing, Joseph, did you find, and do you know where is, you Herbarium? I desire to looks at it very much indeed, but cannot find it. What a heavy thunder shower we have here this P.M. I never heard such crashing thunder in my life. Your bosom I will endeavor to finish to send by Charles - Hope it will fit better than before. Don't know as I shall have time to do it up. Good bye

                                                                                                                                                                                                                       Lucy.
          What time did you get to Bangor. In what plight were Mrs. Weston's Strawberries? Do write both of you.

Brothers Joseph M. & E.W. Metcalf                                                                                             Lucy

                                    Bangor                                                                                                   July 10, 1847
                                                                                                                                                  Engagement

[upside down in pencil] Did Joseph leave his pants home purposely or by mistake - We did not know whether to send them or not.

Milo Oct 1st 1847

Dear Brother Jos.

              Just rec'd this morning a letter from Isaac, which, in accordance with the earnest request from the back. Mr. Mocomber should have forwarded last night. Had he done so, we could have sent Isaac's things by today's stage instead of waiting till Monday. They have all been ready for weeks, waiting for Charles to go down, which he has been expecting to do. Hope you will not send the trunk until you get them. His things, with the key to the trunk which he left with me, are by themselves, your shirts and some things for Ann besides. Have been expecting, from hat she wrote,  a bundle from Ann. Don't know whether it has been sent, and we not got it or not. When you said, better perhaps come by Mr. Welch, and be left at Mr. Kittredge's. Why and wherefore did Moses come home? Did he not answer your purpose, or was he homesick?  Mr. Kittredge wants you to have Steven. Says he may stay with you a year for his clothes & board. Stay in the store or help you on the wharf. He is heedless, somewhat "rattle-headed" perhaps, but good at figures, considerable tact at business, and accustomed to being in a store. However - perhaps you have got another boy before now.  Your horse remains safe and sound and unmolested in the pasture which C. fenced off at the head of the interval. Growing fat and antic

Don't believe you'll ever be able to drive him if you get him. How is your case likely to be decided, in your favor or otherwise?

          Charles is getting along nicely with his work. They are working on the new road today. A good deal of travel on it - will be more after 'tis done, probably. C. thinks he shall have as much as fifty bu. of corn this year - ten loads of very nice pumpkins on the interval -more up here, and a great many beans.
               The woolen shirts which I am making one partly done will send them very soon - two pairs.
            Is it not the case that Angella Dennett and Joseph Treat will one day make a Treat-y? I summise that such is the fact.
            I don't know but the precaution is unnecessary, but we will put this in the Office so that you may call at the Franklin House for the bundle, as the driver may not be willing to carry it to you. The key I out in a paper with Isaac's thing.
           Tell Eliab why don't he write. I must rebuke him for sending any money to pay for making shirts. He ought not to. A pr of stockings for him. Do you want any more for yourself? Write to us when and often as you can - all about your boy and every thing. In great haste.
                                                                                                                                                   Very aff.- sister Lucy.

You will oblige me much by putting the enclosed billetdeau in the P.O. Tis only a card about swearing - you know. "It chills my blood etc. " It may do good & can do no harm.
[at top upside down] what are you going to do with your horse better sell him quick I should think. C had ten loads of pumpkins on "that acre" on the interval, probably 20 or 30 bushels of corn, beans in abundance & carrots and turnips.

Mr. Bucher is going down Teusday. Perhaps he will call for a bundle if you have anything to send. 

 Mother says tell Joseph we have got butter enough to pay him when he goes down.

Dear Broth.

                     the flour is nice wish you would get me another barrel before the price rises shall want more in Feb. you have not told me how I can sell shirts or how many to send to you wish you would give me what light you can upon the subject for I don't know whether to get heavy or light cloth am making some now that it takes more than 11 lbs for a pr.
I wish to leave it to your judgment when to buy the flour

I wish you would write a word to Isaac about taking care of his health if he can bear to sleep with his windows open blowing right onto him when it rains and lay down on the ground during a wicked shower & let it pour right on him all the while (as he did when here) & not hurt his health - he had certainly better not - he don't appear so gentlemanly & there can be no need of such doing

Lucy
Oct 1 1847
Forwarding trunk to / Gase

Milo Oct 1st                                     Mr. J. M. Metcalf                       5
Me                                                   Bangor

                                                              Maine

Northfield Oct. 17th 1847
Dear Brother Joseph
I found my trunk at Brattleboro's last Monday, safely arrived; Charges $1,121/2, Jerome & Co $,50 K. White $621/2. Was that about right? The trunk contained about what I wanted; as near at least as could be expected, considering the circumstances and whose trunk it was. The letters were peculiarly acceptable; the first I had received since leaving Down East. Your letter was rather brief. If you never sin except in way of the "multitude of words" you put in your letters, you may as well start for Oberlin at once. 
Your Schedule of accounts observed. The sum due you shall be forwarded as soon as I can do it conveniently. It may be that I shall not be able to do it by the time you mentioned, first of Nov. I am I suppose earning money, but when I shall receive get it I dont yet know. I have about $10,00 now by me. I shall be obliged to spend considerable for clothing as the cold weather comes on. It is an occupation where one wears out clothing pretty fast, and as there is a good deal of exposure, it is needful to dress warm.
What are you sneering at Mt. Grace for? Were you even upon it on a clear day with a good spy glass? If you ever ascended Mt. Grace, did you open your eyes while there?

Your admonitions upon the subject of personal health are kindly received. Although in the present case needless, they may not be wholly worthless. It would perhaps be well if the could redound where they would be appropriate at least, perhaps needful; to the case of thyself & those of thy kin about thee. those who are placed in unhealthy conditions & situations Advices as to the market value of Onions carefully observed. In reply would state that the price of last year's corn in Northfield & Brattleboro has fallen from $1,00 to about 4,90 per bushel. also that the demand for shoe pegs is probably increasing; that beef is much eaten by Irishmen, and potatoes are rotting. &c.
Does E.W. Metcalf talk of going into the Shook trade in Canton? The prices of Lumber at Northfield I have no means of knowing. I see no sign of any trade in the article. None is ever brought up the river. Whether the R.Roads may sometime make it worth while to bring small quantities of best qualities of Eastern lumber here I know not. Every where above here that I have been, at Brattleboro &c. Slate appears to be used instead of Shingles, sometimes even in the covering of Barns, Hog pens & privies. Slate quarries are abundant. My Congratulations to the W.P.C.D. No. 29 S of J. How is your beard? I believe it is your best!
Your Valise I do not see as you are likely to get hold of again very soon. It is likely too to see pretty hard service this Fall & Winter, boxing about in our buggys from one tavern to another &c. perhaps over the Mountain. The best thing you can could do will be to charge it to me & get another

Dear Sister Anne. Among other letters which gratified my eyes when I found my trunk was one from you To be sure I was a little disposed to quarrel with is as being upon only half a sheet; but it was better than none. Eliab wrote none at all.
You speak of visiting relatives &c. I did not think at first so much of seeing those I knew nothing about, perhaps never saw, but begin to like them where I have become acquainted. Mrs. Dickinson I have not seen - I did not when I came here even know her husbands name. She lives over the river, and I did not know the way. When I was at Northfield, Cousin Hannah kept promising to go over with me but did not. Now I am elsewhere, and my time belongs to not myself. I shall certainly embrace the earliest opportunity to go there. I have been to Winchester to see Cousin Josiah, but it was when I first came here, long before I received your letter. When I was there I thought I remembered going there once with Mother to an Uncle Rich's, but I knew nothing of him, whether living there or not. I should have been happy to have gone there if I had my shirts I received from Mrs. Shepperd at Brunswick they are nice ones! I have bought a new coat, but it is a great rough sack to wear in woods &c. You tell me to write much &c. I do wish that you and some of the rest of the folks would write half or quarter as much & as particularly as I do

Dear Brother Eliab. What do you mean by not writing to me. Not one word among the letters in my trunk. I think I have written enough lectures to you on that score already. One of you shirts it seems you have lost. "What you goin to do about it?" I hardly ? you can get it again very soon. Perhaps you had better let me wear it out for you & you get others. Only it is too small for me.
Brother Charles & the rest of you all, what are your politics? or what are they likely to be in the Presidential canvass of '48?

In old Massachusetts the old Party lines are fairly and fully gone. The frame or shadow only is held up by the political especially the Boston papers, the "Cotton" interest as some call it. The Democrats in their convention nominated you know bushing & bushman one now a Whig the other lately, and that party go full for Taylor as president. and so do the Boston Whigs perhaps. But the rest of the Whig party and the better part of the Democratic perhaps, go against the War & Taylor in toto. headed by the "Boston Whig" (a first rate paper edited by Sumner, Palfrey, Adams, Phillips &c. Boston Courier, & country papers. The favorite Candidate of this party would have probably been Silas Wright of N.Y. of Wilmot Proviso memory, if he had lived. Northern Whigs would have united upon Wright, a former Democrat. Southern Democratic Slavery men upon Taylor & Cushing There is, there can be but one question before the country. the great all important (War Slavery) question. & people are getting to know it. 
Vide D. Webster's speech

Milo Oc. 19th 1847.

Ma Chere Frere

                                Your bundle, as you have probably learned ere this by Alfred Holman, was found at, and taken from Nye's store last Friday, the 15th inst. How long it had lain in that place I know not, but conclude not many days, from the date of your letter. The Bible is very pretty, neatly done - much obliged for your trouble. From your letter I very much fear that your shirts, and perhaps Ann's things were sent on to Isaac. I thought I took every possible precaution that there might be no mistake. I rolled your shirts by themselves, put a paper round them, and a letter directed to you on the outside. Ann's things I fixed in the same way. I just now happen to think that after putting your letter with your bundle we concluded to send your letter by mail, fearing you could not get the bundle otherwise, so soon, and took it out, but Eliab's was left in, so I hope you gave it to him instead of sending away. Please let me know so I may worry about it if you did! 
     Moses is well enough and has been for all I know. Have not heard that Mr. G. is displeased. Presume he is not. The folks are at work on your

pants - hope to get them done this week - Possibly Charles may go down next week. If not will try to find an oppor. to send them without expense. I believe there were materials enough with the exception of thread, and we can supply that. You have written never a word whether you have got another boy - nor who he is. I ask where is brother Eliab? And what is he about? Not a word has he written home but just once since he was at home in July. Why is it? I have written to him  and so has Mother over and over again, but no answer. Do get him to write to us. Your horse is growing fat. She and Bichy are so antic there is no getting along with them, hardly. Your's, I suspect, is terrible ugly, but we don't say so, not anything else about it. Almeda has a husking tonight. Mother, Albina and I helped C husk all the P.M. yesterday. Corn moulding so much wet weather. Hiram goes to writing school. No help about husking evenings - Good bye - in haste. sis Lucy.

               C. had plowed up all the east field - Finished today I believe. The new road is done. A good deal of passing on it.
              Thank you for your hint about Teusday.  Will endeavor to write it Tuesday next time, tho' I always write that wrong I believe - Good bye.

[upside down] Lucy

                   Oct. 19 1847

Milo Oct. 26th 1847.

Dear Brother Jos.

                        Am sorry you have been troubled with Gloves, socks or shirts either. - but 'twas all we had to pay with. Would'nt trouble about stockings and gloves - wear them if you want, or send them home again.
             Sam - excuse me - Mr. Furber is going to Bangor tomorrow probably - so we write a bit and send pants, which were all completed last week. A pair of the raw material deposited in the pocket of each pr for the unfortunates who purchase and wear the same to mend with. You may recommend them as the man did for his Gum all chewed in his own family! Albina wants all you have to make. She is in a great rage to get Charles' debts paid. Nobody has been after your horse - but C. Says you better not let him go on trial, he is so ugly - contrary but put in a team might work well. Very high spirited. What think you of poor Pres. Shepherd? Alas! "There's many a slip"  etc.  Rather mortifying and vexatious really though, wasn'nt it? You inquire about bosoms etc. You sent cloth for six shirts and linen for fours bosoms - Four shirts I marked for and sent yo you, two having bosoms and two without. Two shirts, by your order I marked for and sent to Isaac together with the remainder of the linen, manufactured into shirters. Do you stamina now? O think you would like the shirters. If you need more bosoms and will

send linen, I will make them like Isaac's. Your new patent Potatoes are yet in the ground. Charles says they are "doing well." Wherefore is it a bad habit to say Sam? 'tis his name - what he calls himself, and others call him. Shall I denominate him Samuel, or Mr. Furber, with more propriety?  He thinks some of staying in Hampden another summer. Had he better, at sixty dollars per month? Wherefore were you sent away from Mrs. Weston's? Should not think you would like to board at Washingtonian House. Mr. Thaxter called it a miserable place - secret rum hole. Sebaru himself is a drinking man. Is it so? Wish you could find more time to write. Sorry you are so continually perplexed and harrassed with care and business. Hope it will not always be so. Good bye - aff. sister Lucy.

Milo 11th Nov. / 47

Dear Brother Joseph

                             Yours of the 27th ult. was rec'd last Tuesday, the 9th inst. Your advice was very good indeed, and I thank you for it. Exactly my sentiments, however. I never yet spake to Mr. Furber and called him Sam and perhaps never may. His name is Samuel - by that I have been of late accustomed to style him. Perhaps in company should choose the cognomen Mr. F. but when speaking to him, or of him to brothers & sisters, should prefer the given name, I think. Do you not agree with me? Mt parents, brethren (yourself excepted) and sister have been wont to say Sam, and in speaking of him to them I have occasionally done the same, but tis not my intention so to do. Much obliged for your hint, and will thank you always for reminding me of the same, whenever you see that in my conduct which ought not to be; -whether I sin carelessly, wilfully, or through ignorance.  So far as I am acquainted with Samuel, I deem him a person of good common sense, one who looks on the "sober side of things" and if I have never yet "seen anything serious in life, had any responsibility,  care or trouble, " perhaps by associating with him, I may learn to take different views of things. At any rate, the future doe not seem all sunshine to me. Very far from it.
          I think it is for our own happiness, as well as those about us, to be cheerful, and I do not know as this conflicts with the idea of "looking on the sober side of things." Does it? I don't know as I have written my ideas so you can understand what I mean. Mother, Charles and Eliab are carrying on a very spirited conversation about Orchards, "getting a living by farming" etc. etc. I am very glad you are away from the

Wash. House. I did'nt like the idea of you being there a bit, from what I knew of it. Eliab thinks he will go back tomorrow, but I very much feat he is not yet well enough. If he uses not great care, he may, before many months be brought down with acute liver complaint.

              Mother and Charles will write what Eliab does not tell you about what they want you to sell and purchase. A trunk of things Ann and Eliab will deposit at your store to come with the Flour. Write us all about your new boarding place and whatever else we want to know & you have time to write.
                   Good night. Affectionately Sister Lucy.


Brother J.M. Metcalf

      Bangor


[upside down] Lucy

                    Nov. 11th 1847

Milo Jan'y. 12th 1848.

Dear Brother Jos.

                      Commencing in order of time to answer your respective epistles, - first that of 23rd Dec. 1847. Previously to receiving that, I had almost concluded you were never going to write again. The letter being equally to Mother & myself, we are both equally obliged. As for the Butter part of your letter which comes first in order. the "Rec'd firkin" ought to keep well. It is the very nicest butter which was made during the season, and ought to bring the same price as lump butter, as it was put down to order. People are not willing to allow so much generally for firkin butter, but you must tell the circumstances & make them.
    Your journey to Boston & back was quite "a time" I should think. You did not write whether your ear troubles you, or whether you found your cloak and valise. Why did'nt you put them in somebody's care? I suppose you was obliged to go, but I would'nt if I could help it, again so late in the season. Was'nt you sick after it? Why could'nt you tell us how your sick wife got along, as well as the old lady in Topsham? Very much thank you for the verses. Very good indeed. Ann waiting for some more! You don't tell the Author. I therefore conclude 'tis your honor. I have neither ability nor disposition to criticize them, to say nothing of time, which seems more valuable to me this winter than ever. The Mexico piece is very good,

some parts of it fine. The other is good, very, but I like not that style of Poetry so well as some. In the eighth line of the last stanza, I would inquire if there might not be a better arrangement than to make two syllables of "yours"? I would like to keep these very much, but as you are so urgent, will send them back. I should transcribe them, but my shoulder is so lame I cannot write so long. This ink has been frozen and is very pale - hope it will grow blacker.

             Your last dated Jan. 6 - 1847 was rec'd last evening. I am afraid you don't sleep enough, think too much, and thereby get nervous. You admonish & lecture me from time to time about cultivating correct judgments - "toughening my feelings" etc. etc. (which advice is very good & for which I am much obliged) and now permit me to return it in part to you! I say that under deprivation of "nature's sweet restorer," incipient worryment, cogitation & anxiety of mind, about business, friends, or anything else must (in any of us Metcalfs, at any rate) create derangement in the nervous system which derangement causes, not only incorrect judgment in some case, but an overstrained, highly wrought view of every thing - especially the dark side of every thing. You suppose perhaps, that my situation and prospects lead me to give too bright an aspect to affairs, to look on the future as all calm and sunlight. I do not. I try to and think I do, see things somewhat in the light of common sense. You think and no doubt think truly, that I have, as yet, had few trials, and know little of the troublous things of life. It is true. I know it is; yet the feeling of entire dependence upon somebody  for everything I have

is not far, in some cases, from being a trial. Though given with perfect willingness, the feeling that I am receiving what others need and want, is not pleasant. In exchange for this, I expect other, different, severer trials. I don't know as it is wrong for me to anticipate some happiness. I certainly expect much disappointments. As you say, all have troubles & cares, and every heart "knoweth its own bitterness." I think a good deal of Ann with regard to these things. Many of her sad feelings we cannot understand  - or at least, not as she does. Almeda, too,  has her full share. I think sometimes that men in business, have greater anxieties, cares and responsibilities, while women have the lesser ones, a great many of which are as hard to bear as one great one; - they, too, it seems to me, have more trials of the feelings than men - but perhaps I don't know.

           The business part of your last was duly attended to last eve. With regard to the sheep, I had nothing else, and no way to get anything. I disposed of them to Mother and Almeda two to the former & one to the latter, to get the shirts which I sent to you, and with which you have credited me. I don't know what I can do. I know you are in want of money, and have worried & worried about in how I could pay you but I have nothing of my own. Mother will write to you something about the sheep, she says. Your advice about a knowledge of pecuniary matters being desirable is duly appreciated; such knowledge every woman ought to possess; we know not what may be, but I should think, & most any one would suppose the probabilities much stronger than the opposite might take place in a few years than that I should become a widow. It is certain any prospect of long life is not as good

as that of some others. I expect now to go to Bangor week after next. Shall want to talk with you a good parcel then, about a good many things. Report here says there are thirty cases of small pox in Bangor. Some people are much frightened about here. Our schools have been stopped three or four weeks - not begun yet. Several new cases been brought out of the woods lately to Brownville. Hiram was vaccinated last week - most sick yesterday and today. Why don't Eliab write? I can't stop to write to him now - tell it when I come. 
We rec'd letters from Isaac & Aunt Conant lately. I feel sorry we are not going to live in Bangor next summer on your account. I wanted you to live with us. However, the summer will soon pass away. I suppose the present arrangement is best. You do not write about your boarding place, much, whether you like it or not. Tell Ann and Eliab to wait for their letters & I'll deliver them in person - or by word of mouth. Good bye Aff. sister Lucy.
[upside down at bottom] Lucy. deprivation of sleep. The heart knoweth its own bitterness.  Jan'y 12 1848.

Very dear Son. We all think you to be a very "likely fellow,, Some of us Isaac Lucy Almeda etc. etc. think you almost perfect considering who your relatives are - but if I have any words where with to express my ideas - & withall if my ideas were not so confused and worthless - would undertake to tell you wherein you need mending - this I begun to write you days ago & got discouraged. I feel for the most part of the time that whatever I could write would not be worth the reading . I don't know what to do for L. poor girl if I had anything or could do anything to help her I would be glad to it seems wrong to me (as there is property in the family some) to have her so situated that she must be dependent on S. for every thing even Wedding dress to be taunted with it in years to come tis possible. She would have kept school and got something to pay you the last summer of her health has been sufficient for it. She ought to have a decent dress & I want she should have a half Doz. silver teaspoons marked with her name I have been thinking to keep 10 sheep on the farm here. ? my own use to clothe myself with etc. but if I could sell 4 or 5 of them I would be glad to, to get these things for her.  tis very possible yes probable that you ay want in sewing or something she can do the full amount tho' not in clear cash your letter cautioned? her some times but by the sadness of the countenance My heart is made better some times I have not time to write anymore at present I want to talk with you shall we never see you do come home I want to write more but I have not time now

Mother
Lucy's affairs.
Jany 14th 1848

Milo                                                            Mr. J.M. Metcalf
Me  Jan 14..                                                      Bangor
