Milo Jan y 24th 1848.

Dear Brother Jos.

                     I put a letter in the Office for Ann this morning, but Almeda is just going over to see her elder Lord about bring of come Flour etc. for her, so I'll scribble a word to you. Am disappointed again today about going to Bangor. Might have gone in a wagon, but thought it most too cold, as I am not very well. Hope we shall have snow before long. I wrote Anna all the news - you will see it - about small pox etc. etc.
                The linen you mention will do to make common bosoms - not very nice. One yd will make a pr. I think there was linen enough left of that you sent last summer to make two or three collars,  Will you send a pattern how you wish them made, also directions as to manufacture of bosoms. Whether you like small plaits, like those in your shirts, or still smaller or larger. Don't Eliab want some more made? Perhaps he had better send it by Samuel. when he comes, if you see him. You say in your last "don't be foolish." I don't mean to be. I had a good deal of you, intending to teach school and repay you. My health was not, and is not now sufficient for it. I talked to Mother about it, and worried, but could do nothing. Things are just as they are. I have nothing for myself, or others, and Mother can make nothing available for them or me at present. Says when she can, will help make restitution for what others do for me. Some things are necessary, others perhaps expedient. But I must'nt stop to say more. Almeda is waiting, Good bye. I mean to write to Eliab this week. Affectionately sis Lucy.
 I want you to change the boots and get no. 13 I send some more butter which I want you to sell for me 

I send my flour by Mr. Lord and want you should send a broom too.

Lucy
making shirts etc.
24 January
1848


                                                          Mr. Joseph M. Metcalf
                                                                 Bangor
                                                                    No. 10 Broad
                                                                                 Street

Dear Brother Jos.

                      I hoped to write you quite a letter, but have not time now - you can get all the news from Eliab's. Hunt up a nme for Nimshi, will you? And - you have'nt sent me the rest of that poetry yet. I want to see it The piece you could'nt find in that paper too. I had so little time, and so many things to think of that it seems as if I did'nt see you and Eliab any when I was at Bangor. By the way, the slip of paper you handed me just as I came away, I lost. Won't you write it again in your next? I put it in my pocket as I thought, but when I got home it was not therein.
                You have not written whether your bosoms suit you. Am afraid they did not. Tell me in your next, and if not, just where they fail, will you? Seems to me you don't write me so many good nice letters as you used to. Why? Don't you have time? Isaac says 'tis not wicked to perform such acts of mercy as writing to absent brothers and sisters, sabbath day! We rec'd a letter from him last week. Seems in very good spirits as usual. One thing I forgot to mention in Eliab's letter - Uncle Nathan Steve's oldest son - a bright lad of 12 or 14 years died recently. What do you think of Mother's going to Mass. with Isaac when he come home in the Spring? Fine thing on many accounts I think. I am sorry we had not time to call at your boarding place when I was there, but you must percieve I had so little time, I was very much hurried. Ann can call just as well. 
                                                                                                                                                                                 Do write soon, won't you? good bye.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Affectionate sister Lucy.

Don't you think it a nonsense plan they've got about my going to Mass. to be sure I could enjoy it very much & especially if I could have Isaac with me - But wont it be right to spend so much money as it would cost. Do write to me soon.
[left-hand side and top] Joseph don't you mean to come home before the middle of next May. I say you must now while you have no wife or children you ought to be willing to see your Mother as once in six months at least.  I suppose it is difficult for you to leave your Business but recollect it will probably be more and more so for you and Eliab both

March 29. 1848

Dear Brother

            I should have written some time ago only I told S.W. Furber all I knew about Sargent & Holman's business. When I left Sargent came about 3 weeks since they had about about 50 thousand shingles made and hauled out as far as Milo they had stuff enough sawed and hauled together for 100 thousand in all I think they will be as good as those sent to you with the exception of a very few of poor ones sorted out they have had three hands shaving since but it is Doubtful whether they get quite all made up in season to haul out to the Iron works before sleding is gone.  I understood that Severence hauled down a load of Sargent & Holman's shingles for one Mr. Bunkers and sold for 60. dollars at fifty dolls. for Mdl? but that is only hear say they have hauled in about 40 ? of Pine logs and the expected to sell them to the Iron Works - cost of dolls. per ? the shingles that are not hauled now will not probably be hauled till the ground settles I expected they would have sent them right down to Bangor what if I see then is quite a pile of them at Bunkers store. I think likely they have contracted debt for hay, Provinder etc, about here to the amount perhaps of $50, but it is only guess work they ow me $97 1/2 Dolls and gave me an order on you to be paid in cash when

you received shingles enough to pay what they owe you and enough to pay me. I should like to know how many they have sent to you and what amount of goods they have had of you I expected they would have sent enough to you by sleding to pay you and me but they walked that they should hold on to the rest till the price of shingles was higher. Hector has hired another hand to shave about a moth at $20. per month I know nothing about their having any offers for shingles. They get no clapboard cutt.

    Holman and Sargent go halves in furnishing labor or supplies and Proffits though Hector's half is subdivided by taking in young [Will?]] Homlin who is also in company with him in buying Hills Farm but As for whether a demand against Sargent being good against Holman &  Sargent I suppose any supplies get for their lumbering concern would be good against both Holman & his son Wm. and Hector & Wm. Homlin make up the crew Holman and Homlin shaves the shingles and pretty much all the business of Procuring supplies etc. is done by Hector. I understand they have caught 13 + Moose since I come out if I had had a pair of snow shoes I should have had a share of them. Hector calculates to keep his Bars upon account of old debts Everet I believe holds most of his attachable property, his Oxen etc. he told me that he had sold his lumber or his interest in it to Everett But I suppose it was only to make sure of it

I think they calculate to pay up all their bills I think they will make a pretty good winter's work he told about his having to pay $50. the Middle of March and that Aaron Hill would lend him the money he has got $75, to pay for his Oxen in June to Rollins. He expects to go on to the river on a drive this spring.

                                                                                                                                     C.W Rich

Dear Brother - I cannot stop to write much as little Jamie's waiting to carry this to the Office, I besieged Charles about answering the questions, till in self defense, he sat down & wrote himself every thing he could tell, he says. Of the revolutions in Europe, and of matters in our own country I desire to know much more then I can find out. No papers. but Mirror, ? only short notices in that. It is outrageous that we here can not get hold of a single new book, periodical of any kind, not even a paper that tells much of what is going on. I know a little something about the doings in Paris. Should'nt have known much if Samuel had'nt  told me. Who laughed at me? All did their share. Almeda most - Ann some. But I don't care one bit about it. As you say, if they had'nt I should probably have been spoiled the other way. With regard to coming home - the 17th of May is concluded on. You must not come before, unless you will come then too. Mother & Almeda want very much to have you come soon to talk etc. but I cannot think of all the rest being here & you away. Now really, you won't think of any such thing will you! Come right off, and then too, won't you. Am afraid Eliab will be tired of waiting for his shirts. They are all ready. Send by

your letter was unsealed when it got here two a pages not stuck ??               Charles & Lucy 

                                                                                                                                    Mar 29 1848
                                                                                                                                  H & Sargent affairs

Milo Me Mar. 31,

                                                     Mr. J.M. Metcalf
                                                      Bangor
                                                                Maine

[bottom and cont. on right-hand side] I have written in such a hurry I hardly know what I have written. Suppose Miss More speaks her wishes, which are certainly very natural - only in the imperative- Mean to write again soon. Do send my brush and comb which Ann says are at your store, by Samuel if you see him tomorrow - next oppor. Miss More is quite a little Poetess, is'nt she? Send me some more. Great haste - must not stop to write now. good bye. Sister Lucy.
The sentiment of "the grey hair" is not quite correct, is it? Or is it only a ditty without intention of much sentiment Almeda wants to know if split Palm Leaf is to be obtained in Bangor -pretty fine - if not she wants to know immediately so as to send to Isaac before he comes home, if he comes.

If some strangers are to be here, others may as well cine so bring 'em all along . At any rate - that is be consistent - come yourself - It won't take you away from your business long. All the rest are to be at home. You will? I shall feel very much disappointed if you do not.


                            Mr. Eliab W. Metcalf
                                           Bangor

Dear Brother Jos.

         Have but a moment to write, but beg you to accept my thanks for your nice and generous present, which came duly to hand last Tues. evening. Very much I thank you my brother. I know not whether circumstances are such as to render it proper, - if that you will please judge for yourself - but I will venture to invite you to bring Miss More home with you, the 17th of May next. We will be happy to see her if you think proper to extend to her, and she to accept such an invitation. Rec'd a letter from Isaac last night. Says he shall be here. No more time - good night Aff. - sister Lucy.
        Issac wishes me to get shoulder braces and I am very certain they would be very beneficial. Will you inquire if they are to be obtained in Bangor & if there is enough left of what Isaac sent, procure a pair. In his last letter he sent another V because I used the other partly to get his shirts. I intend to return it to him.

He says he needs another pr of shirts, so 'tis all well. Much obliged for your Newspaper. Got a bunch of news out of it. "Saw up and saw down" is a good story - Almeda read it to the children.
Mr. Holman told Charles last night that the shingles were all going to you. Expect to send them down this week. C. wishes you to send up by the first opportunity a bbl of flour 1/2 dozen lbs of brown sugar, 1/2 doz lbs of coffee, 1 lb of tea, 2 lbs saleratus. These things are wanted to use immediately as you know. Three weeks is a short time you know & we need, even now, to be using them in preparation.  You are to take your pay out of the shingles on what Hector owes Charles. You will send them by the very first chance will you, and let us know when, if you can so we may get them sooner. Almost out of flour. You certainly will not fail to come home, will you, and  write again first, and let us know how & when. Oh dear! I do wish it was all over. There are times when one wants to be alone - except our folks -Such be funerals and weddings! Come, come all! and have a merry time if may be.  Aff. Lucy.

Milo Apr. 27th 1848
Dear Brother Josie
I have got to go to Mrs. Lee's visiting this P.M. with Mother, but Charles insists that I must write to you to send by tomorrow's mail, before I go, as he is in haste to sow some Oats & Peas, and can't stop. The story is he has been waiting to get his money of Hector to pay his taxes - Last week Mr. Drake (Collector & Constable) threatened to do so, and yesterday morning actually came, with horse and waggon to carry him to Bangor! At first Charles declared he would go, and was stuffy as Drake, since he would not wait till next week, when Charles and Hector both guarantied him the money at that time. But on going to the Village, concluded finally, considering the state of his business here at home, to hire the money, 20.00, but has to pay a dollar a week for it. Severance is going to Bangor next week with shingles for Charles - but if C. could have the money this week instead of next, it would save him a dollar, so he wishes you to send the money - 20, by Sat. mail, if you will, and take the proceeds of shingles next week instead. It was a real time, I assure you, We felt - yes we did - and Albina looked pale as - so she did.
You see the necessities of the case - Dollars don't grow on every bush, and 'tis vexatious to put them in Niles Carver's pocket - Charles will speak to Severance to bring up the things I wrote for by Samuel - A dozen tumblers and a pitcher
I forgot to put down, which must also be hard. If there will be risk in sending them by Severance, you or Ann bring them when you come - In great haste - Lucy -

Milo Plantation Jan. 9th 1849.

Dear Brother Jos.

             This night when John returned from school rec'd your letter together with two others for Samuel & one myself from our Lizzie Doe. One from Walter Brown & in relating to their scaling business, the other from one Boobar, who, according to agreement, wrote to Samue when the Brown & Son's went into the woods. Rec'd another letter from you last Sat. which he did not have time to answer, as he started for the woods ? (Mon.) morn. early. Went part way there once before, week before last, but the team had not gone in. He will probably be absent more than a week this first time. The only thing we know how to answer in your other letter is about the cash of ? I heard Father says it was omitted in the first account. Samuel has scaling to do for Freeland Holmes, & Wm. Mc ?gides what he had engaged when he came from Bangor.  Had nothing from Cushing & Hayford. P.P. Furber and wife started yesterday morning for N.H. to be gone five or six weeks. Mehitable says they d not go very near Lowell. Samuel will tell you when he comes home next week all about it. I do mot understand your allusion to Roman Gen. Pres. Jackson etc. unless it is not to divulge the business of the Firm, which I am in no danger of doing. I have been intending to write you for some days. Have written a long letter to Ann sent in answer to one from her, but because she don't write  - also one to Isaac, today, and will conclude by scribbling a little to you, unless, forsooth, I should incline to say a word to Lissie when I have finished yours. She has told me all about the "mince pie lunch." Want me to send

another! I have been at Mother's and Almeda's almost all the time since we came up till this week. Samuel has been quite uneasy at being so long unemployed. I had'nt think he could ensure it a whole winter. Our family consists of four persons, to wit; John, who goes to school and is, I expect, a very fine scholar - Alfred Holman , a very eccentric youth, as you well know; but a good strong fellow, who does the chores, and waits upon the women - Mehitable & myself, and our husband when he is here!

            Mother seems in good spirits now - was very gratified with the chair. She loves little Charlie dearly- he is a sweet little fellow with red cheeks & bright black eyes - noisy as any boy can be, and fat as butter. Wants axe and some good sticks bigger than he can lift to play with all the time. Laughs out loud most all day long - just beginning to go alone. Charles doats on him too much, I'm afraid. I almost forgot that I am married when I am at home. Lucy and James are good children, but a luttle ? They go to school, and so does Jane. She is a real capable smart girl, and with right management will make a good woman. But alas! That right management! Who is patient! I feel that I am not. I expect to have her next summer & shall do as well as I can. I can but think it will be better for her than to remain where she is. There are many bad influences - taunts of children at school concerning her origin etc. She is bright. Lissie is a dear little thing. Perhaps petted a little too much - That is not

strange - however - on the whole a very good child. Seems to me very strange we don't hear from Ann. Tell Eliab is nice good "Capes" was divided with Almeda. There were three deaths since we came to Milo. Mr. Thompson, old Mr. Dow & Mr. Varney. Mr. Thos. Tash has a son or daughter I misremember which. People say there is the best school at the village there has ever been. One Bartlett, a graduate from Waterville, teaches. Logan, from Atkinson teaches at the corner. Jamie froze his ear, thumb and three fingers one day last week going to school. Not very bad, I believe. Rev. Jones preaches all the time at the Hall. Baptists begun to build a meeting house. Good singing school this winter. Pall cloth finished. Lapels hardly heavy enough- Cord. not so handsome as made bu Machinery, but answers very well. Matters seem to look rather encouraging here. I don't know but some good things may come out of Nazareth even yet! Great Ball at the Hall New Year's eve though! Going to have another Pic Nic the 22nd inst. Sons of Temperance - grand time, I suppose I must go, and also try to get off some toasts. Awful cold weather last week, was'nt it? Suppose if I was at home, Mother and the folks would put in a little here. When are you coming home. Why don't Eli' come said he would pretty soon when I came away. Tell him that letter was very good. Presume another would be ditto if we could get it. Love to Lissie. Please to forward the enclosed soon as convenient. Samuel will write soon as he returns from the woods - not till next week, probably.

                                                                                                                                                                              Aff. sister Lucy.

Lucy Jan y 9 1849.
Milo                                                                                                                5
Maine Jan. 10                                        J.M. Metcalf

                                                                  Bangor
                                                                        Maine

[bottom of page upside down] Please sir, do write us a good "correspondence letter" now and then. Also if you can sometime send by Bucher, or any way any good history of the French Revolution, from the Library or any where, I should be glad, and will send it back whenever you say so.

Milo Jan 22 1849

I rec'd your letters & papers this morning all safe John will send Baker & Wellington things soon as he can find a team to take them will send them to you if Wellington does not pay that note when he is in Bangor, or do something concerning it, I went yo to see it and attach these things be sure and not let them get out of your reach I dd not go to Dover last week, it was so cold I shall be away the next three weeks after that I shall be here one half the time untill spring.

      Our Exhibit shows more loss than I expected, but it does not give me the blues by any means. why should the loss of a few hundred dollars make a man miserable? Unless there is a better prospect another season I think it best to close our business and seek some other investment for our labor. Your reflections upon yourself I will answer some other time. Do you cherish those feelings! Can they not be resisted? Have you even made a determined effort? Or do you not wish to resist them!
                                                                                                                                                S.W. Furber

Much obliged for the History.
Will send it back in season. I certainly know how to feel eccentric! Mines?, I think I usually make beklow the line; Much obliged however for the correction as I shall always be for like favors. I will not trouble you with billets doux again. You must not allow yourself to have the blues. There is no use in it. Be happy. You were never destined to be alone. You must not think so. I don't know of a person

who more decidedly loves and enjoys domestic & social happenings than my brother Josie. 'Kick the blues out of the store. Pound away all such thoughts & feelings. Give 'em a emetic or something else! You were made to be happy & socially happy too. You did not write anything about your new boarding place. How do you like? We had a letter from Ann little more than a week since. You have probably heard from her before now. 
Wish you'd bring up some letter paper when you come - pretty good

Milo Maine Jan. 21st                                                          5

                                Mr. J. M. Metcalf                                 Lucy & Samuel
                                    Bangor                                                Jan 22  1849
                                        Maine

[bottom, upside down] This 22nd Jan. is a "great time" at Milo. Pic Nic, Anniversary of S. of T. Two "Daughters" came up from Bangor Saturday. Form a division here today. Don't know whether the Goat is to be used by them or whether they have got him "a wife!" Poor business, I think. Write to me. Hope Libe will come this week. When are you coming? Won't you try to before we go back in the Spring. Good bye. Aff. sis. Lucy.
23rd Saw Libe at Pic Nic last eve - said you would come Sat. Good bye.
I shall be over to "our house" Are you going this morning to stay all the week. Samuel has just started for the woods.

Hampden May 17th 1849

Brother Joseph

          Lucy wrote you a note a day or two since in regard to your boarding here at Mrs. Crosby's you can board here a week or two and be quite comfortably situated. I cannot at present tell when we shall go to keeping house. I have tho't some of building here but at present feel rather off the hooks about it. I have been trying since I came from Milo to obtain a copy of Ireland's a/c from Dea. McDonald. but have not yet succeeded. I have spoken to Eliab who promised to get it till I am ashamed to mention it; he has seen McDonald once or twice but somehow does not get the a/c I have been to his office quite a number of times but never find him. We had an order come into the Mill about a week ago which will confirm me to the Mill for two or three weeks to come all the time so if our Hermon business must be attended to I do not see but you will have to do it; I suppose there can be another continuance with but little cost and we can manufacture the logs as at present, which Jewett will do by the ? and require but little attention our other business I know but little about sometimes I go to Bangor in the evening but Eliab is always busy at Browns Thurston has paid some money I know not how much The Brandywine was under repairs a time ago do not know her whereabouts at present; have not seen Thurston

for ten days. Fletcher has paid no money nor hauled anything. Eliab says he has not seen him for some time. If your health is so that you could come and stop here ten days or more without any injury, perhaps it would be well for you to come, but I think your health of much more importance than any business of ours at present. Porter was up river when I came from Milo. Hear nothing from Wing or Wingate.  Good Night

                                                                                                             S.W. Furber

Pa Furber is just going to Milo. Has been here but a few moments. If you come down Joseph, be careful of yourself. Lay down and rest at the tavern. In haste

                                                                                                                                                                                                                                    Lucy.

[upside down] S.W. Furber

                      May 17, 1849

June 18th 1849

Brother Joseph

        Eliab rec'd your letter Isaac which I forward with this yours was duly rec'd The Brandywine's papers are all fixed and in the Custom House. Fletcher has not got any money I am to see him this evening at Durens to do something, saw Jewett a few days since, will commence sawing in a few days, shall make some arrangements about the shingles before he hauls them in Irelands' case is continued McDonald thinks he means to make us pay a jury fee Eliab says Mr. Smith wants to pay his note of $100, On the Clark concern I think. Please send the note if you want to pay, give everyone a chance to pay when willing.
                                                                                                                                                                                       S.W. Furber

Hampden July 11th 1849

J.M. Metcalf, Esq.

                                       Dear Sir
                                                        I saw Mr. Jackson of Bangor Monday. he has nothing to do with his brother's business say his brother cannot get pay for lumber sold last Fall says he is coming to Bangor last of this month intending to pay us then I wrote a pretty smart dun to Jackson yesterday and shall follow it with another soon unless that brings the money. Fletcher got no money least I saw him yesterday. he has promised me Pearsons note tomorrow if he does not get Pearsons note, is it best to settle with him and take his note? I think he would pay his note if it were discounted on in the bank. Eliab has paid his notes $4.95. if I have an opportunity to use it for a short time I shall do it: Is it best to write to Isaac that we have his money for him subject to his order. I think favorably of the place - operations shall manage affairs at present for that purpose. I have not seen Jewett for a week or so. when I saw him last he said he could not saw much of our lumber unitll the water rose so that he could roll the hemlock logs off from there the No. R's? are not to be hauled untill ordered.
                     Let Lucy come home as soon as you can spare her for I am lonesome.
                                                                                                                                                                 Yours etc.
                                                                                                                                                                     S.W. Furber

How very warm it is What about the Wing? affair.

S.W. Furber

     July 11 1849
                                                     J.M. Metcalf
                                                             Milo

Hampden July 25th 1847
        This same July 25th, if I recollect aright, is brother Josie's birth day. I did not think of it until I sat down to write. I intended to have sent a letter by yesterday's mail, but did not know that Samuel was going to Bangor in season to send it.
                   I need not tell you that the stage on an hour longer than usual, and we waited an hour & a half, as you learned that from Eliab. I arrived at Bangor at 1/2 past five P.M. with no accident or injury save a terrible jounce in the stage which sent me up to the top of the stage and brought me down with such force as to cause a "neutral tint" upon my arm larger than a dollar which has not yet disappeared. Mr. Cutts apologized when we stopped for driving so violently into a deep rut. Found Samuel waiting for me at the Hatch House. Everything as usual down here, excepting that Samuel has suspended your swinging book case over our bureau in the chamber. It looks quite "kedge" and is very convenient. Much obliged for the use of it!
             I saw Hiram at Kirkland - just spoke with him - he looked quite foppish. A little boy from Katahdin said he worked for his father. I asked him if he swore - he said he did.
             Last sabbath forenoon just as Prof. Smith rose to commence his sermon, one Daniel Stone went into a fit. I could not see his face, but his head shook dreadfully. A great many men in the back part of the Hall went out. - they carried him into Sayward's office below - it was half an hour before he got so they could carry him home. Eliab took him home with our horse. Strange how Libe is always on hand in every scrape! Never had fits

before. I bought me a new bonnet (Coburg) for 2.25. like it much. trimming and all came to about 3.60. Saw Mr. Upham sabbath morning - inquired of Samuel particularly about you.  Ann Thurston introduced me to Mrs. Jewett.  She also was very kind and particular in her inquiries about you. Said she though the Water Cure would be the best thing in the world for you. Invited me to call on her. Would you, without further ceremony?

 I have made what inquiry could about Waterford. This young William went there for deafness. Had received no help for that when he last wrote, but his general health was much improved - felt invigorated and was in fine spirits. They packed him in wet sheets several times a day - said it was very disagreeable at first - took him some time to get accustomed to it. He wrote about a very bad case of spinal complaint perfectly cured. So near as I can learn they have been more successful in their treatment of spinal diseases than anything else.  Yours was occasioned by an injury of the spine, and it seems as though their treatment might be beneficial to you, but I don't know what to advise you, I am sure. I wish if you do conclude to try it, Mother could go too, to be with and take care of you. I feel as if you will get better there at home, if you are careful - as the cool weather come on, you will feel stronger - but perhaps in some other way you might get well quicker. I wish you would write to me often and particularly, just how you get along, and all about everything. I want to see little Charlie dreffully. The little boy that lives with Mr. Cutts, his nephew I believe, broke his leg badly in five or six places last week. A log rolled on it. Pres. Taylor's fast is to be observed in

Bangor - and the Steam Mill is to be shut down. Most all the logs are sawed up, and they can get no more without rain, Samuel says, they will have to stop in three weeks if they get no more. Then if we wanted to we could go to Wisconsin, but we should not fee as if it was pendent to go right through so much Cholera. Mother did not tell me exactly what she wanted to do with that money - did you conclude to get silk for the parasol, or wait till next summer. If you get a cloak next winter, if you can send money soon, I can probably get it some cheaper than to wait till winter. Albina's shoes I will purchase ready to send when an opportunity offers. Guess I must leave a little room for Samuel. Do all write - do write Mother. Sis Lucy.
[left-hand side] Has the boy got a name?
Wednesday noon

                            Brother Joseph
                                                       I suppose you wish to know about things in this section. I am quite busily engaged at the Mill this week am surveying two cargoes of boards one for the W. I. and one for South American. I saw Fletcher Monday night  he has promised to have something for me tonight. Unless he does fix our business in some way very soon I shall be in favor of securing ourselves. have rec'd not ans from Jackson shall write him again in a day or two have got no shingles from Hermon yet. I believe there are but few sawed yet. I think that Eliab has not heard from Clark (Dearborn) yet I hear nothing from any of our debtors. The Brandywine is on her third outward trip had stocked when in last $203, Thurston paid to Snow of $12,50 for us. Paul did not settle I do not like the management very well but can do nothing about it except to grumble.

dinner is waiting                                                                                                                                                                                               S.W.F.

Hampden Aug. 13th 1849.

Dear Friends

        It is washing day after tea. Samuel has not come, and I do not feel like doing any thing else, so I'll put pen to paper for your behoof, though I don't seem to have any thing in particular to say.
    The one great and absorbing topic of conversation here is the "Cholera". I heard so much of it, that for two or three days after I came back I really felt quite alarmed, felt as tough I was as likely to be taken any minutes as not, but feel quite calm now - do not think much about it. There are so many reports one can hardly tell what to believe. There have been eleven deaths in Hampden and Hermon. I have heard of no new cases within a day or two. No one who was sick recovered. Some say it was "ship fever" brought by a sailor. Whatever it was, it was certainly contagious. Some thing it is owing to bad water. Dea. Adams says that forty two years ago that neighborhood about that pond, was almost entirely depopulated by a disease similar to this, denominated then "Cold Plague." For my part I wish I need not think of Cholera again for a month, but I can hardly keep it out of my mind day nor night. Mr. Crosby's people and Samuel persist on eating cucumbers freely notwithstanding. Joseph's Cholera cobs I consider perfectly harmless when eaten moderately. I have always eaten them and do not know that they even hurt me. As for the Cholera, I

think nothing about it except when at the house. I do not believe there has been a case of it in town. there have been a number of sudden deaths in the back part of this town Newburg and Hermon What the disease may be I do not pretend to know some say it was brot by a sailor and is the Ship's Fever or Black Vomit a very fatal disease and contagious others say it is local owing to bad water, and others call it Cholera. It matter not what it is. I feel not the least uneasiness concerning it: Jackson was here a few days since and paid $51.28. which was $5.99 less than the a/c and intst it was all he was willing to pay. said the shingles were put in at a higher price than agreed on. I th'ot  on the whole it was best to settle with him but perhaps I done wrong. I sued Fletcher the 4th inst. have not served the writ. Shall not at present the attachment is on record. if he looks at the records of attachment he will see what has been done otherwise he will not know it Thurston sued him the 21st of July, and trusteed Pearson Fletcher went to Norridgewock last week was to be back today that he could pay $200, cash and a short piece of paper for ballance. if he does I shall stop the suit and pay costs I saw Jewett last week not water enough to get our logs would it not be well to pay up Snow for repairs on Brandywine perhaps we can get a discount by paying all up. Thatcher has pd him $12.50 and I have paid him $20. ballance about $60.

Tuesday 14th - Isaac would not stay here all night - did not go until Friday. I carried him up to Bangor Thursday P.M. He called up to Uncle Natty's with me. I called at Mrs. Thaxter's - she presented me a very nice linen cambric handkerchief - 1.00 or 1.50 I should think.

     It has been very healthy in Bangor until within two or three weeks. Cholera Morbus & dysentery prevails considerably, rather more than usual at this season of the year. Dr. Rich said two or three cases so bad, he should call them Cholera if it was raging there, but as it is, does not. He says no body need fear the Cholera if they would live as he does - cold water, bread and butter and salt beef.
             I got those things and sent them, Mother, because you so much desired, but I have felt sorry ever since. It does not seem right to me. I desire to know if all the shoes fitted. Did Charles see Mr. Cutts when he was at Milo? He has received the letter, but I hear no tidings therefrom. I think of calling on Mrs. Jewett soon. Margaret's foot has not most well. She was marvelously interested in "Margaret Smith's Journal." It rained so sunday, we did not got to meeting. What a long day it was! The Mill will stop in two or three weeks, unless there comes more rain. What "dog days weather" this is! Isaac brought Eliab a book "Life in earnest," which is very good. I have not seen E. since Thursday - said he was very well then. I don't seem to say much, so I guess I'll stop. good bye. 

I desire to hear especially & particularly of your health, also whether you conclude to try W.Cure, and if so when.     Sis Lucy.
[left-hand side] Samuel says he fears you will get nothing of Cutts as present Night crew have left for lack of lumber, and he does not find the boarding very hospitable.

S.W. Furber 
Hampden Oct 2 1849
Wednes. morn. Samuel has gone to Bangor with Col. Mitchell. The logs have not come yet. Mill will not probably start before last of the week. Have heard of no cases of Cholera since last Saturday. Hope there will be no more- six deaths last Thursday.

                                                                             Wednesday noon

Joseph

        Our action vs Ireland is dismissed by consent of parties each paying his cost. we still hold the lumber if Ireland gets a good note for $75, we are to release him in full. Hewett is about beginning to saw the lumber. W.F. Barrows paid. Brandywine one trip $9.01, some talk of trade Dealing at $300, but not much expectation. wrote very short letters, to C. Clark and the Wings. think I will not go out there at present Fletcher by mistake was sued in the District Court writ served two weeks ago. I called to see him yesterday was "not at home" I expect he is considerably excited. he was packing his furniture to move to Noridgewock. If I can catch it on the road I'll show him a trick. ten days after our attachment he deeded to his Mother. What think of the propriety of securing when we did? A thought just passed my mind. Fletcher bot lumber of Pitman on his own up in Pushaw last winter if that is yet in his hands I attach it tomorrow.

Eve I find that Fletcher's logs are holden for stumpage and probably for part

of the purchase money. think it not best do anything in that direction perhaps it will not be best to trouble his furniture as it would create much feeling and we are now safe.

 The Gold Hunter was advertised to sail this morning at eight o'clock, some two or three thousand people were on the wharf to witness her departure and listen to an address which I suppose we must pronounce good. after the address came the U.S. Marshall and put an injunction on something else. I didn't suit upon her for reason of her not having suitable accomodation for her passengers (60 in number). This was done on account of a protest of a part of her passengers, to wet those hired by Government how the matter will be settled I do not know. There is a great deal of lumber now being shipped to San Francisco shipping boards have gone up to $12. per M. I do not think it very probably that the mill will start before the first of next week. Hinman began to paint his house Monday. will move soon as the paint will admit, in the mean time I shall be getting ready to settle down at home.
                                                                                                                                                                              S.W.F.
 Tell Albina I will get her veil and calico this first time I go to Bangor, which will probably be before many days if I am well, as Samuel wants me to help select housin' stuff, before the mill starts. Do not think of anything more to write, only that the biggest lump of fat in the form of a woman took tea here tonight that ever I saw. A Mrs. Holt - I think likely the same one that Mr. Kittredge begun to learn his trade of! Love to all - good night - Aff. daught and sister Lucy.

Saturday Eve. Oct. 13th ( I believe) 1849.

Dear Brother Joseph

            I was at Bangor yesterday, and Eliab gave me your last two letters to him. They made me feel very bad. It seems to me I cannot believe that you are really growing worse. I don't know what to say to you. I cannot bear the idea of your going away, and yet I am afraid it is best. I don't see how you can go. You are not able to endure the journey. It seems to me you will be all worn out before you could get to any water cure establishment.
             I do so wish, if it is best for you to go at all, that you had gone the first of last summer, when you were better able. I dare not say anything to discourage you, for I don't know but it is best. I don't know what to say. Would'nt it be better (no matter what it costs) to get a hydropathic doctor to come here and doctor and take care of you, than for you to try to go away so far? But if you do decide that it is best to go, ought not, must not, Mother go with you and stay as long as you stay. What is money compared with life and health and comfort? I dare not say anything either in favor or against your going, but I should think of it well. I can pray for you, dear brother, and I do constantly, that if it can be, you may be restored to health - and resigned to whatever may be in store for you. I have thought of it a great deal. and am very glad that you are so patient and cheerful as you have always been since you have been lame. It does not seem right, certainly, in such a

case as yours, to sit still and not try any means to get well, and if you feel that the Hydropathic treatment would be most likely to cure you, I suppose you ought to try it.

     Eliab was going to write by Mr. Furber today in hopes the letter would reach you sooner then by monday's mail. He foolishly and wickedly, I told him, exerted himself so much at the fire (which I suppose he wrote you about) that he was sick abed all day Thursday & could not write by Friday's mail as you desired. He brought the last box of goods out if Hagg's store, had to go in twice after it, and fainted as soon as he got out. I think he did quite wrong. I don't know who would have risked his life to go in after him if he had fainted in the store. Strickland block - total loss said to be $40,000. Fifteen thousand insured. Fire was not all out and engines playing last night - burnt Thursday morn.
  Is there anything that I can do for you or furnish you with, Joseph, if you decide to go? If so please let me know. I have lotted so much on having you and Mother come to see us this winter. But never mind, perhaps you will yet. Keep up good courage Josie, and hope for the best. I can not think but that you will get well. We will hope and wait, and try to be willing to have it all just as our Heavenly Father sees best. We know that "He doeth all things well." I must leave a place for Samuel to write some. Write to me too, won't you Joseph, so I may know just what you are going to do. I don't see Live to get his letters very often. I want Mother to write too, and all of you. Love to all. Affectionately, Sister Lucy.

Brother Joseph

  I do not know whether to feel glad or otherwise to learn of your determination to go to a water cure establishment this fall, but hope if you do go that you may receive help from their treatments. What did Doctor Veselhess write you in answer to your letter? When do you think of starting? How are you comeing to Bangor? Mr. Hinman proposes to move next Thursday if we go to house keeping before you start you must come here, perhaps we can take as good care of you as they can at H.U. Brown's. Had you not better put off starting untill week after next, when we shall probably be keeping house then you can stop and get rested, which I think you will need to do. If there is anything that we can do for you will you let us know. I am not so hurried but I find some spare time which I might devote to your benefit, though I can never tell one day how busy I may be the next. Lucy sent a bundle by Father with some things for Albina and Jae thinks she would like to have Jane sent by stage Monday Oct 22 if there is nothing to prevent. I send am order for her passage.

Mr. Millett. I will settle the fare of the bearer with Capt. Cutts                                                                                          S.W. Furber

Thurston's note is in the bearer's Bank for collection. Fletcher I have not seen luckily. I have his signature to settlements, which saved it from the fire Thursday morn. Ireland's concern is fixed I suppose. I take a note vs Alvin Foss of Old Town due May 10th 1850 for 71.79 which I believe to be good and Ireland's note for $3.25. I do not know whether I have made a good bargain nor, it is as it is

                                                                                                                                                                   S.W.F.
   Sabbath morn. Stopped after meeting to Johnny Barker's funeral - he has been away on a journey with his wife - got as far as Unity on his way home and died.
     Cannot stop to write more. I do hope you will think best to wait a few days if you go, and come to our house and get nicely rested before you go farther. Mother ought he not to be well supplied with good warm flannel drawers & undershirts. Is just as convenient about sending Jane - only we should like to know so as to be at Bangor for her at the Katch house. Ought you not at least to come as far as here with Joseph Mother - and farther too!
                                                                                                                                                 Lucy.

[right-hand side] Come right to us and we will do all we can to make you comfortable.
[upside down] Lucy & Samuel

                          Oct 13 1849.

Samuel & Lucy

My dear dear Brother

           Charles has just been here to tell me that you are gone - and gone without my once more seeing you - it seems as if I cannot have it so. And yet, as Mrs. Crosby says, I ought to feel thankful that you are able to go right on without stopping to rest. I am glad and surprised too, that you could come so quick, and without being more fatigues. I am afraid though, that you were more so than Charles thought, and that it was only excitement that kept you up. I will try to feel that it is all right and best for you to go. May our Father in Heaven bless you, dear brother and care for you and sustain you, and return you to us sound and well. I hope it may be so, dear brother, and you must keep up good courage and think you are going to be benefited. I feel as if some of us ought to be there with you all the time, and yet I suppose we could do you no good, only to be company for you. I did hope we should get to keeping house, and you would come and stay a few days with us before you went, but I suppose it is best as you say, not to as it is getting late in the season, and the weather growing colder. If you were going, it was probably best for you to keep right on. I suppose Eliab told you that Mr. Jewett saw Samuel, and insisted on your coming right to his house at Bangor. He appears very kind. I should think him an excellent man. We expected just as much as could be, to move today into the Hinman house, - I got

things all ready, and even baked an over full of good things yesterday, preparatory, but - Mr. Hathorne is very anxious for Samuel to go in there, as he is going to move to Bangor into the Cooper house in about a fortnight - so we e'en concluded to wait and go there - we like the house much better - more convenient, pleasanter situation, and nearer the mill - we have it this winter for the same rent we should pay for the little house - forty dollars a year - and next year pay eighty dollars. I am of course glad on the whole, but am some disappointed  that we cannot move sooner. Pa Crosby has the hypo terribly, and Grandma is very sick, so I know they want us to move. I think I begin to write to you pretty soon after you go away - but I could'nt help talking a little to you, as I could'nt see you, What did you do for comforters etc. I was going to let you have some things. Guess I'll leave this now, and finish some other day. Had letters from Isaac & Cousin Maria last week. I did threaten to go right home with Charles - how lonesome poor Mother will feel.
Oct. 20th Samuel began his letter on the next page, so I'll finish out this one. Grandma has been very sick indeed. It has seemed for a few days as she could not love, but she seems a little more comfortable this morning. Mr. Crosby has the hypo by spells all the fall pretty bad. Eliab seems to feel quite encouraged about you - much pleased that you feel into lady Purley's care. I have often heard her spoken of as a fine woman. I feel very anxious to hear how you are, what they do with you, and how you endure their treatment. I felt very much afraid that the excitement

                See 4th page

Monday eve Oct. 29th

And so Joseph you went off without calling to see us. I suppose you that you were doing right probably you did do right. I have no reason to think otherwise but we so much expected to see you that we felt very much disappointed.

  We expect now to commence housekeeping next week in the Emery house. I think there is but little doubt about that matter now.
    I have not seen Fletcher since I came from Milo he has gone to Noridgewock. Morrison thinks we can get judgment in January. Ireland was here one day this week wanted to fix up our a/c should have done it but Eliab had the note. I have no doubt but that the note is good, it is a great trouble to do business through a third person. The Mayo's I have not seen, shall give them a call soon. Shall probably sell Porter's note to Cushing & Heyford. Think I shall leave Wings note and Clark's a/c with Morrison to be duned some people are afraid of lawyers.

Rec'd a letter from Charles H. Metcalf no news, all well. Business at the Mill quite lively sending shooks to Frankfort Hathorne & Co. have sold their shooks to W. Brown & Son 55 cts at the Mill a very great trade for Hathorne. Frank is at the bottom of it in a speculating fit, it is something of load for Brown $20000, at a very high price. I am doing considerable surveying now, so that I quite profitable to my employers which is I reckon to my advantage, also. Think we shall own the Brandywine some time yet. If it did'nt get wrecked last night! I expect
[left-hand side] Nov. 1st O! how Mr. Crosby has got the horrors this morning.

Thurston's note will be paid at maturity. What shall I do with any money of your which I may have this fall? shall I invest it on demand at six per cent  or on time at a higher rate if opportunity offers?

You will write to us often, will you? Eliab tells us that you stood your journey well, thinks you were better when you got to Waterford than when you left Milo. I hope that such may prove to be the fact and that you appearant improvement a not merely the result of excitement. Write
                                                                                                                                                  S.W.F.

etc. of the journey was all that made Eliab think you were better, but I hope not. I do feel that there is hope that the cold water system will help you. Margaret says there is a very  fine young man there - Williams - son of the former Baptist minister in Hampden, who she hopes you will become acquainted with. He went there for account of deafness, has not yet recieved any benefit. What a terrible storm last night. Seems to me I never knew anything like it before. I fear we shall hear sad tidings from the sea. You will write to us often, dear Joseph? How much we want to know all about you - every thing about your situation - how you feel & what they do for you. I think likely Isaac can leave to go and see you, if he can not get away long enough to come here. I hope he will. Samuel got another Vol. of Kent's Commentaries from the Library for himself, and a Vol. of Shakespeare for me. Shall we continue so to do in your name? How often shall we write to you? As often as you do to us? You will write soon and often, won't you? Your affectionate sister Lucy.

Hampden Nov. 7th 1849

Brother Joseph

            We have just rec'd yours of the 3 we feel somewhat disappointed that you tell nothing not a word about your health. I think you ought to have said something about your own case. I do most certainly hope that your folks will not shut down this fall. Can't they obtain cold water in the winter season? You conclude I infer from your letter that you think if us as keeping house in our own hired Hinman house but not quite so fast if you please, we expect to live in the Emery house when Hathorne moves - he cannot move for want of a wife expects one from Boston next boat but that boat has not yet arrived, it has been expected for one week will probably be in the new few days.
Thurston's note was paid the 3 $366.25, Eliab sold some shingles left in the store cellar $11,55. Fletcher "in status quo" rest of the schooners "hauled up" I bot today of W. Brown & Sons 180 bbls of flour, new Oswego. T. Hadden N.Y. inspector $5,53 in their (an exception to your friend Dole's rule) store. I shall get it insured which will probably cost: 9 cts more, making the whole cost about $1000. I rec'd notice from Co. of Piscataqua  that my my money was at my order. have sent for it. Do you wish for an interest to the amount of money in my hands? on interest on your money. I do not think the prospect very flattering for anything more than a

fair rate of interest, but I prefer it to letting money. Thurston wanted to use his money and give a two months draft. I should liked to have accomodated  him and did intend to before buying the flour. I think he is getting along quite well.

   I believe that my knee is about well. It is very seldom that I feel any lameness. I think the pitch plaster helped it much. Mr. Crosby has the real horrors now, it certainly is a very dreadful disease, this hypo.
Prof. Sheppard preached Sunday PM from the words of Peter, "depart from me for I am a sinful man, O Lord." The character of Peter was his subject and such a sermon, the feeling of the Roman Catholic pretence that Peter was Bishop of Rome for twenty five years was clearly exposed, it is almost certain that he never was at Tome. The Universalists did not escape his attention he shew how very improbable it is that such a doctrine would produce such effects as did Peter's Preaching, such as led the Jailer to cry out, "Sirs what must I do to be saved." Eliab thinks Mr. Webb will be settled over the third Church. Think I shall sing at the Hall after this as Mr. Jewett wishes me to.

Sat. Nov. 10th Your last letter of the 6th inst. was rec'd last night, together with letters from Mother, Pa Furber & Olive. Did'nt we have a good time reading them all? Yes we did.

 You speak highly of Mr. Jewett and family, and with reason, I should judge. I take back all I said about Hannah Moore not being as handsome as I expected. The more I see her the handsomer she grows - truly a fine form - very lithe -

By the way (don't laugh) I've only seen it through her shawl. I should like to become acquainted with them. Since Mr. Barker's death, Miss Moore has been in Mr. McDonald's class, but now when I want to stay to S. School more than ever, I cannot, as the time for meeting is changed and we have not time to get our dinner & stop to S.S. They say things go on more lively since she has been in the class. How we do like Prof. Shepherd! and how he does preach - especially sometimes! Next Sabbath on Peter's fall & recovery. I am very anxious to hear it, but fear it will rain, as it does today. I wish Mr. Crosby could go to Water Cure. He is a wretched man as he is nowadays. I should hardly be surprised if he should commit suicide some day, though people say he has not courage to do it. I don't know how many times he has said he was in hopes the Cholera would have carried him off. One trouble is, he has always been in the habit of eating luncheons at all times and seasons - drinking tea & coffee etc. You do not say what is the matter with your friend Dole - nor whether he has received benefit. I am very sorry you are to lose such a good society. I know it is difficult for you to find one whose society you really enjoy, as you seem to his. With regard to my own health, I call it very good now. I do not doubt that I have some spinal disease about me very slight however- but if I have plenty of exercise & not too much sedentary employment, presume it will not grow upon me, in which case I shall call myself well. I don't see why you don't writ something about yourself - what we most want to know, you do not even mention.

Do you feel as well as before you left home? Is the treatment agreeable or otherwise? But I won't ask questions, lest you answer them as the renowned Charles Lowell of Elloworth had his answered! Please to give more particulars with regard to your own case in your next.

  I wish we were - as you seemed to suppose in your first letter - moved and settled  - for my consolation , Mrs. H. has at last returned from Boston, and we expect they will move first of the week when we shall immediately step into their present place. It seems to me twelve patients for such an establishment is a very small number. How much are your expenses per week? Mrs. Crosby wishes to know. Why do you speak so discouragingly of your own case, when you say Dr Deane is improving? Is not his a much worse case than yours? Don't think of anything more to say now & guess I'll wait a while.

Monday noon

                     Hathorne begins to get ready to move this day. will probably get moved in all this week. Did not attend meeting yesterday therefore did not hear Prof. Sheppard.

[upside down] Samuel & Lucy
Nov. 7 1849

Hampden Dec. 12th 1849

Brother Joph,

                I think I owe you a letter which has been over due for some time.I have no excuse plead guilty and throw myself upon the mercy of the Court. I feel somewhat disappointed by the report in relation your health in Eliab's last letter. I cannot believe yet but that you may receive help from some source. Flour, I bought Nov. 7th 180 bbls $5.50. 2 cts truckage,  1 ct hoisting, 1 ct per month storage 1.2 per cent insurance for 9 months $1.00 for policy, $5, 56 1/3 , and storage, I think it will sell for $6,00 without commission.
   Brandywine has paid $54,34. will probably pay $12.00 from her present freight say $66.00 cost $317. 50, balance $251,50 without any interest a/c. I presume she is worth that sum. shall let Capt. Dealing have her wintered where he thinks best probably at Frakfurt. I hear nothing from Fletcher. Barton of Bradford is cold, all mortgaged up to Brown. Porter, exchanged his note for Cushing & Hayford's payable first of Jan. Lot of old shingles rec'd of Eliab $11,30 Sent T.H. Swazey $7.38. balance and int. Have not seen any of our other Drs. shall visit them soon. Our Mill shut down the 3 ' I have not engaged any scaling shall not probably do much this winter. Eliab bot for me yesterday 1/16 of the H. Crosby about $210. Walter Brown & his son Frank will yet make money out of their shook trade with Hathorne  the Son has gone to Cuba for his health and to please his friends.

Elian I suppose stays with Mr. Brown another year $400. Mr. Webb preached at the Hall last sabbath he certainly preached very well. I think the Third Parish will settle him another year. Mr. Jewett is in Bangor this winter have not seen enough of him to judge of your opinion. I see nothing to lead me to dispute with you and I think Eliab is of the same opinion of yourself certainly as to one member of the family. There is a new block of six wooden stores nearly completed where Strickland's block was burnt.  Jane is here on the tiptoes feel as well as she can and live is a very good girl and a big help to Lucy. John is boarding with us attending the Hampden Academy  have killed our winter stock of hens (35) and packed them in snow.

        There will be a large number of teams in the woods this winter. hay is now worth $12 in Milo it is tho't that it will be much higher towards spring. W.B&S. are supplying some they charge now for flour $6.95 which could be bought such flour as theirs for $5,50. It is not surprising that they never yet supplied a man but that came out in their debt. Their high prices and Fryd - y are enough to ruin any man. What should you think of my building there on farm small tenaments near the Mill to rent to Irish families they would cost probably from $75 to 100, each and rent for $20, per year and the rents safe. I am inclined to believe that they would be good property.
                                                                                                                                                                                                     S.W.F.

I suppose dear brother Josie has been looking for a letter some time. I know we ought to have written before, but we have both been very much engaged, as you may suppose moving & arranging things which have been scattered in so

many places so long, besides "shutting down" and discharging men. We moved about three weeks since. I have worked pretty hard, necessarily, took cold I suppose, & suffered for a few days from lame shoulder & side (rheumatism) but 'tis better now. Our home is very convenient in every part & comfortable, we have it furnished to our mind, and feel more settled than before since we were married. Pretty carpet, real pretty french sofa, $32. centre table etc. in sitting room, carpet, bureau, sink etc. in best chamber, chamber for John, another for Jane, large, convenient bed, room below for ourself - stair carpet, & oil cloth to. on front entry. dining room with cook stove in it this winter, nice convenient kitchen beyond - a great abundance of clothes presses, closets & drawers all over the house.  Wish you could pop in now & then, like last summer, to have good times with us, as then. Mrs. Finnegan helped me pick & dress 30 chickens last week - the fattest creatures I ever saw - packed them in snow - Samuel got some nice Buckwheat flour, with syrup prepared on purpose, for fritters - very nice. Jane is happy as a lark & a capital good girl - She got her dress, cloak, bonnet, aprons etc. I tell Sam'l that they'll spoil her - she is bright. She wants dreffully to see a rat. Said today she did wish she could find a whole nest of young ones, wish the old one on - she would wring their necks & set the cat on." Guess I wanted to laugh. She is certainly a very capable child - owing to Mother's faithful training. Her right shoulder blade protrudes. I don't know the meaning of it. I expect Mother will come soon, & I so want to have her. Eliab was here Thanksgiving day - and came down last Sat. night

staid till Mond. morning. Boil on his leg - not so bad as before- ought to go to water cure! I can't leave my family to go, you know - ought to have gone last summer  if at all - guess I don't need it - wrote to Ann this week - ought to write Isaac tonight, and 'tis nine o'clock - shoulder been lame & could'nt write - good deal to do for Jane besides all my other work. I don't know what to say one word about your remaining there or coming home. I cannot endure to think that nothing will help you, and it certainly seems as if your present treatment would be as likely to as any. Miss Roxanna Treat (Joseph's sister) who visited Margaret Crosby last week, does aver that Mary Tower is engaged to one Hunting, who is going out as a Missionary. I rec'd a letter from Mary recently - she is attending school at Woburn Mass. Her roommate, Miss Lord, it is said is engaged to a brother of Mary's betrothed. Mr. Crosby continues hypo bad - Margaret been sick. Don't think of anything more now - In hurry - half sick and sleepy. I hope Dr. P. was so naughty as to say you was'nt getting any better, to back up the establishment, rather than because it is so. Do write particularly all about yourself. good night brother.

                                                                                                                                                                                                            Sis Lucy.

I am learning Jane to write.
[upside down] Samuel & Lucy

                      Dec. 12, 1849

Hampden April 13th 1850

I.S. Metcalf Esq.

                            Dear Sir
              I left with your agent E.W. Metcalf yesterday the amount due on Metcalf & Furber one hundred dollars and fifty five cents $100.55. Will you please to send me the note. Got up Steam at the Mill to day. I do not work for Hathorne. I have the promise of an appointment to survey here and will probably have my limits extended indefinately The ice departed yesterday noon full of days and holes.                                                          
                                                                                                                                          S.W.F.

J.M. Metcalf

                               Do you want any money?

How much? and when? Have obliged? Capt. Paul in the absence of Arnold Dealing. he took it very ungraciously. Capt, Jellison went to Frankfort yesterday to bring up the Brndn sails her for 1/2 and $10. per month. we expect to try to sell her next week if we can for all we can get. The Senator is in the Surgeon's are at Brewer. 

  Send your obligations for that beautiful book mark & I will deliver them to Miss Moore. Margaret visited me yesterday. Lute

I went to Hermon this week, rec'd to day of $15. of Mayo and a promise for the balance due next week. closed the Oliver Clark concern yesterday. Settled with S.F. Barton got a note payable when he demands it"
Further your deponent is silent

  Mehitable is going to help me manufacture  rug, the long talked of. - I want a black border, can color some, but I fear not enough - if there is any old black flannel or other thin suitable material - or for that matter, any other color, & I can make it black - which is not wanted in those regions, and you can send it by Isaac, or otherwise in the course of two or three weeks, it would do me (good. Lucy.)

Vy don't ye write?
