[upside down] Hampden

                            1850

Hampden Apr. 16th 1850.

Albina & Lissie come in to the docket today. Sam'l is appointed to survey at the Mill, and Walter Brown says he "shall have him" survey up there, so I suppose he will. My fingers are cold - in the dining room devoid of fire. I did not go to sewing circle yester. but will thank Miss Moore vigorously when I do go. She gave the mark to me requesting me to send it. Libe had nothing to do with it. My teeth were all finished Monday - eight cavities - mostly very large filled, two teeth & roots extracted, tartar removed, for $8.25 - not bad charge, was it? Sam'l is going to have his done next week. Lissie spent the afternoon & night here last Wednesday. Pa Crosby last evening. Mr. Mason's health very poor - heart disease & scrofula

J.M. Metcalf
                           I send you Hulls Laurie $1.50. Physical Theory of a future life $.75. There were at last advices nine barrells of flour unsold at Milo. I will send an exposition of the affair so soon as I rec the balance of sales from Milo which I expect in a few days. I am spending some time every day at Brewer looking after the Senator. think it better to know what is done than to beat down on settlement.
  The Brandywine Capt. Jelevson is somewhere on her passage from Frankfort to Bangor. it is somewhat provoking that she is a week getting from Frankfort when others have gone out bonded. Did not advise Cutts to break his contract.

July 1846 
                                                                                                               after School in school house
                                                                                                                                          La Grange July 9th /46

Friend "Tip"

                            Mr. and Mrs. Kenney contemplate journeying to Milo tomorrow with a load of wool, so I'll improve the opportunity though I have only a few moments before I must go to tea. About this time I feel like talking with you a little, for I suppose that you of all other can best sympathize with me; if indeed I deserve sympathy after having left my quiet and happy home & entered voluntarily on this scene of vexation. I had made up my mind to spend the rest of the Summer at home, but I d not deny that the "Almighty dollar" (or "filthy lucre" as some would have it) possesses some influence over me as well as other people. I suppose I, as most others, teach for the pay; and one thing I am sure of, we school - ma'ams earn all we get!  Well to proceed to business. Here I am in La Grange, snugly ensconced at one Mr. Kenney's, who, I believe, is an acquaintance of your father's from 'Old Hampshire State.' As good luck would have it, I went not to Mr. Trott's board. I believe friend Libbey thought it not good that I should live on beans this summer, or be lived upon by B. b's. Do you understand? eh?
            Some people conclude that you did not recieve the best of treatment last Summer, but Mr. Libbey said you kept your own counsel. I told hm I should have my case in his hands, but if he did'nt provide a good boarding place, I should forthwith rebel, and go straight home. H says he'll see me well used; so I feel quit at ease on that!
                                                                                                                                                                                                (see third page, mistake)

on the bank near a beautiful spring on Charles' upper lot, where were twenty head of cattle struck with wonderment at our operations, and strongly inclined to dispute our right to invade their territories.

               My school is not the worst in the world by any means, but I think it the most wearisome one I ever had charge of.
      Have about 40 scholars, the oldest only 13 years old. Such an array of little ones I never before saw together. Sixteen Abecidarians! H. Tolman kept here three weeks before she was turned away, so I shall probably have no more than eight weeks or thereabouts to keep. We seldom find ourselves so badly situated that there are no pleasant things to counterbalance the disagreeables - and I usually find it the happiest way to "look on the bright side," enjoy what there is to be enjoyed, & as much as possible forget the rest. Contentment is in the state of our mind, not in our condition. I am too selfish for a school -teacher. The school-ma'am is expected to take an interest in every thing pertaining to everybody's "little dears," be they never so ugly or disagreeable.
 She must hear with patience, & interest if possible al the long yarns which garrulous old women are pleased to spin for her, nod assent to this, and "shake the negative" to that, when her wearied spirit would fain wander away to seek repose in a more congenial atmosphere. As I said before I love myself & mine too much to bestow so much care and thought on strangers. Yet I ought to think some of doing good, and hope I do. If you have patience to read this through, you are a wonderful child.I did'nt know 'twas in my power to make such an awful looking letter; but I beg you'll excuse it. Written in excessive haste, very warm, hand trembles. Do write to me often won't you? Makes me feel better for  week to have a letter when from home! Love to all. Good bye 
                                                                                        Lucy.

score at present. Mr. Kenney is "stright as H." as the saying is. Mrs. K. has a pretty eye, - don't you think so? They have seven, pretty, red-lipped children. Little Johnny that had fits is a beautiful boy, except his eyes. I never knew there could be so much beauty in a child's countenance apart from forehead & eyes.

             What a pity he is so injured! His mother seems to love him more than any of the others. I conclude these folks are pretty clever. I staid at Mr. Libbey's the first night. Mrs. L. is in very truth a notable great good natured sociable soul, isn't she? They say "Mehitable is a real nice girl - yes Mehitable is the first rate of a girl, but she's drefful bashful." However that does not lessen her any in my esteem. These people want to see you, and I am sure I do, so if you please some of these long days you may get one of your good brothers to harness old Dobbin into the vehicle, then you may jump in & team yourself down here, stay as long as you please & then wend your way home again. The ride would do you good & the visit would do me more good than I can tell you. Why won't you? I had no thought of leaving Milo in such haste when I last saw you. Mr. Libbey came after me Mond. morn. and found me at (not in) the wash tub. Mother had just returned from Exeter, and I could hardly make up my mind to come at any rate, but he over persuaded me. By the way let me tell you what a fine time I had while Mother was gone. Sat. P.M. after being alone till I wanted to see somebody, Mr. Greenlead came & invited me to a boat ride and Pic Nic. There were fifteen of us children included. We went about three miles up the river & stopped in an old house when the chambers are on the ground floor. Then we came back about a mile & took tea 
         {second page

The loquacity of Mrs. Tolman and her two interesting daughters almost made me homesick before I got here but I find matters better than I expected. There are some redeeming qualities about this place. Will you not write to me, often, very often?   L.
Miss M. W. Furber

          Milo Plantation

Aug. 46 
                                                                                           La Grange Aug. 4th / 46.

L.H. Metcalf to Olive & Mehitable Furber greeting.
I conclude from my feelings 'tis about time for me to direct another "missile" at you; so prepare yourselves to recieve it manfully & return the blow.

              Eliab and I had a fine ride down here. It did'nt look quite so much like home here as the place I had left did, but it answers for a temporary home. I found a score or less of my family at Mr. Kenney's waiting and wondering. My school since haying commenced is not quite as large as before. Not more than thirty-five or so usually. I rec'd letters last mail from Albina & Isaac. Why not from you too? Isaac's letter, by some queer mistake was sent unsealed! Don't know who read it. Papers from Joseph also; contained not much interesting except three pieces of poetry. "Mother's smile" "Words are things" and "large (not great) women". From the latter I will extract.
"If little ones our sense please

And add to life one pleasure, 
A larger one will joys increase
And multiply our treasure.
The last best gift to man from heaven
Was woman - love possessing- 
'Twere weakness then - 'twere folly even-
'To accept of half a blessing,"   What think

you of the Author's logic? I admire to see a large woman now and then for variety's sake, but should not like them all so.

 Well Mehitable, has your Wisconsin fever "turned" yet? And has Olive disposed of the 'old bonnets' to her mind? Tell her by no means to destroy any of them. They'll ll come in play in the course of time. When you all get off there to "Furber land" I venture to say you'll find use for them!
  Olive, I'm whispering. Nobody'll hear me. How does Mr. Lyford like Wisconsin? "As I look forward into futurity" I can see Mr. and Mrs. James Lyford - seated on a "great high stool," shall I say, with sparkling eyes & happy hearts, enjoying a felicitous "tete a tete." - or - on a low bench in the chimney corner of a long hut, with rueful faces and still more rueful feeling their heads resting on their hands, consoling with each other in sad and melancholy tones, and bemoaning the "Wisconsin fever" of " by gone years", and the "Ague fever" of later times? Ah! that's the picture.
          As for Mehitable, she goes out there a blooming blushing maiden of some eighteen summers, fit prey for some of Sarah's "open mouthed old bachelors and amorous widowers". Sake alive! They will "devour somebody" with a will, when they get her. Well seriously I don't fell in a mood for joking - not at all. I can't think of your emigrating , and cannot yet believe that you will. "Milo Plantation" is too pretty a place to be deserted in that way. I predict that if you do forsake the

"home of your fathers" you will all repent. I know how you must long to see your brothers. I have often thought of and felt for you, though I know I cannot fully enter into your feelings. As you say, I have never been separated from " so many, so far, so long." It is most true that

                                                                "There are sorrows,
                                                                  When, of necessity, the soul must be
                                                                  Its own support."

"Who can penetrate into the secret recesses of the heart? who save He that made it, may know its tumultuous throbbings, or delve its hidden depths of affection, passion, sorrow and joy?" When you want to say something & can't, its just as well to let somebody else say it for you, is/nt it? 
Application, Extracts above.
Aug. 5th Don't you wish you could see "our Oats" down here, all round the house & up to "tother place"? Mr. Kenney sowed 76 bushels this year. My beautiful field of clover is gone! 

                                                                        "The clover scented heath"
                                             Which the scythe must sweep (has swept) so soon."
 What fine evenings now-adays. If 'tis being "sentimental" to love the moonlight, I must plead guilty to the crime. I have "stern reality" all day. Why should'nt I indulge in "moonlight fancies", now and then at night? Do you have any blueberries? Willaim Banton sent Mrs. K. a few one day. I want some more. Well friends, between you now, don't you owe me a letter? I dare not say much 'cause Mehitable is so 'fraid of my tongue, but I should esteem it a great favor if you would both write to me any time & all times. Affectionately
                                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Lucy-H.

I have has to punish only one scholar yet, and I assure you I keep them in very good subjection. I think a mild, decided government, especially for small scholars decidedly preferable to a harsh hasty one. I am convinced that singing is a very great help to the government of a school, or at least to the order & good feeling, which in a measure prevents the necessity of government. The thought of my "teaching music" may excite a smile, but, nevertheless - I may use my one talent or even half of one, if I can do good yet.

[across address] Refused
[right-hand side] Sunday is the most trying day to me. People go visiting without distinction of age, sex or condition. Quiet is out of the question. Mr. Pronty has a meeting every Sabbath. Few attend. No singing usually. I take it there are some good farmers here, but not very enlightened as a general thing. What think you of this? "The Owl is a monk that chants midnight mass in the great temple of Nature."
[bottom of page, upside down] Mehitable, I am informed that Miss Laura Ann Foster would be "very pleased" to see you. Did Phebe go to school to you? Has been to me till this week, is sick now. I think it is Consumption. Catharine Pronty seems a pretty good girl, though I have not much acquaintance with her. M.A. Libby beats all the rest. O, dear! Patience is a monument! Write me a good long letter next mail, won't you?

Hampden May 2nd 1849.

My Dear, dear Mother, Brother Joseph, and all the folks

                I have made my toilet, eaten Breakfast, put my room in order, and now I suppose the next thing it to begin a letter to send home. We got to 'Kirkland Hotel' about noon yesterday, where we took dinner and stopped an hour and a half. Arrived at Mr. Crosby's about five o'clock. Great old fashioned flat - roofed white house- large family, big farm, I guess. Very good sort of people, member of the church, remarkably sociable. Mr. Crosby's Mother, a very feeble old lady lives with them. We have the large Parlor chamber, where I now am sitting by a comfortable fire all alone to myself. Wish you and Jos. were here with me just now. Sitting in the sun by the window is the sweet little Primrose with eleven beautiful blossoms, (much larger than last year) besides buds too numerous to mention. By its side the tall Cactus, with some thirty buds, some of which are nearly blown. It is truly a beautiful thing. Very much obliged to you Joseph. I don't feel very bright this morning. Was pretty tired last night. The road was not muddy scarcely at all, but very rough, full of holes. I advise Joseph not to come down unless absolutely necessary, until we go to keeping house, as by that time the roads will probably be better, so it will not tire him so much.
     May 7th Thought when I commenced this I should finish and send it last week, but here it is yet. The splendid Cactus has two blossoms wide open. I wish you could see it Mother. The sweet little Primrose has eighteen bright beautiful blossoms

'Tis a darling thing because it blossoms every month in the year. Our sitting room chamber is large and very pleasant. Two front windows command a fine view of the river. Can hardly look out without seeing one or more vessels, & now and then a Steamboat. Last week I wrote to Cousin Marie and nearly finished the long talked of Mourning piece. Guess it will look considerably pretty. Also did sundry matters of sewing and mending. We went to Bangor (Central church) to meeting yesterday. Heard Prof. Shepherd all day - forenoon subject self denial, afternoon Pilate's condemnation of Christ. One cannot look away from him, nor think of anything else when he is preaching. It must stretch, enlarge the mind and heart more to hear such a man, than Mr. Sewall and the like. One must feel - cannot get away from it when he talks. It is indeed a privelige to attend a good meeting which some people know nothing about. It is a very little farther from where we shall live, to Bangor than to Hampden, but not so many hills, and I think we shall be amply repaid for our trouble. But Joseph, they don't sing well. Not half so good singing as they have at Milo sometimes. What shall be done about it? What a darling day it is! I shall go to Bangor this week if I am well and attend to my business in the millinery line. I want to see you all, more than I did last fall I really believe! Mother, you will write to me. Don't think Joseph an do it all. I can't do without letters from you, too. I know Jos. will write, and make Bina write, and Charles too. How glad I should be to get one letter from Charles. I want to see Charlie I do. Love to Meda & children. Good bye................................Lucy.

Brother Joseph

   I have not yet been to Hermon think I shall go this week. saw Jewett Saturday says there is no water in the steam he starts his Mill in a few days, wants to saw own logs will saw shingles for $1.75 on one half the Extra's & No. 1 and all the 2's. I think it best to trade with him, what will be the preparation Ex. & 1 if we saw all the logs into shingles!
         Mayo had a/c of $15, on his note. wants to take it up please forward. In what way is he holden for Goodspede? have not seen Thurston Wood do ? not have No. 10 no tenant yet; Uncertain of when we shall go to keeping house, shall not probably know anything definite for two weeks

Please write and tell how your health comes on.
I am busy shall depend on you in a measure to remind me of what is my duty,
S.W. Furber

Bangor                                                                                        Hampden Oct. 11- 1849.

Dear Mother & all

                   Oct. 11. 1849
                                  Pa Furber came this morning & is going home something. I could not tell where to put on the buttons, so if you will please to sew on her pantalettes I will fix them afterwards. I send also old Chemise of Lucy's which I fixed last spring. Guess though I'll only send one of each, as she is coming so soon, s'twill make a bigger bundles. The only rails I could find were 1.25 and ,75, so I got the latter, and two yds of ninepenny calico. Hamilton print warranted not to fade. Suppose it will make Charley two aprons, won't it. Shawl I suppose Jane will want to wear down. We expect now to move last of next week. I believe I left my famous pattern shirt on the shelf in the dark closet where I put my things. Should be almost undone without it, and cannot find it here - please to send with Jane if you find it. Also if you please lend me the loan of Montgomery's poems, for the sake of letting Margaret read "Wanderer of Switzerland." There is every prospect of our going to housekeeping now, but I have hardly dared to think much about it. There are so many changes - we know not what a day may bring forth. If we do get into a nice little home of our own, I shall depend very much upon having all of you come and see us.

Mother, you will not so much as think that you cannot. Joseph, you will of course come and stay a long time, if you are well enough, and Mother with you. Charles & Albina and dear little Charley - I shall feel hurt if they do not. I know they can, if they only think so, and it will do them all good. I do want to see  line is partly missing as page is cut out real hug and kiss for me. "Gold  ditto Emigrant Ship lost in the gale last  ditto harbor -  a hundred lives lost. Have

heard of no cases of Cholera for some days. I have written letters to Anne and Isaac - ten pages each - since I came back, including what Samuel wrote. Father brought us some taters, butter, cheese, apples for housekeeping! How it has rained today. I have wondered and wondered why none of you have written, when I expected a letter so soon. How I want to hear from Almeda & sprained foot, and how you all do and feel. Dear Joseph, are you not well enough to write a little to me, often - and won't you take it upon yourself to plead with Mother to write. How few letters I have had from any of you this summer! I am one of the family yet, am I not?

              I suppose I should have told you before that the mill staid started last Tues. afternoon. Samuel has been, I cannot tell you how busy since. I suppose, Joseph you have seen the Obituary notice of John D. Filby - Dr. McRuen's student, who died of Cholera. The same one I suppose, who was at Foxcroft when we were & entered College at the same time with Isaac. Mr. Crosby has got the regular groaning and taking on hypo - not so bad as he is sometimes though. It is very disturbing certainly to hear and see him- what it must be to endure it I know not. While I think of it, let me ask you, if you find a Citizen having the Poetry, "Jesus of Nazareth passeth by," to save it for me - I set much by it.
             Next morning. Father is just going, I cannot tell yet when we shall move exactly & will therefore write again - in great haste - good bye.
                                                                                                                                                                                                                      Lucy.

"? Jos. Newton"

"My dear Eliza, a long time

I've wished to write to you a line,   
And now, as I've found out a way,
Nothing shall hinder or delay.
The subject upon which I write
To you, I fancy, won't be trite:-
Perhaps 'tis what you least expect-
Therefore I wish you to reflect
And ponder well, ere you dictate
To me an answer, or relate
That you have made a firm decree
For, or against, respecting me;
For know, you are the Arbitress
Of my mis'ry or happiness.
I've always loved you tenderly,
Since we met accidentally
In the brick store on Chestnut Street, 
For there is where we first did meet.
Since then, I've pondered much theron,
Deliberated, likewise, long,
And now make known my urgent suit,
Hoping, ere long, to learn the fruit
Of your researches in this case,
And whether I must e'en erase
Those tender feelings of my heart,
Which ever yet have been your part.
Hoping, dear E. that this may not
Be my unhappy, wretched lot,
I ever will as now remain,
Very sincerely yours, Amen."
This letter read, and pondered well,
Lizzy was much at loss to tell
What course it would be best to take,
Also what answer she should make.

He's "popped the question" plump & fain,
With great propriety and care,
And now he can't to save her life,
Tell whether she will be his wife.

THIS PAGE POSSIBLY FOLLOWS LUCY LETTERS PART 2 OCT 15, 1855

satisfied with his whole course. Capt. Pendleton had two apoplectic fits about three weeks since - was thought to be almost well, walking about the house etc. when he had another & it is now considered very doubtful whether he will recover. Drs. Rich & Snell, two real old fashioned betty & attend him - will not have Dr. McRuen. Eliab says they feed him on Calomel & Croton Oil. Our people think if he does not get well, he will not die of apoplexy but of medicine. Eliab has been with him a good deal. You know Dr. Rich won't allow a bit of cold water about a patient. If he should be taken away, it might seriously affect business matters all around. I was very glad to hear of Isaac's safe arrival at Dunbarton. I should think he would begin to feel uneasy about business Rufus Crosby came home from Kansas

the first of winter, leaving Wm. there - he is going back in about two weeks. I wonder they would stay there now. Yet if Pres. Peirce would let them alone, I should say the more such the better - but what can the free state settlers do if he is going to put the whole authority of the government against them? O, the letters from Washington in the Independent are so good nowadays. I am afraid you don't see them. I have been reading the "South side View" - could hardly have patience to go through it. If one did not know better, they must think Mr. Adams a fool - at any rate, he was fooled. If they are not lost &'tis not too much trouble, I wish you would gather up the story of Mrs. Rose & send to Nettie - she wants to know about it. Walter Riller is getting along nicely - he was no small trial to Almeda to have them there this winter, without

taking into the account his sickness. Sally, with her two babies, thinks she helps ever so much. While she cannot do a thing unless somebody takes care of the children, which is harder than any other work. Almeda & Lizzie could have done the easier without than with them & served so much confusion & noise, besides being so much better for Lizzie.
28 - So far last night - Sam'l sent away this morning dressed for meeting (prayer for colleges) but soon came home, to prepare to go to Searsport again, having received telegraphic notice to be there immediately. He has been there about three weeks in all already & has got one new vessel to load. O, this lumber - shan't we be glad when it is all disposed of. Mary has left Maria because they did not let her do the cooking, though I think one reason was that her friends feared heretical influence - they are glad to be alone - will do without help for a few weeks. I just put out the washing & ironing. Mallie has written you so lately that I need not say much about them. They - especially Hattie and Eliab - are perfectly bound up in the baby. It is a smart little baby, but not so good looking as Gertie was, I think. Do please write often & oftener. Tell Anna that her request about an image for Libby popped into my head all at once the other day; I am very

left-hand side Lucy Feb. 21

My dear Lucy

    After so long a time of letter silence between us I have actually, upon this Sabbath day attempted an opening of our former, to me, interesting and profitable correspondence. Nearly six months have elapsed since we have written each other; but Lucy I have all the while felt that it was a duty and privilege, for the neglect of which I was suffering the loss of much enjoyment: and it that were the only misstep of which I had been guilty I should be spared, a deal of remorse and mortification which I now suffer. I have very willingly departed from the straight and narrow path I was down whose ways are ways of pleasantry and all whose paths are peace. I doubt not Lucy that you have wept in secret places over

[left-hand side][Naomi
[left-hand side upside down]Miss Lucy H. Metcalf

                                                          Present

very fully and applied many a fervent prayer that my backslidings might be healed.

 God has in mercy been pleased to make me in same measure sensible of my wanderings and incline my heart to turn to Him with penitence and faith in the promise that He will turn unto me.
Oh Lucy! my heart is desperate full of every abomination and all uncleaness and I am led almost to believe at times that I have never known a saving change. I fear I have been trusting to some suffused righteousness of my own instead of looking entirely to Christ for salvation.
 When I consider the covenant that I have made with God, that henceforth denying all ungodliness and every worldly lust I will live soberly righteously and godly in the world, seeking the interest of Christ's kingdom the purity of his church and the welfare of souls and see how widely the covenant and my deportment differ I am alarmed and made to exclaim can there be pardon for such a sinner.
   The sermon last Sabbath it ? was much of it most applicable to me. I felt it high time for me to ? to watchfulness and strengthen things that remain lest my candlestick be entirely removed and I left to grope my way through life without one cheering smile from my Saviour or any of the comforting influences of his spirit.
    God in his Providence has spoken to me loudly and affectingly, admonishing me of the shortness of time, saying what thou doest do quickly.
    My prayer is that I may be enabled by his grace to give diligent heed to the warning and file up the measure of my days with usefulness. - 
    Please excuse the form of this letter- I doubled it in this to take advantage of the lines. This is intended for no eye but yours. affectionately Naomi.

Milo April 14 ' 43

My dear Lucy

                       You are a nice good girl to write me a letter of love and lay me under obligation to write you; for without this feeling of obligation, as you know, I am apt to allow my disinclination to write to prevail over my inclination to recieve letters. - 'Tis now Sabbath day, we have no meeting and I am sitting line in the parlor so dosy that I cannot read without going to sleep and don't you think I had better write to you than to do that?

O how sweetly the dear birds are singing praise to their Mother for the return of Spring and if I were not so stupid and senseless I would "join in a song of sweet accord." I suppose you have the privilege of attending church and hearing Mr. Parker preach today; and probably you attend

the Bible Class also. Our Class has not met since the Sabbath you was with us and for my part I think it useless for us to try to maintain a Class with those question books without a teacher. The questions were too doctrined and difficult for us to pass over profitably without instructions from one that can study and enlarge upon them. Mrs. Foss and I are sorry we have got these books and I think I shall send mine back.

                        Angella is at Charleston at school. She is deeply afflicted by Francis' death, is very low spirited and enjoys nothing. Her mother is very sorry she did not go to Foxcroft instead of Charleston.
  We have had a series of Miller meetings here & they closed last Sabbath. I suppose it was a feast of fat things for Mr. Searles. I attended two evenings and Sabbath forenoon and was neither displeased nor converted but for aught I know am just as far from expecting to see the close of time as I ever was. "Millerism," I confess is something in regard to which I hardly know how to feel.

I saw your little sorry? a few days ago - he is as ? as ever and talks quite intelligibly. "By the way" Mrs.

Kimball is not in a plight to go out without wearing a cloak. Mr. Sewall has concluded to preach to us untill the Missionary meeting in June.

       If you should come across a Hymn Book with Aaron S. Hill's name in it and some verses written by L.H. M. you may claim for your friend Naomi S. Hill. I left it in the Baptist Meeting House I suppose. If you are acquainted with any member of the Baptist Society so that you can without any trouble make an inquiry you would oblige me not a little:   
  Send me a paper next week. There is a upsurge? covered by a seal of religion at Bucksport and report says that our cousin Jane Sparhawk is a subject, though I do not feel as sure as I want to that such is the fact. 
 You may give my love to Mr. Parker and accept as much as you want for yourself.
                                                                                                                                    Your affectionate sister
                                                                                                                                           Naomi

Milo Me
Apr 18                                                                          6                      Naomi S. Hill

                        Miss Lucy H. Metcalf                                                   April 14th 1843.
                       Care of Rev. Mr. Parker
                         Foxcroft
                                 Me

Twilight

Twilight sweet hour of peace,
Now art thou stealing on;
Cease from thy tumult, thought, and fancy cease!
Day and its care have gone!
Mysterious hour,
Thy magic power
Steals o'er my heart, like music's softest tone.

             __________________

Cold must that bosom be
Which never felt thy power;
Which never thrill'd with tender melody
At this bewitching hour;
When nature's gentle art
Enchains the pensive heart;
When the breeze sinks to rest, and shuts the fragrant flower.
Wearied care how sweet to hail
Thy shadowy, calm repose,
When all is Silent but the whispering gale
Which greet the sleeping rose;
When as thy shadows blend,
The trembling thoughts ascend
And borne aloft, the gates of heaven unclose.
Written by Margaret M. Davidson at the age of 14.

Lucy H. Metcalf
Lucy, I fain would write a verse
Unique in sense, smooth, flowing, terse.
Complete in all poetic rules.
Yet free from pedantry of schools.
Haply, if I the muse could move,
My friend, to aid me she would prove,
Erst power impart to my poor brain
To form ideas, not fancies vain.
Call fitting words with careful art, 
At once to please both head and heart - 
Love's language let me rather use, 
For heart to head I always choose.

Nonsense is said to be better than sense sometimes, though I doubt the assertion, however that may be, I have fulfilled my promise you see in writing you 'a verse.' I have thrown the words together without trying for any meaning but only to make the first letter and the last syllable come right - The poetry on the other page is worth keeping.--

Dear Lucy                                                                                                 Sat Evening Feb 15th

   I have long wished to know the state of your mind, but I have had no opportunity or I should say no good one. I have reason to think you are still halting between two opinions. Is it so dear Lucy, are you still rejecting the offers of mercy! cannot you come boldly and say "as for me I will serve the Lord?" Life is uncertain death is certain; we are warned continually of this fact. And should you be called as sudden as many, are you prepared to enter that Heavenly rest which is for the children of God alone. This is a most solemn question for us all. Perhaps you are stumbling at the faults of professing Christians. I fear that my example as one professing the love of Christe, and the advancement of his kingdom in my heart, has not been as it aught.. If this has been a hindrance to you, allow it to be so no longer. look not for an example of Christian perfection here on earth, we have an example in our Saviour which was without spot or blemish if we follow will most certainly lead us to that heavenly rest. Your have calls and entreated from

your Christian friends and Sabbath School teacher and above all from your Saviour. He says "Come unto me all ye that labor and are heavy laden, and I will give you rest." ill you not accept this kind invitation ? you longer slight these offers, "He has waited long, is waiting still.

                                                                                                   You use no other friends so ill .,,

Come then dear Lucy come now and give you yourself to Christe. he is ready and willing to save all that will come unto him. The pleasures of this world are vain and empty and of very shorty duration. "We live a few years on earth and then come a neverending Eternity, and our happiness or misery during this Eternity depends uppon the course we persue during our short lives And shall we not be dilligent in preparing for this Eternity But there are calls, independent of our own interests why we should devote ourselves ? to the service of God. When we think of his boundless love in sending his only son into the world to suffer and dies, that we sinful unworthy creatures might live, we have reason to fear we can ill repay this debt. Can we then begin to ?

O! most certainly not. Then will you not come forward and give yourself to him while the day of grace is at hand. The holy spirit does not always thrive, he may depart and not return. O seize this golden hour and make your calling and Election sure. Fall uppon your knees and say 'Here Lord I give myself to thee, 'tis all that I can do. He will accept you, his arms are spread wide to receive you

               "There is a fountain filled with blood,                             
                Drawn from Immanuel's veins!
                And sinners plunged beneath that flood
                Loose all thier guilty stains."

'Here I will leave you, hopeing that my vews of your state of mind have been revived. If so well you not correct me But write me a few lines and answer those few questions above mentioned. And beleive me your sincere friend

                                                                                                    Sarah L. Stinson

Miss. L. Metcalf.

Milo 25 May ' 40

My dear Lucy

            I received and read, with pleasure, your letter I was surprised to see Mr. Hatch, though I was glad to see him. He is a good man. I wish there many such here. you will excuse me for taking a half sheet for when I begin to write I begin to tremble so it is almost impossible for me to write half a page at a time decently.
I do not know much more about Mr. S. preaching here. It is expected he will bit cannot be decided till the Missionary meeting which I believe is the first week of June. The Bible Class is interesting yet it has not been my lot to be there but once. there were at least nine & I believe more there then. Ellen had commenced her school so she will not be with us any more at present, but Oliver Furber has come home & is going to join it. I hope there will be some good done. It is thought that there is considerable feeling among the people here and oh may it result in a great revival. My side warns me that it is time for me to stop writing for this time. I wrote thus far Sat. yesterday. I went to the mill to a society meeting. Mr. Boyd had been expected but his Father (at Berwick) was sick & sent for him, he write to Mr. H. that he should be here soon as he returned. We had an interesting B. class, but for thou - Your brother C. is talking of going to B. soon and I should like he have another letter from you. Give my love to Ann, tell her I should be happy to receive a letter from her by him. I have not heard C. Ann say anything of her own feelings particularly, I think she feels and perhaps is decided but cannot say. Now my dear will you wish me every opportunity and I will write some in return. I have as many sisters there to wrote to that you must excuse my letters are short.
                                                                                                                                 Very affec. Elisabeth H.H.

Dear Lucy

I could not deny myself the pleasure of writing a few lines to you as I had such a good opportunity to send them by your Sister. When I last saw you I did not know you were going away so soon, consequently was much disapointed at not seeing you again. before you went I suppose you would like to know what kind of a class our dear teacher has now. it is quite different from what it was when you were here though not much more promising. She has now the class that was Miss Feilds when you were here there are six in the whole generally four as I was unwilling to go out at the Sabbath School. Mr. Whipple has resigned & Mr. Bush is now our Superintendent and we like him much. Miss Sampson? is now gone out of town to spend a few weeks and I am to try to fill

her place to the class, while she is absent. how far I shall succeed remains to be seen. you may suppose from this fact that our teachers are very few, but, you know she always found it difficult to get a teacher for her class, probably because she is so good a teacher. but you must not think I foolish enough to beleive that I can in any degree fill her place but she is only to be gone two weeks but it is time to bring my letter to an end; will you please to write to me, and when you come this way do come and see me . It gave me great pleasure to learn that you had made up your mind on the all important subject of religion you have now an unfailing source of happiness which the world cannot take away from you may you continue to the end. Adieu my dear friend and should we never meet again on earth

may we meet in heaven. Sister sends her love to you. do not fail to write to me.

                                                                    your affectionate friend
                                                              M. Elizabeth Pike

Our wensday afternoon meetings are very poorly attended generaly not more than three. the ? that week so forward to address the meeting does not attend at all nov. I mean
Louisa C--y.

Bangor October 12th 1840

Respected Friend

        I trust you will not judge me to have been insincere when I intimated that it would give me much pleasure to hold a correspondence with you because I have neglected so long to write. My reason for this delay is that since I last saw you I have been altogether unsettled going from place to place, untill within a few days. You see by my date that I am not, as I expected to be, in Massachusetts. Before I left for Mass. measures were adopted to continue the Classical school another year and I concluded on the whole that it might be as well or better for me to return here then remain there. I expect now to remain here untill next Autumn when life and health permitting I shall probably go to Yale.
 I found on my return to B. two members of my Sab. school Class remaining Miss Spooner and Miss Webster. It is now increased by three young ladies about your age, and I would they were altogether of your mind in respect to loving & serving God. But alas it is far otherwise, They are each without a hope in the Saviour's atoning blood, and only one manifests in any considerable degree, that interest in her lessons I could wish, and neither for the salvation of their souls. Do pray for us, for me, that I may be divinely assisted and faithful in presenting to them the claims of God for the affections of their hearts to be placed on him & not on the things of Earth.  And a Saviour's dying love as exhibited in the garden & on the Cross,

the priceless value of the soul, the consequent importance of its salvation, the fathomless & immeasurable extent of the love of God manifested in the plan of its redemption And the awful consequence of neglecting to secure it; And for them, that they may be induced in view of the above with innumerable other motives immediately to repent. Yeald their hearts to Christ, become his faithful followers, and in fine to seek in all things to answer the Chief End of man, which is to glorify God and enjoy him for ever. The interest on the Sab. School although I am sorry to say it seems to be on the wane. The number in attendance is not as large as when you left, while, at the same time, it should be larger, from the fact that its advantages are greater. It is now provided with choice library containing nearly 400 volumes. The interest ought also to be proportionably increased.  The useful matter contained in the books read during the week, should not only serve to keep the mind less occupied with worldly subjects & consequently more permanently so with those of a heavenly nature, but it should also lead the mind to an increased interest in the things which are unseen & Eternal..

 Now if there is not this manifest increased interest there is fault somewhere. And where does it rest? Are Christians praying less frequently & earnestly than formily? Do the teachers feel as anxious for spiritual well being of their pupils as they have done? Do each doing his utmost to bring all the members of his Class to a saving acquaintance with the Lord Jesus? Does he pray over the lesson with wanted fervor, that his own mind may be the more abundantly replenished with the momentous truths he is about to urge upon the considerations of his class, with the hope that they will prove

the power & wisdom of God to their salvation? And finally does he feel himself amenable to God for their salvation as he surely is, if so be they go down to Everlasting woe through his neglect? These and similar questions should be pondered as of no small moment by every S.S. teacher who finds that an increasing interest fails to be realized in his class.
What an awful account the unfaithful teacher will have to give at the judgement day! Are you a S.S. teacher? I hope you are & I hope too you are a faithful one of which I have no reason to doubt if indeed you are one. If you have a class I would advise as the first thing that you secure, if possible, their confidence, & this you will find easy to do, especially of it be a young class. When this is effective you will find it more easy to make impressions upon their minds which time can never efface. some word of instruction advice, admonition or entreaty may be blessed of God to the saving of their precious, undying souls. And as encouragement just bear in mind "that which converteth a sinner from error of his way shall save a soul from death, & shall hide a multitude of sins." And they that turn many to righteousness shall shine as the stars for ever & ever? What encouragement there is to the S.S. teacher for indefatigable efforts to win souls to Christ. Should you be made the happy instrument in the hand of God of bringing one to a knowledge of his sins & of turning his feet from the paths of vice to those of righteousness you will save a soul, upon which no "value can be placed," from death, and that mountain of sins, by the impertation of Christ righteousness which otherwise would be held up to the gaze of an assembled universe when God shall summon all to the finall judgement, will be hid.  And that soul too, which you thus save, will be as bright luminary in the crown of your rejoicing through the countless ages of Eternity. O then if you have not already, be persuaded to take a class

in S. school being assured that this place of all others is the one in which you may hope, with good reason, to become this honored instrument of saving some immortal being from the anguish of the second death. Then with no other mind that that which was in Christ engage in this glorious work, ad "you shall reap in due season if you faint not."
paid                    Miss Lucy H. Metcalf                                            James Newton

                                     Milo                                                           Oct. 12th 1840
                                              Maine 

I see I must necessarily draw to a close, and will close by soliciting an answer to this if you think it worthy, praying that you may be divinely assisted to adorn the doctrines of Christ in all things, ever seeking to do good as you have opportunity. Yours in Christian love & fellowship. J.A. Newton

Boston October 26th 1840.

My Dear Lucy

       It is with great pleasure that I have an opportunity of sending a letter to you by Mrs. Searles. I want to see you very much indeed. When you answer this letter I want you to tell me how you got home & send me all the news you can. I have not much to say in this letter. I did not know that Mrs. Searles was going so soon or else I should have written a longer one but you must Excuse me. I am well and I hope you are. Give my love to Miss Rich & your mother & take a portion of it to yourself and before long I hope we shall meet again. Oh Lucy! I had almost forgotten it. Mary Newcomb sends her best love to you and Miss Rich. Do you remember the 2nd of October and your silk dress it is 4 years ago but it does not seem so, but time flies rapidly. I suppose you know that Mr. Whipple has left the Sunday School as Superintendent, but when he left  (after the absence of three or four weeks) he intended to take a Class but his health would not permit. His lungs are in a Very dangerous state. He Visited the Sabbath School Oct 18th & with much difficulty said a few words, he bid us Farewell as his Physician advise him to go south as it was uncertain weather he should see us again. Yours affectionately
                                                                                                                                                                                                   H. M. Goddard

N.B. Pray Lucy do not wait so long before you answer this letter as I did. Lucy H. Metcalf.

Bangor July 24th 1841

Highly Esteemed Madam-

      For a long time I have been wishing to write you, but knew not whether to direct your address to Milo or Boston as I think before you left Bangor you mentioned that you some expected to visit the latter place this spring. But having learned from your friend Mrs. Cutler who visited the family in which I board one afternoon of the present week that you are still in Milo, I gladly embrace this favorable moment for gratifying this desire, Though the subject upon which I address you may be the least of all expected. Yet, dear L. be assured that since our first acquaintance thou, who are destined to become the arbitress of much of my future happiness or misery, has possessed the most tender of my heart's affections.
That you would wish in any way to be the cause of the latter I cannot allow myself for a moment to believe for I feel it would be doing you the greatest injustice to think that a heart possessed of virtues so sensitive & tender as yours could ever be the willing agent of unhappiness to any one.
                     Permit me to say, dearest L., that naught on earth could, at present, contribute more to my happiness than the indulgence of the fond hope of being permitted at some future day to do all that shall be in my power to administer to you every earthly comfort as the companion of my bosom.
I presume it unnecessary to mention what I expect will

be the business of my future life as you are doubtless already aware that is the Gospel ministry.

 An early answer to the question whether I may be allowed to cherish the fond hope I have expressed above will be a great relief to those feeling now severely agitated by suspense & as I fondly hope, will secure to me that glowing tranquility, which is in your power to confer by a word of encouragement to my urgent suit.
As I have not made this avowal of my highest regards for & earnest solicitation from you without mature reflection and much prayer so I trust you will seek the counsel of High Heaven and confer with your worthy Mother before you dictate an answer.

Let me say here that your favor of Dec. was gratefully rec'd and read with interest. I expect to leave for College in about give weeks.

 Anxiously hoping for a favourable reply. I am, dearest Lucy Yours sincerely -                                                      James Newton

Miss Lucy H. Metcalfe
