Bangor August 7th 1841

Dear Lucy,

                I received your letter about the last of June; and I should have answered it before; but I have been sick with the Whooping Cough; and have not been able to write. I was sorry to hear that you was sick for I wanted you to come back and attend school this term. you said you wanted to see all the girls; and I dare say they all want to see you.

We get along very well this term; and I think we make great progress in our studys. We have the same task yet, to perform in school; that is writing compositions. I do not dread composing them so much as I used to. E Marston; H. Mcintire; and a number of other schollars from our school; attend the Littlefield school this term. our examination is in about a fortnight; and you cant think how I dread it. The schollars are dropping of one after another. some are sick and others are a going away: and some for one thing and some for another. I think there will be but a few scholars there examination day. Mary Henderson left of coming to school about the middle of this term. I

hope we shall pass a good examination; and I wish you could be there. I shall be very happy to come up and see you if it were not for my school. I think I should enjoy it very much; as I have not been in the country for a long time. I suppose you enjoy yourself much better being at home at this season of the year as it is now most time for ripe fruit and vegetables, than you would to be at school. I suppose your garden of flowers which you took so much pains to cultivate in the spring is now in full bloom. It is very sickly here among children and youth. The Scarlet Fever prevails the most of any disease. M. Mills is sick with the Scarlet Fever. The last that I heard from her was that she was very sick. On the Fourth of July, or rather on the Fifth of July, which was celebrated for the Fourth, there was not any celebration worth nameing. There was an address delivered on Slavery. I attended the meeting and I think I never saw so few collected together on such a day in my life. I have a little sister, about a month old and you must find a name for her. give my love to Abby Hill and tell her I want to see her very much.
please write me as soon as you receive this

                                                                                          Your affectionate friend
                                                                                                     Annette House

Dixmont Sept. 4th 1841.

Highly esteemed Friend

                         Saturday night having overtaken me at this place on my return from Bowdoin College, where I passed an examination for admittance yesterday, I think it may not be improper to improve the passing moment in acknowledging the receipt of Your most acceptable answer to my last, which was quite as favourable as I had reason to expect. I shall leave here for Bangor monday and hope to be in Milo in the course of the week, when if I am as happy as to see you. & I hope I shall be, I can say more in ten minutes than I could write in an hour had I the time. but I must hasten to close this that I may be able to mail it to night before the Office closes. I expect to come out in company with Mrs. Wingate, the lady of the house where I boarded the summer past. She is wishing to visit her friends in that vicinity & I have engaged to drive her chaise.

Please accept my best wishes, Yours most affectionately

                                                                                                                                              James Newton

Sketch of  BOWDOIN COLLEGE, BRUNSWICK ME  Thayer, successor to Moore, Boston.
                                                                                                                                                                  Bowdoin College (Brunswick) Oct. 19th 1841

Ever dear L.

                               More than three weeks have elapsed since by the kindness of your sister (Miss Rich) I received favorable intelligence in regard to your health.

Yet, although the information afforded encouragement in your case, and in a measure, relieved my mind of great anxiety, I can but feel anxious to learn your present state. A relapse may have brought you, ere this, lower than ever. But I hope not. I hope to learn by an early answer to this that, if you have not already, you are fast regaining your accustomed health. If so, what reason for thankfulness to God the kind Author of so great a blessing. Health surely is a blessing none can justly estimate but those who have been deprived of its enjoyment. Wherefore it is but just to infer that whenever God visits us

with afflictions it is only to prepare our minds the better to enjoy the blessings his benevolent heart prompts him so profusely to lavish upon us. Realizing therefore our dependence on God, may we ever have in constant exercise feelings of devout gratitude towards him for all his benefits both spiritual & temporal, like the Psalmist may we in sincerity call upon out souls & all within us to bless & magnify his holy name.

 Four weeks of my college life have now passed away & for the most part pleasantly. Mr. Gould from Dixmont is my room mate as you will perceive by the catalogue I send you. In order to shun as much as possible the initiatory salutes, common to freshmen from the higher classes, such as breaking out windows, staving down doors & the like, we hired us a room out of the college. Nearly all rooming in College of the freshmen class have been saluted as above & some have been dealt even worse with. There seems to be nothing to bad for some of the students to do.

I am grieved to find so few in the freshman class who profess to be christians. As yet I have learned of but four, we meet around in each others' rooms for prayer every sab. morning before breakfast. I hope this little number will increase until it embraces each member of class. In the other classes the proportionate number of professing christians is considerably larger. In the sophomore class I believe there are twelve, but how small a number this compared with what it ought to be. May God of his infinite mercy pour out upon us the efficacious influence of his grace till there shall not be one left to go out from the consecrated place with an unsanctified heart. 

  I think this college view rather imperfect. North College & Main Hall are too far south & the trees are represented as being quite too large; though it does not represent the place as being any more pleasant than it really is. It is a delightful spot. Within the college enclosures are some fifteen acres, as level & smooth as need be. And directly East is a beautiful grove neatly pruned out & the earth grown over with grass.
 My health since I have been here has not been at all good when I came out first, I took some cold & have been getting additions since untill it have come to be quite severe & what has before been unusual, it has been attended with considerable cough. But I feel in hopes I am getting better of it.
  I hope to hear from you soon & shall feel quite anxious untill I do. Please give my respects to your people.
                                       Ever yours in true friendship

Miss Lucy H. Metcalf                                                                               James Newton

Brunswick Feb. 19. 1842

Much esteemed Friends

                        It is not for want of the highest regard towards you that I have so long neglected to acknowledge the receipt of your kind letter bearing date Nov. 12th the perusal of which gave me the mingled feelings of pleasure & pain. I was rejoiced to learn that you were in any degree recovering from your low estate, but was sorry it was in so gradual a manner. I hope ere this you have fully regained your health and can now lift up the voice of thanks - giving to the Giver of all our mercies for the full enjoyment of one of Earth's greatest comforts.
   Health is a blessing we but little prize as we ought until we are for a time deprived of its enjoyments. And even when we have learned something of its worth by painful experience how soon do we forget duly to regard those laws, so well known to us all designed for its preservation? Perhaps next to the interests of the soul are the means of health neglected by mankind generally. I do not say this reflecting that your sickness was in any way attributed to a want of suitable care & caution by you. Yet I do feel especially desirous that in case you may have partially or altogether recovered you should use every precaution to retain your health - almost the only thing that renders life itself desirable though I doubt not you will.
  During the two week before this I was engaged in teaching in Topsham a town adjoining this. The school was small but pleasant. Being so near the college I was favoured with an access to the Libraries & employed the most of my leisure hours in reading.

Among the books I read was that of Dr. Grants giving an account of the Nestorian Christians, containing a journal of his two visits from his station at Coroomiah to these mountain tribes, and his reasons for considering them a remnant of the Ten Tribes.
 It is an exceedingly interesting work - and one which I hope is destined to do much good by awakening an interest in the churches not hither to felt in behalf of the Missionary enterprise.
 The Doctor thinks that notwithstanding the degradation into which these people are sunk, they will soon rise from their intellectual & almost spiritual death to their former state of religious interest & influence the case of Christ. He states that in their present ignorance they exhibit so much of the true Christian spirit. he could but fellowship many of them as the real friends of the Redeemer. And even went so far in manifesting that fellowship as to partake of the Lord's supper with them. If you have not I could wish that you might be able to find this book. I am sure you would be much entertained & I think profited by reading it.
  I have taken the liberty of occasionally sending you a paper & shall be pleased to continue so to do it it is agreeable. I was much entertained in the perusal of the paper you sent me, and the more so from the fact that it gave me, as I trust reason to believe you a friend to the Abolition cause, in which I have & do still feel a great interest, and earnestly desire the time to be hastened when this national blot shall be swept away & our beloved country freed from the sin of slavery.
   Allow me to inquire if you expect to remain at your mother's the coming spring & summer? In case you should, I

shall come East to spend my spring vacation provided urgent business does not call me to Massachusetts, and should it be agreeable on your part. shall feel myself honored in making you a visit, which, if enjoyed, I hope the state of your health will be such as to render more agreeable to you than my former one. It was then such that I felt it injudicious for you to talk much.

 So sudden & extreme have been the changes of the weather here this winter that the inhabitants almost without exception have suffered much from severe colds and in the case of many it will I doubt not terminate in consumption. Within about three weeks God has seen fit in his righteous Providence to visit this town with the scarlet fever by which very many of the youth and children & in some instances adult persons have been swept away. There were nine lay corpses in the place one day last week. Wh? a call to be also ready? How true it is "we know neither the day nor the hour when the son of Man cometh."
 The religious interest here is very low, though I think the prospect of better time is a little more flattering now than it has been, but still the ways of Zion mourn & comparatively few come to her solemn feasts, her priests sigh, she is yet in bitterness. May the Lord come quickly & revive the drooping graces of his children. I hope it is not so in Milo. I hope to hear that Christians there are prating with much fervency & strong faith for the reviving influences of God's Spirit, And witnessing answers to their prayers by seeing many turning from the ways of sin to holiness. Please let me hear from you soon. Yours in sincere friendship                                         James Newton

Miss Lucy H. Metcalf
[left-hand side] P.S. Please give my respects to your Mother & all the family and through you hear from them all.

Milo Feb 24 ' 42

My dear Lucy

                 Your proposition of a regular confidential correspondence meets my wishes exactly. It is what I have myself thought of asking, but a fear of my inability to perform punctually (to say nothing of my indolence) has detered me from doing so; but now that you have volunteered I must heartily acquiese. I think it is out privilege Lucy, and in some measure our duty as member of the same church and indulging the same hopes freely to open our minds to each other and encourage and comfort each other in our pilgrimage.

The Sewing Circle cannot legally meet again untill the second Tuesday in April. We adjourned at the least meeting to that time and if we would meet we have not much to do and no presiding officer. Mrs. Dow would not probably be able to attend so that we might depend upon her and you know we have made no provision for choosing new officer.s
              My feeble prayers, dear Lucy, you shall have, that your afflictions may work out for you a far more exceeding and eternal weight of glory and that while you live you may live to the glory of God and when you die you may be admitted to the blissful presence of God 

[right side]and the Lamb forever. This note is written in haste [top upside down] and confusion and I hope I shall [left-hand side] receive a long one in return. your sincere friend Naomi

My dear Lucy

       With shame that I have so long neglected you I now commence the agreeable task of attending to you. As our correspondence is designed for mutual profit and interest I shall therefore come at once upon serious and interesting topics.
 Dear Lucy I am deeply impressed with the feeling that we must and I dare to think that we shall, have very soon an outpouring of the spirit of God in this wicked place. I am moreover sensible that this great and undeserved blessing will come

in commission? with the faithful and persevering prayers of God's people and perhaps of this particular church. That Saviour who was moved with compassion toward the multitude that had been three days and with Him having nothing to eat and who fed them so bountifully of seven loaves and a few small fishes is no less compassionate toward this people who have been so long famishing upon the husks of worldly things. He is now waiting with intense solicitude to bestow and it is only for us to reach out and recieve the blessing and it is ours.          Can it be that when

so much is in store for us we shall fold our hands and shut our hearts and permit those who have no interest in Christ to fail of salvation! I hope I am not mistaken when I seem to see, already, thoughtfulness and anxiety in the countenances of some. 
Lucy, what do you think of our having female prayer meetings?
- It seems to me highly desirable, at least, and I know not why 'twould not be expedient and certainly they will not be otherwise than profitable. O, remember me daily at the throne of grace that my faith fail not and that grace may be given me to continue until

the end.   your affectionate friend

                                  Naomi


N.S. Hill                                         Miss Lucy H. Metcalf
March 1842                                                 Present

My dear friend Lucy

           How do you do this morning? I feel desirous to hear that you did not take cold Tuesday and that you feel the better for your ride, though I presume you was considerably fatigued. In one of your billets which I have not answered you complimented me pretty generously for my ? rest of this sentence and next opinion. I do not undervalue but I fear if you was perfectly right I should not have delayed so long to write you.

I fear my habit of procrastination is growing upon me - but some how pr other I am all the time engaged about something if I do not other things which I intend and know I ought to do.

 The children are ready and I am not half done. please write me and I will endeavor to be more punctual in future.
                                                                                                                                   Naomi

April 7th ' 42

My dear Lucy

                                    Your letter was duly recieved Tuesday morning which I felt inclined to answer immediately but thought I would defer it untill to-day that I might have sufficient time to answer it as it deserves. You ask if I know of any particular persons who I think are feeling thoughtful on the subject of religion? I know of only one who I think may be and perhaps I am mistaken in that one though I do earnestly desire that that individual may soon be numbered among the people of God. As I have so little evidence that my hopes are well grounded I dare not mention the name. Lucy, the still small voice of the Spirit has been among us when and where we know not of it. One case I will confide to you prefering that you should not mention it at present. I recieved a letter from Olive Furber while I was at Bangor last fall which affords to me good evidence that she has become a christian! I had long felt a particular interest for her and made her a particular subject of prayer and when I read her letter I felt that God is indeed a hearer and answerer of the persevering  impartunities of those who desire that

the Saviour may see if the travail of His soul and be satisfied.

I felt encourage to hope and pray for the bestowment of still greater blessings and as though I could not live long enough to pray the salvation of immortal souls. I have refrained from speaking of Olive's conversion because she confidentially told me her feelings and requested prayers that she might not be deceived and because I wish to see the fruits before the fact is made known. Now if you thin I did wrong in telling you I wish you to say so - my motive is to encourage your faith as mine was encouraged.  Dear Lucy it is even as you say - I feel that God is waiting to be gracious even unto us. O that we could feel the force of that - waiting - waiting to be gracious. Does it not imply that we are not prepared to recieve the blessing? that we have yet something to do which we have not yet done? that we must feel as we have never yet felt and pray as we have not yet prayed? Are we willing to be low in the dust and be counted as the filth and offscouring of all things that God may work here and work a work of grace and have all the glory to Himself? Are we willing to be anything or nothing that souls may be saved?  O we must experience such heart searchings and sincere repenting and deep humiliation before God ere He can condescend to dwell with us. O let us Lucy lift up our united cry, with strong and persevering faith that God would make known to this people the riches of His grace.

As to the question which I put to you at your house I have thought I ought to apologize for and ask your pardon for inquiring into what perhaps it is none of my business to know. I doubt not your confidence in me, at all and think as you do, that it would not be right for you to make known the contents of his letter to any but those concerned; but my question was, whether you had come to an engagement? but that is none of my business, and if you do not see fit you need not tell me. I know of Newton's partiality towards you but believe I had no suspicion that he had written you and thought it was not his intention to make an immediate proposal. I have tried to place myself in your situation as you requested and I think I should have, as you had, many scruples whether it would be right for me to show such a letter to any one - but if to any body it would be one whose trust I had tried and was sure such an one would not betray me, and even then, I should be governed by considerations and circumstances. I am glad of it hoping that you will "hitch up" a step nearer to us. 'Twill seem a sight better to go to see you and [continued left -hand side]

                                                  your sincere friend   Naomi

[left-hand side and top] Mrs. Searles all together. Lucy what is your opinion about calling on Mrs. EA Dow? For my part I cannot find in my heart to give her up , it seems to me that by keeping an acquaintance with her we visiting her we may exert a good influence on her a good way.

April 10th '42

My dear Lucy

                                 How thankful ought we to be for the Sabbath, with its sweet stillness and calm and holy privileges! - How little do we prise this blessed day as we should do! - Though we cannot always meet in the sanctuary of God and write in supplication, thanksgiving and praise, yet we are not defined of the Book of Life nor of the calm retreat and silent shade "which so well with prayer and praise agree." If our circumstances are such that cannot be alone in person yet we can retire in the spirit of our minds and commune with our God and Saviour and derive such food from the great source of all our blessing as the world knoweth not of. O the blessedness of the christian religion! what a wonder that I was ever made a partaker of it! --
 How different is the state of my dear, dear sister today from what is was a year ago. Then she was pining with the sickness her spirit confined within a tenement of clay - to day - O the rapture of her freed spirit. She is done with the emblems of a Sabbath of rest and is now in the full enjoyment of the reality of a never ending rest from all

that can disturb or distract. She is uniting with our dear father in ascriptions of praise to God and the Lamb. A few more days of trial and I shall be admited to join with them in this blissful employment! "O what eternal joys await the christian mariner He enters the celestial gates Where endless pleasures are".

Wed May 13th I guess)  You see dear Lucy that you have not been forgotten by me during this long silence and I must confess that I am not altogether justifiable for having so long held my peace. Human nature is hard to be entirely overcome and 'tis a part of my nature to wait for a more convenient season to do the things which ought to be immediately attended to --

I believe that in our last communication we expressed hopes that God would come and help even us with an outpouring of His Spirit; the ever this wicked people might see his salvation.- and has he disappointed our hopes? While we were speaking after to one another did he not open the windows of heaven and pour us out a blessing? And what suitable return shall we make unto him for his unspeakable goodness. How shall we so wait upon him that he shall continue to show is favor and "rebuke the devourer for our sakes"? How shall I wait patiently upon God

and continue to wrestle with him untill not one soul is left out of Christ. O Lucy I am weak and ignorant and am sometimes almost left to wish that I could cease to exist for fear that I shall not walk before God with all meekness and circumspection. Is there not something yet under which Christians ought to do to prepare the way of the Lord that he may ride forth more gloriously in the chariot of his grace? Are we anxious enough for the glory of God on conversion with the salvation of souls. Do we feel that God must dwell with us that we cannot let him go and that we will recieve even the crumbs that fall from our master's table? Dear Lucy allow me to solicit your prayers for my dear brothers - they are both of them (I have reason to think) ? with a sense of the importance religion and O that that might now come into ? of it. Ammi Carver too is particularly upon my mind. O let us pray for his unitedly - he is borne down almost in complete anguish longing for the appearance of the Saviour and let us pray that Christ may speak peace to his soul.. What a work Christians have upon their hands! What need of walking constantly with the Saviour! - The verses which you send me are very pretty indeed and very appropriate and are complete expressions of my feelings. ever your affet sister Naomi

Woonsocket Apr 13th 1842

Cousin Lucy

     I received your letter of March 28th with much pleasure, as it convey'd intelligence of friends that I have not seen for a long time and I will endeavor to answer it, although I ave not much to write that will interest you. 
 I have not attended school the past winter. I went in the Fall, about a mile from where we live, the school was kept by a lady. We had a very pleasant school indeed.
 Charles is learning the bobin makers trade he commenced about two months ago. It is rather new business to him but I believe he likes it very well so far.
 The Village of Woonsocket has altered considerably since you visited us, there have been two Meeting Houses built also three school Houses, and a great many dwelling houses. I think you would hardly know the place.
 I suppose you know that we do not live in the same part of the village we did when you were here

Father having built a small house on the west side of the river, and about half a mile from it.
If you should come now I think you would say that we live in a much pleasanter place than when you visited us before, we have considerable of a door? yard now filled with rose bushes, and various kinds of plants, which presents a striking contrast to the one the other side of the river. But I guess you are tired of this subject, so I will go on to something else. You say the young ladies at Milo have a Sewing Circle, we also have one here though the married and single ladies all meet together, we generaly have reading from some member of the society, or from some gentleman that happens in. The proceeds of the society are appropriated to the rest of the poor. A number of families of children have been provided with clothing to attend the sabbath school and meeting. It is called the Ladies Samaritan sewing circle. They intend having a library attached to it, which will make it still more pleasant.

  Our sabbath school commenced a fortnight ago. There were 160 scholars the first sabbath, and quite a number more the next. At the close of the school last Fall, we had an Exhibition in which there were a number of diologues spoken, besides addresses, and Poetry, by the

smaller Children, there were a number of peices sung by little girls. There was one peice sung by nearly half the children in school, the children being nearly of a size, they made quite an interesting appearance.

  Uncle Jacob and Cousin Josiah were here last Fall and made us a visit of a few days. Though as you have had a letter from Josiah I suppose he told you all the news, and I suppose you know what has transpired lately, better than I do, as we have not had a letter in some little time.
  We had a letter from Uncle Enoch not long since, his folks are all well. I have never yet seen little Charles Uncle Enoch's youngest boy.
   I think cousin Lucy you have had considerable of a share of sickness. I hope your health will continue to improve, as you write it is better than it has been.  We have generaly enjoyed pretty good health excepting colds, which have been very common here.. Give my love to Aunt and all my cousins. Mother send love to all.
                                         Your affectionate cousin Eleanor M. Metcalf
              I had forgotten to tell you that Father wrote a letter to your Mother in March, which I thought by your letter she had not recieved. Please write as soon as convenient.

Bangor Sept. 22nd 1842

Ever dear and never forgotten Friend

                                                   Nothing could have induced me to believe when I saw you last that so long a time would have elapsed without my writing you. The causes of this neglect have been various. It surely has not been because I have not thought of or wished to hear from you, but in part for want of convenient opportunity. Until the latter part of the term my time was wholly taken up, for besides my regular studies I have considerable to make up by being absent the last of the spring term and the first of the summer and in addition had no trifling task to perform in writing an address, pronounced before my Class at the close of our freshman year. After the term has considerably advanced I neglected to write, thinking I should be able to visit you in the vacation; but circumstances have conspired so as to oblige me to forgo this pleasure. My roommate Mr. Gould of Dixmont, being desirous that I should teach near him the coming winter, last spring when at home partially engaged a school for me in his town a short distance from were himself proposed to teach. And being encouraged with the prospect of having one or two singing schools to teach at the same time I have been to Dixmont and engaged the school at twenty dollars per month for three months. And have the promise of several to interest themselves in getting up one or more singing schools. I came from

Dixmon to this place yesterday and having given up the idea of coming to Milo, as I could wish, this fall, concluded to write from here hoping by the time I shall arrive at Brunswick to find a letter from you in answer to this. I expect ow to return the next Monday's boat. My health for the past term, and is now, as good I think as I have enjoyed at any time since I left Michigan,  a blessing for which I trust I feel grateful. The spirit of religion continues low in College. I hope the Year to come may not be as has been the one past in this respect. I do hope that another year may not complete its circuit without some hopeful conversions in college. It seems to me that the year past in a spiritual sense as been next to lost with us there, those clouds big with mercies which were scattered though the length & breadth of our land importing b their genial showers a life-giving power to thousands were suffered to pass us almost if not wholly in rain. I can but hope it may not be so in time to come. There are some in college although the number is comparatively small, who I trust, are praying devoted disciples of our blessed Lord & Saviour Jesus Christ. This little band meet regularly twice in a week for prayer and conference; the times of meeting are on saturday evening & Sabbath morning an hour & a half before public worship. They need and I trust in some good degree have, the prayers of Christian friends. How important it is that the influence was and extensive, which will be exerted by those who go out an from year to year from that place of mental training, be a sanctified influence. I sometimes fear that Christians do not feel this subject to be of half the moment it really demands.

A word in regard to Commencement. It was truly an interesting one and I heard several say that one more so had not been enjoyed for many years. Tuesday afternoon two literary societies, Peucinian and Athenaean held their anniversary meetings. The Athenaean selebrated first. It was addressed by the Rev. John Lord of Berwick, generally know as a lecturer on History. His subject was the Middle Ages. He gave a vivid description of the state of society in those times, and vindicated them from those evil tendencies so often charged upon them. He confined his remarks chiefly to the Germanic tribes, naming some of the prominent traits of character which distinguished the period & especially these tribes. Among which he instanced their love of personal independence, high veneration for woman & for the priesthood and maintained that it was by the power of faith that our progenitors were rescued from the evil influences which surrounded them. Their philosophy, next fell under his revision. The disputes of the schoolmen were treated of, & he close ? a high panegyrie on their modes of investigation & dwelt ? upon the advantage which might result from a more ? entrance by modern scholars into "the inner temple of ? philosophy." The stile of Mr. L.'s writing is peculiar and interesting. The manner of his delivery any thing but ? be possessed by an Orator. You have doubtless noticed the description of the other exercises in the Mirror which so surpass one I could give. I will forbear even to name them. I shall hope to learn that you have ere this fully regained your strength, thought I should not think strange at all, if this is not the case. You was bro't so extremely low by your violent & protracted sickness.
Regards to your mother & family, Mr. & Mrs. Searles. Yours as ever J. Newton

M M
                                                                                                                                                                  Lowell, May 15, 1843?5?

Dear Cousin.

      I received your letter last week, and am now improving the first opportunity to answer it. Perhaps you will be a little surprised when I tell you that when I first opened it, I could not imagine who it was from, and that I had really forgotten who Lucy H. Metcalf was; but I soon found out, and right glad was I to hear from you and your family, of whom we had heard nothing for a long, long time. I don't wonder I had forgotten you, from the fact that I never was much acquainted with you, and also from the length of time that has intervened of since I had seen you, and more particularly since I had heard from you. Isaac and I corresponded a short time after you went to Milo, but  the correspondence ceded with Isaac for what reason I never knew. I wrote to him last, and since then, it has been only by accident that we have heard from any of you; and you may rest assured that I and indeed all of us were very glad to hear from you once more, and hope that for the future we shall hear from our friends in Maine oftener.
 I reccollect very well seeing you in Boston, and although "old time"had nearly effaced the circumstance from my memory, yet the reception and perusal of your letter brought it up again fresh to my memory, the encroachments of "Old Father Time" to the contrary notwithstanding! I should like very much to see you, Isaac, Mayo, Aunt, Charles etc. and hope to have the pleasure soon; as you write that you think of spending the next Winter in Mass; and also that Aunt & Ann think of visiting Mass. Should you do so, you must not fail from coming to Lowell. We heard of you last visit to Mass, and were very much disappointed because you did not visit us, and hope you will not again neglect us. We had heard of Almeda's removal to Milo; but did not know it until several months after they

had gone. Being in Boston I called, where they used to live, and was informed by the people in the house that they had gone to Milo, which a little surprised me, as I had not know of their intention to do so. We were glad to hear of their good health, and hope the change from city to country will be beneficial. And you inform me that you are attending an Academy in Foxcroft, which from your description must be a very pleasant and good school. You doubtless are enjoying yourself finely, particularly if you love your books, and I presume there is no doubt of it, as all of your family were always very fond of books and study. Your studies are all interesting, particularly Astronomy & Philosophy, and I presume you find them so. I am anxious to know one thing; viz how old you are; will you inform me when you write again & so do. Also the age of Isaac & Mayo; I have really forgotten.  I did not see the lady who brought your letter, and presume she did not come to Lowell, as it was mailed at Methuen about 10 miles from Lowell. We were sorry to hear of Aunt's ill health, and hope that relaxation from her duties will completely restore her to health again. I have been quite unwell the past Winter with Bronchitis and Inflammation of the Lungs, occasioned at first by a cold and made worse by singing. Was confined to my room several weeks, and no one allowed to see me,  as the least exercise of my lungs produced coughing. I had a severe cough and was not able to attend to my business for about two months. I am now better, and my cough has nearly left me, and the warm weather will I think entirely effect a cure. I think of going to the South in the fall, as the cold winters of New England do not agree with me. The rest of our family are in good heath and have been so for sometime. Sarah as you are probably informed is married. She has three fine children. Caleb graduated last August and has been in Peru, the past winter

teaching. Expect him home in a few weeks/ Enoch is in a Counting Room here, the same I was in before Almeda went to Milo. I am now engaged in teaching music; teach the Piano Forte and singing, and have a salary for singing on the Sabbath at the Episcopal Church. Is music taught in your Academy? and have you ever attended to it? How far is Milo from Portland? I was at Portland last Summer and spent several days. It is a beautiful place, and I enjoyed myself finely while there, and think some of visiting there again this summer. Have not heard from our friends in Royalston for several months; then they were all well. We have had beautiful Spring weather for several days and the prospect now is that grim old winter has really departed, and I for one am heartily glad he is gone, and hope he will take a long journey ere he troubles us again. The past winter has been the severest ever known in Mass. and immense quantities of snow has fallen. Well Cousin Lucy this is the first letter I have had the pleasure of writing to you and may it prove equally as acceptable to you, as yours was to me; and is this to be the close of our correspondence? I hope not. As Isaac has broken off our correspondence by not answering my last letter, I shall now claim you, as my future correspondent, and shall expect to have the pleasure of receiving another letter from you soon; and my dear Coz, you must not disappoint me. Remember! Give my love to all of your good people. Father, Mother, Sister & Brother also wish to be remembered. Give my love also to Cousin Lucy! and beleive me

                                                                                                                                                         Your Affectionate Cousin
                                                                                                                                                             Isaac N. Metcalf

Woonsocket May 28th 1843

Dear Cousin

                      I recieved your letter in March, and I can assure you, it was with pleasure, that I recieved inteligence from friends so far distant.
                      You spoke of your visit at Woonsocket, you say that you do not reccollect much, of the village. I think if you should visit us now, you would hardly know the place it is so much enlarged and improved.
                    I have been attending school this spring part of the time, the school is taught in the vestry of the Universalist meeting-house, the distance is about a mile from where we live, but as it is through the pleasant part of the village, the walk was very aggreable to me, the school is taught by a lady. different kinds of work are taught, at present there is the most cruel work in school of any kind.
                    We all enjoy very good health, which is a great blessing, and one which cannot be too highly appreciated. It has I believe been generally healthy in this place for the past yea. What has interested us most for a few

months past has been the recent Election. But now it is cooled down very much. Politicians have little to say - having "said out". It was an Election of more importance than any previous, in which every energy was exerted, and the result you probably know. Millerism has not made much advance in this village. we had one - Lecturer here in the winter who lectured four to five times, having full houses at first, but grew thinner towards the last, most attending out of mere curiosity.

              I guess you will think this is rather a disconnected letter, as it is now more than a week since the commencement of it, some one coming in, I was obliged to leave my writing unfinished. Charles had a letter from Cousin Josiah, a few days since, informing us of the death of his mother. She has gone to the land whence no traveler returns, where this corruptible must put on incorruption, and this mortal must put on immortality. The last letter that he wrote to us early in the spring, they were in hopes, that the coming warm weather would be beneficial to her and that she would be more comfortable but it was ordered otherwise, and her spirit has returned to the God who gave it. He writes, that calmly, and with but few struggles, she passed the great change, which awaits all mortals. May 19th at the past 2 o'clock. Prescott's health has been rather poor for some time past, being troubled with a cough

He says they are in hopes it is better. They have had an addition of a son to their family within a few weeks, which makes three children, two sons and a daughter. It is some time since we heard from Uncle Enoch's folks, the last time we heard from them they all enjoyed good health. Perhaps you hear from them as often as we do, though the distance is much greater? By the catalogue of scholars, that I received from Foxcroft Academy, I learn that you are attending school there. We should be very happy to recieve a visit from you, and the rest of your family. Now that Almeda and her family have removed from Boston, we expect to see you this way very soon. 
   Remember with pleasure my visit at Milo, and should like to repeat it, as you remember our romping over the fields and meadows and down to the Interval to gather flowers, the Swing in one of the out house chambers, and making dresses for the dolls are all "still fresh" in my memory. Our love to all your family. I should be happy to receive a letter from you as soon as convenient.
                                                                           Affectionately your Cousin

Lucy H. Metcalf                                                                                                   Eleanor A. Metcalf

Foxcroft Aug. 26th 1843

Absent Friend

        I fear I have given you occasion to think I have forgotten my voluntary engagements to write you. Perhaps you have even begun to suspect, my professions of regard dwelt on the lips- but came not near the heart, but my time has been so much occupied in the various domestic affairs of our family, that I have hardly had time to write to my dearest friend. My sister have all been absent this summer, and the work must nessessarily deade? on Mother, and myself. But I doubt not that you are acquainted with the duties of a farmers family, and will excuse me, for so long delaying an answer to your very interesting letter, which was duly received and perused with much pleasure.
                                                                                                                                                                                                       I was happy

to hear of your good health, and that you was so pleasantly situated in your new home , where you appeared to have every thing to make you comfortable and happy. Although I can not say I think as pleasant to teach and attend school (especially if we have a good instructor) Mr. Tash has closed his school and gone to visit his friends. He has engaged a female

assistant for next term which I think will add very much to the interest felt in the school & presume it will be very large and should like to make on of their number but my sisters wish to go and it will not be consistent for us all to go this term, so I must be contented to stay away. We are not apt to realize the worth of our school hour till they have fled beyond our reach, then we look back and sigh for those portions of knowledge which we might have treasured up had we rightly improved past opportunities. 

                             But there is a kind of knowledge which is of far greater worth than all human learning. I mean that which maketh wise unto salvation. We live in a part of the world destinguished for its religious privileges - the light of divine truth illuminates our land. We have the written word of God to teach us his will and our duty, and the way to obtain eternal life. This is written in a stile as simple that it may be understood by very young children, yet it affords an inexhaustible source of new and sublime ideas to the researches of the schollar. This rich treasure we have in our own hands and may peruse it when we will, we have also sabbath and sanctuary privileges and every inducement to become the followers of the meek and lowly Jesus who went about doing good

can we slight all the invitations of the blessed savior's dying love. But I trust & have given my heart to Christ and desire and interest in your prayer that I may so live that when the messenger of death shall overtake me I may be prepared to meet it with a peaceful smile and resign my soul into the hands of Him who has died to redeem us by his own blood.

 I cannot close this without telling you of the happy meeting with my dear brother who had been abroad nearly five years  he made a very short visit and left with Mr. Tash who accompanied him as far as Boston, but I will write no more lest you should be unable to read it so I close begging you not to follow the example I have left you? but write soon. Please excuse this unconnected scribble and except from your sincere friend                                                           R R Tower

P S Please send me paper when you receive this.

Sabbath eve Dec. 3rd 1843        

My own dear sister, Lucy

                                                                                                                                                                                                                I was made truly glad

by the reception and perusal of another kind letter from you this P M by the hand of brother Marshall, but will first answer the one of Nov. 19th. In that you say that you have not written me for a long time because you thought your letters were not acceptable.

          I acknowledge with shame that you had to much reason to think so, though in reality this was not the case.
          Lucy I am confounded and almost overwhelmed with painful regret, mortification and confusion of pain by a view of my life and conduct for a year past.
          I do not wonder that, when I was so openly denying an attachment to the friends of the Saviour by my too friendly intercourse with the ungodly, you thought any communication of a religious character would be unacceptable: but whatever my feelings might have been if you had written me perhaps it might have been the means of bringing me sooner to myself. These were months of fancied ( but not without many misgivings and deep relenting of conscience) enjoyment but O have been far from any thing like happiness. I would rather be allowed one hour of real penitence at the foot of the cross or one moment of rejoicing and prayer for the conversion of a soul to Christ, than an age of such worldly-mindedness and folly. O, if I ever knew any thing of the love of Christ or felt any interest in the advancement of his kingdom, how far

is possible for a lover (?) of the Saviour to stray from him.

  When I came to myself I knew not which way to turn. It seemed to me that Christians could not overlook such a utter dereliction of the faith of rectitude and recieve me with any favour; and I had almost limited the Holy One of Israel and thought God could not pardon such a sinner. But forever blessed be his holy name, he has not left me utterly to despair. There is balm in Gilead, there is a Physician there O may I daily repair to that fountain, which is set afar ? and un-cleaness, for the washing away of my mountains of sins; and may I pray not only for myself but may I and may you be enabled to go to the Saviour with a heart burdened for the impenitent and there at his feet plead with faith in their behalf untill we recieve an answer to our petitions.
  Let us go like the prodigal returning to his father and we shall not be denied. Let us plead before the Father the merits of his Son feeling all our own unrighteousness. Let us plead his promise to his backsliding children, which is Return unto me and I will return unto you. His promises are yea and amen to him that recieveth them.
 Lucy, do you think these words are believed by and come from the heart of one whose life is an constant denial of them? If you are "a wanderer, a grevous back slider", what shall I think of myself? what do you think of me? Oh, if repentance would undo the effect of my sins upon others there would be some mitigation of my sorrows.
But, no this can never be; if I have been the means of hardening any in sin or given occasion for any to blaspheme

the holy name bu which I am called I can only be humbled and penitent and pray the Father to bring good out of evil. I think I should have been very glad to have been at the conference yesterday though I felt it was all right for me to be denied the privelege of meeting with Christians. I think too that I should have enjoyed sitting at the table of our common Lord  and partaking the symbols of his dying love for I think I have repented of my wanderings and there I should have felt that his blood was sufficient to cleanse me from all sins. O, it is a glorious thought that our sins can't exceed the greatness of the ?? for them. He may come boldly to the throne of grace and plead for the conversion of th most hardened sinner. We may hope all thing through the merits of Christ.

  Let is take courage Lucy and have our faith strengthened by the account of  remarkable conversion and happy death in the last Mirror. What a direct proof that ours is a prayer hearing and covenant -keeping God.
   Finally my sister, let us pray together for the reviving of our own church ( for reformation must first begin at the house of God) and that the ungodly among us may be brought to inquire what they shall do to be saved.
   You say with emphasis "Pray for me." I will Lucy ask that you may be kept a burning and shining light to light others to kingdom of rest, that may not do as your unworthy friend has done, deny like Peter the Lord that brought you, or betray the Son of him with a kiss. Will you pray for me that I may exercise real sorrow for my sins, and that if I have been decieved in relation to myself I may never be undecieved and

I may repair with real penitence to the Saviour and that a decieved heart may not again turn me aside.

Miss Lucy H. Metcalf                             Naomi S. Hill

                         Present                         Dec. 3rd 1843.

My health is better than it was yesterday. I have sat up all day and felt quite smart whereas yesterday I was not off the bed at all. I attempted to sit up in the evening long enough to have my bed made but fainted. 
Write me again and love to Mrs. Searles and family

                                                                   your friend and sister Naomi

Monday night and Jane is not gone yet so I'll scribble a little more. the Stage Man said he would drive round this way so Jane sat here all ready from 9 or 10 till one oclock she got so impatient & disappointed that she had quite a cry. I don't know yet why did didn't come this way. I will go down with her tomorrow. I had a letter from Joseph at last. He says he shall stay there longer. I think from his letter that there is not much if any prospect of his being benefited by the "Treatments,, he is trying it very faithfully I should think. Packing, Douche etc. & he says he has not begin the sweating process says that some do sweat so as to soak thro' the other comforters, Blankets, Mattress, Their bed and often require vessels below the bed for recieving it in which several quarts are collected - without producing weakness or loss of flesh, which don't seem to me possible, unless they have a great deal more flesh & blood to begin with than Joseph has. He says his hand & arm continue to fail. Are you lonesome any - I am very sorry Jane could not have gone Saturday. Today I have been at Almeda's & after fixing xxxx you know & sweeping etc. etc. which took till one oclock & did a considerably hard Washing. She is affected not only with lame foot (which is very much better) but has had rather a bad turn of rheumatism in her neck & shoulders - and Lucy is - a good clever girl. But about work she is - I feel rather tired but will get it tomorrow.
1850

24th I don't know as I shall for want of spirit do mu Muff but I think I could if you got any thing just Irritable to put on the ends you may send it if you have a convenient opportunity.
'Tis a lovely day for this time of year what fine warm weather we do have  - the House is in a chitter? from top to bottom with Lumber, shavings and lime mortar & sand

                                                                                                                                                                             goodbye

write often - no letter from Joseph yet what is the reason
1850

you know I never have felt that Rogers has any part of Jane's name I dont know but now you have her away from the Hobb's I should call her Hobbs unless you give her your own name. I think that her Father's name is Hill but I don't know but doubtless the only name she has any legal right to is "Hobbs" & it is an "troubled? name in other places if not here.
