Hampden Feb. 4, 1850

My Dear Mrs. Furber

                         Rec'd I tell you how rejoiced I was to heare from you! and although I have not had an opportunity to write ere this my mind has been with you almost continually since you left, - knowing the feeble state of your health we feared the result but little did we think that the mournful intelligence of your dear brothers death would reach us so soon, we heard of it a few weeks before you wrote. I could scarcely believe it; so sudden and all his friends were so confident that his life might be spared many years but our Heavenly Father "who doeth all things well" in his infinite wisdom saw fit to take him to a happier home a blessed exchange for which he was well prepared. I know it must seem almost heart-rending to part with such a brother and one so dearly loved around whom so many fond hopes were clustered whose whole sickness seemed characterized by such sweetness and forgetfulness of self. On hearing of his death my thoughts instantly reverted to that line "Sweet is the scene when Christians die" and I felt that his was the death of the righteous. O what a blessed privelege is - must have been

to have stood by him in his last hours and witnessed his triumphant departure the sting of death was taken away and "trust- perfect trust" filled his soul that peace which cometh from Christ alone can render the waves of the dark valley tranquil and smooth.

                            Our Savior seems ever calling us in his Providence to place all our affections upon him and no longer trust to the world for happiness sometimes in a still small voice so gentle we scarcely heed it then a dearly loved one so taken whose life seemed indispensable to our happiness, to remind us of that stronger, higher claim which Heaven possesses. I feel as though I had hardly begun to realize the grand object of my existence yet - and shall I live on so unconscious: 
                             O: my dearest friend would I could see you of it were only for one hour that we might talk about that dear happy brother. I know your feelings are "sorrowful yet always rejoicing" we have the blest assurance that in our Fathers house are mansions reserved for those who love him I verily believe & have thought whole long letters to you within the last week but like phantoms they seem to elude my grasp: you know my ruling passaon so well that you can easily imagine an apology was being framed for writing in such a dull proxy style but with such a theme for contemplation I seem to forget everything else I have been to the sewing circle this afternoon which met at Mrs. Greelys the first that I have attended since a year last June with you on my way home I called at Mrs. Thayers to hear how she survived a very painful operation performed

this afternoon 2 cancers cut out - she was under the influence of Chloroform is now very much reduced  She never has been more engaged in the world apparently than for a few weeks past and seemed to regard her situation with indifference she insisted upon having it done during her husbands absence O how much of suffering there is in our midst. Catharine Sewall who married a Tibbets is just alive the Physicians say there is no more hope half of her body so paralized she seems sensible of her condition requested to see Mr. Mason he has called to see her twice and conversed with her She was confined six or seven weeks ago with a pair of twins one is living. I suppose you have heard of Jacob Curtis' death he was perfectly resigned died a very joyful death. ? seems very lonely, and I have something to tell you which will make your heart rejoice Hati Wheeler has at last yielded her heart to Christ and is rejoicing in hope I feel that this new trophy should encourage us her nature is so compulsive? I think she will be active and her influence be felt by many I had almost forgotten to say that I spent the former part of this evening at Mr. Parker's had a very pleasant interview with the Rev. Mr. Wiilliams whom I found there I informed him of your brothers death which surprised him very much he desired to know the particulars said "that young man was a model of patience" You cannot think what a comfort your letter was to us. I have read it over and over again and hope to receive another good long one soon if your health permits which by the way I hope is nearly recovered Mother sends an unbounded share of love to you and sympathy says you must come down very soon it seems so desolate to look at your house and know you are not there. Our family all send their respects to your family including your husband, it is now nearly 12 oclock Mrs. Goddard wished me to give her love to you and wished you would write to her.

                                                                                                                              Yours affectionately
                                                                                                                                  Margaret

Tuesday P.M. Glenburn March 14th/ 51

Lucy Lute darling dear,

                         I would like much to know how you are body & spirit this sunny day. Are you out about, gathering - flowers there are none, but icicles all in the little chinks. - Because yr. Mother is doating tender & kind you must'nt think to play lady " no, not by no means," Lucy. I really think I'd rather be well, working than sick. - I perceive my discourse is leading me not to sobriety, for life is too great a boon to be lightly spoken of.
    When yr. husband call'd to see me bringing your kind letter, I was not well, afterwards quite sick, but for the last two weeks steadily progressing in health & strength. Six weeks ago, I was awakened from my slumbers coughing, immediately I began spitting blood, in a few moments raised more than a gill? I was soon checked however by sale. I was not at all alarmed for I supposed it some little ruptured vessel of the stomach. It was Saturday of the next week I had no school lounging upon the sofa reading I, intending the following Monday to enter upon school duties. Sat. I wrote to Ma a long letter which caused severe pain in left lung. I could only rest in bed lying on my face, had no Physician till Sabbath. On one week after the attack that day arose. Dr. Rich sneior said there was a spot of congestion in the left lung, ordered irritating plaster etc. etc. I sat up but little for one week

third week Dr. said I must leave my school for six months at least & wit cure could restore my health. I have entered upon the plan. Dea. Clark's daughter Francis has it till her sister Mrs. Richardson can take charge. Getting better I was able to see my friends who were attentive & kind beyond all my dreams even of goodness, nicities books and flowers came in abundance, so that my heart from its depths was grateful I think. Spent four weeks very pleasantly indeed with Mrs. Webster learning the value of her kind, good heart.

       I came to this quiet home retreat two week since. It was stormy almost all the first week and the winds would not get weary, so lonely withal, that I read my remaining vitality pretty much away. Tho' I should not neglect to mention that the daily arrival of "milk man" brought me daily letters & nice bits. The last week Mrs. W. has spent with me. We have sewed, knit, read, wrote etc. We are so prisoned in with snow banks, egress is a thought never indulged in. She left this morning & this long week just entered upon, I have appropriated to letter writing; that is, you know, at intervals - a pleasurable duty I've neglected because it has been too fatiguing. I Rec a letter from "Sister Ann" Sat. no items of news particularly. She is well & pleasantly ensconced with the Father & Mother & Sister of that well-to-do bachelor. She says she plucks up courage and behaves as well as she can. 
      Lucy dear I'm thinking of a western journey

to my brothers in Ill. Will you please write me when yourself & "husband" will probably return to your Hampden home, also when the Father & family leave Milo & what time do they fix upon for their journey. Ma has sent expressly for me to come to Portland, & arranged for me at her boarding house but I do not think to go sooner than four weeks. I shall ride ro see you, if you are home again within the time, would be glad to meet "Bell" (I do not remember any other name by which she is know) & so wear away the feeling of being strangers - you know it's chilling, very -

         I have not seen Eliab since his return to B. but have been told his health is improving. Your brother Joseph's death was very unexpected indeed to me. How difficult to realize he has passed from earth - and will not return. But he was so peacefully dismissed from life's cares, you will not be sad I hope. The silver cord which fastened the soul to its earthly cage is severed - no more encumbrances to progress, & then the joy of being where we can say, this is for ever. What words, midst the painful vicissitudes of the happiest life of earth. 
    Please give my love to yr. husband & friends. Lucy dear, sometime when you find yourself in a some what playful mood, read this long string of little verses. I met with them a few weeks since & they have pleased me as often as I have read them.
      If you would chance to write me & will enclose them, I'll be obliged, because I have them in reserve for another friend.
                                                                                       With love yrs, Elizabeth

If E. Doe really come on with the Furbers. it will be a fine chance for me to send for any article of dress I may need - it is much more difficult to shop to advantage here than in Racine: ? go to Buffalo so much that little variety is brought here: With regard to the skirt do just as you find it most convenient: it will do me just as much good when I come back there, so do not hurry to do it in order to send it this summer but consult the benefit of your health. As to Saturday Evening I can think of no book in the world, scarcely that I should prefer to it. If the binding is poor I should like to have it bound as handsomely as may be at my own

expense, and if convenient should like it sent if Eliab does not get entirely well. - if he should need recreation and relaxation had he not better make the tour of the state of N. York, possibly take E. Doe under his protection, get to Buffalo the last of June at which time I shall have a month's vacation. I could meet them there visit Niagara- take the trip by water to this famous port - half a day's sail - survey the beauties of the scenery and take such farther course as might be deemed advisable.

 I was to hear immediately about your health. tell Almeda I should read a letter from her with great pleasure, and I specially request her to write in detail of you as well as the rest of Mother's family and her own.

Concod N.H. Apr. 28 1851

Very Dear Friend

            May I write you now that I have again delayed so long? I have just perused again your last dear letter and to my astonishment find it was hardly penned more than a whole year since! But it seems as if written but yesterday, and to day I will write in return, yet my Lucy, will please to accept a very brief letter this time. I am preparing to visit home once more, and, if possible, intend to avail myself of the opportunity of meeting you again. I intend to be in Bangor about the 17th or so of May. Where shall I find you? May I come?
             How has passed the last year with my friend? Has health and happiness still been hers? Does she ever have a passing thought of Mary?   Oh, Lucy, you know not how wonderful and gracious has been my heavenly Father's care over me. I have been favored with the high privilege of remaining at school another year! Have now attended school 18 months in class - six at Woburn and twelve at the female Seminary, Charlestown. The last term at that dear institution closed the last week in March and I have spent the time since with relatives here. Is it possible my school days are over? Perhaps they're not. though it is altogether too probable they are.

Could I have remained one term longer, I should have graduated like a former teacher, received a diploma for my "overmuch knowledge,"

In reply to one enquiring paragraph of your letter I scarcely know what to say. I have indeed the pleasure of an acquaintance with a friend who is looking forward to a missionary life, but where his field of labor may be is quite uncertain.
                 He desired to proclaim the Glad tidings where it is yet unknown to preach Christ to those who have never yet heard the story of a Savior's love, and in this I find truly, my own heart beats in unison. What a high and holy privilege would it be to be permitted to devote one's self this wholly to the Lord's to consecrate one's self thus entirely to the service of that dear Redeemer who has done so much for us. Though weak, and ignorant , through Christ we an do all thing. Does it not seem - is it not true that the grace of God is sufficient for us. "As they say; so shall thy strength be."
     But to return, ardently as my friend wishes to spend his days in heathen ground, it may be that he will not.
    I can calmly trust all in the hands of my heavenly Father, to whom alone the future is know.
   The future, the future is a closely sealed book
   In vain, at its pages, I endeavor to look,
   I know well the present, and the past I can see,
   But what has the future, the veiled future for me?
   Has it happier hours than the present or past?
   Has it flow'rs that will fade not and joys that will last?
   Will my heart's dearest wished be realized all?
   Or, will they be shrouded, as with midnight's dark pall.

Let your prayer, dear Lucy, ascend with mine that God will prepare me for whatever he is preparing for me. My time is spent. Please accept this brief letter with the sincere

                                                                                                                      Affection of Mary. W. Tower

[left-hand side] May I not expect to hear from you at Charlestown. I shall be there one or two weeks previous to the 20th of May when I intend to leave for home. And say, may I not meet you once again? I have many things to say but must defer till I see you, if permitted.

Lissie Doe. Aug. 1851
                                                                                                                                                      Providence
                                                                                                   Aug. 22nd Friday

My Lucy dear

                   It was so very kind indeed of you darling to write me without waiting longer the fulfillment of my promise that I sit me down this PM expressly to tell you again of yr goodness to thank you for this unexpected manifestation. I am indeed, professionally, a housekeeper in Ill. too, where women & horses fare hardly enough "Sure." Five men this day, stocking grain. I spent the long AM from sunrise till midday getting breakfast & dinner for them. I have prepared supper in part, which ceremony takes place here when the toil of day is over about dark. The intervening hours I'm happy to spend spiritually with you. My journey here was exceedingly pleasant. My Stay, with Anna delightful I never need enjoy more in the same place of time. My health much improved thereby, now I begin to think it quite restored. what you can understand to be a real blessing. "Not enjoyment & not sorrow is ours & destined end away" you know, so the fact is I did not find on arriving here all my even considerate expectations met. My brother Thomas who has been a resident here, about for the past five years, was just recovering from a severe bilious fever, just at the same time which he had appropriated to finish of his house, sewing, planting et. He was feeble & discouraged. A younger brother

with him was also in poor health & the lady where they had boarded, wearied with her cares. The first 6 weeks I had a very good boarding place, employing my time, making of mending, knitting, cooking etc. for the brothers who undertook to keep "Back" till they could get things ready for me. Meanwhile one had boils, & the other Ague & I felt decided I'd dwell with them. When we meet, I'll amuse you with a graphic description of Western life. We have a cottage, of brick, all unfinished, is a half mile from neighbors, farms are laid out in sections & quarter sections, the latter containing 80 acres. My brothers' lost is a half mile East & west, a fourth North & South, the neighbor's likewise, & although it is called a village, you perceive there cannot be much of the rattle, bustle & din of city life. Our immediate vicinity is the highest land in the state, a rolling prairie height as the natural scenery around, distant & interesting, is very beautiful indeed. If yr "chair" was only here, I'd wheel you to the door of my cottage & suffer you to extend yr. vision nearly 30 miles. An undulating Prairie, dotted with the oak graves called "Openings". beautiful as the park of an English nobleman. I can distinguish horses, settlements, twelve miles distant. I do not embellish. I am charmed with this spot of earth & you would also be, that circumstances keep me within doors & household duties occupy me thoughts so much. My taste, inclination lead me to move, ride & write to my friends of the things so beautiful here. But hen I'll hasten to fulfill life's Mission of rigid stern

realities, gleaning something daily mid them all, for future fun & soberness, & shake the "napkin" or maybe turn, "Homesickness" had not prevented me writing more but the want of leisure has, which has been a great self denial. Notwithstanding you would be surprised to know the pages I have prepared weekly for home friends. The Doe's & the Pa's & Ma's are numerous you know. On a little eminence, less than a half mile distant - clusters a black smith & wheelright  shop, two hotels, church, small Congregational only one of the place, & P. Office - Eastern mail arrives Monday's Eve & Thursday's noon, & there myself straightway moves through the tall tangled grass, perchance birds numerous & flocks thitherwards, Many a light?, & many a damsel, I meet there at such times, pedestrian & equestrian there's novelty here everwhere & I must not indulge in a hint at it hardly,lest I immediately dip too deeply & make my letter too late for the mail. Just now glancing out upon a winding prairie "bridle path" road, I see a long beggar tent covered very white drawn by long procession of cows, oxen , emigrating to the farther west. It has a sad & sorrowful look to me. I pity the children & mothers. They camp at night in the damp earth kindling a fire to cook their scanty fare for life's support. "O, the mystery of life"! Such Scenes are of daily occurrence. Now the items of yr. kind letter which is widespread before me must be attended to, firstly much love to all the friends who think of me enough to "wonderment" at my silence. Louise Shaw shall have tidings soon. Please see her when you can, & if this hasty letter contains an idea toss the said idea to her, the dear lovely Mrs. Webster has

heard from me long ere this. Thanks for the "wishes jointly & severally,]. I have hesitated much, thought much & ? the subject of my return. I do not think I've fully decided, but probably shall remain here during the winter. The society is good Episcopalian, much the more numerous class, will have & church & pastor soon. Mt health is much better than one year since I think the climate is decidedly favorable. Providence has a locality, tho it's not on the map, lying 15 miles from the northern shore of the Ill. river you'll see Princeton which is the Shire town, & Where I've had pleasant visits.
The same Eve yr. letters came, one came also from Anna she's clever to me in writing & so am I to her.  She told me of Eliab. I wish him a 'heap' of happiness. I wish Isaac was nearer to me, we would have 'fun', despite that lady whose name I've forgotten. Josephine, Henryette, Maryette, something. Sorry for Mrs. Furber & Belle. I became quite attaced to B. and very much regretted leaving the family at Buffalo. My love to her when you unite, & ask B. to write to me. If Mrs. Thaxter had died, I should have hastened home to the responsibilities of Mother-in-law.

          I am glad Mrs. Blood has called. She is a very excellent & interesting lady. She writes that Mr. N. Harlow thinks to remove to Conn. Please tell me.
       Ask yr. husband if it was sufficiently affectionate to sat "I remember her". How do I know whether it is good or evil that's treasured up.
        Love to him & yr. good Mother.
       If Mrs. Benj. Plummer does'nt call or you she is naughty.
             Adieu
                                                        With love sincerely yrs, Elizabeth

I'm promised horseback riding (very much the fashion) when "harvesting" is over. Been three times blackberrying 9 miles last time & horse vehicle. Any dump of a N. Englander would laugh outright at their style of riding & carriages.

Lizzie Doe
                                                                                                                                            Lameville Sept. 14th / 51

My Lucy dear

                  Your last kind favor came to me at this place about two weeks since. Various have been my wanderings & diverse my thoughts & plans in regard to spending the Winter in this Western world since I last wrote you. Six weeks ago, perhaps I left Providence. My eldest brother Thomas decided on teaching, rented his place, & we disbanded. By special invitation I came here, (to stay a little) homeward bound. Two weeks of much enjoyment passed. when the day as the shadows of evening were deepening. My brothers, three, drove up. One run hastily in, to say to me that brother Frank was not quite in his right mind etc. The next moment himself appeared, clasped me in his arms, with tears of joy exclaiming "I thought you were dead, I saw you in heaven & I wanted to get to you" During the 48 hours he remained with us we had medical attendance almost constantly, but he grew worse at length violent. He was taken to Chicago to the insane Asylum in so high an excitement that the Dr. there in charge said in one night he gave him morphine sufficient to kill five well men, with little effect. An extra man is employed with him, the charge is $10.00 per week. He has been there nearly three weeks they have succeeded in allaying the violence of emotion & in inducing sleep. The cause we do not know. The premonotory symptoms for a few weeks were extreme irritability, & sleepless nights. The physician writes me every week. He closed

his last letter by saying he had good hope of his recovery. Chicago is about 100 miles from here. I wish I could be with him but do not think of going at present, -b gentleman from this Village, was there last week & saw my afflicted brother. He lies in bed most of the time in a stupor in part induced by medicine, no movements even of returning reason. His heart was one of the most generous & best, but he was not a christian. We cannot reasonably hope he will ever be the same again, but I cannot help the hope of a partial restoration, that his soul may be given to his Savior, & so pass away peacefully to his home in heaven. Lucy dear I live in amazement at this sudden visitation of Providence. I don't know what to think of myself. I'm so strangely calm. Frank was remarkable for health & hope. He loved me very much& I looked on his with expectation- but - the hand of his Heavenly Father rests heavily upon him. He is stricken. I see & know just this, & no more. It seems to become me therefore to say from the heart resigned. Thy will be done.

 I have not yet written to my Parents. I'm waiting the farther progress of the disease, so you may please not speak of this letter to any one at present. I think I shall remain in this vicinity the winter. I shall be very glad to hear from you often. Direct to me, Lamville Bureau Co. the P.O. is kept by a "widow lady." - I often sit with her & read Eastern papers etc. I am not visiting in Mr. Patterson's family. Mrs. G. is sister to Mrs. Tasker of yr. city. I ride on horseback or otherwise wherever I like, find pleasant friends & enjoy them. I suppose, as usual time is wearing away pleasantly with you. I know, remember and

sympathize in yr. privations but then I recall yr. quiet comfortable pleasant - earthly home, with anticipations of the heavenly- & so I think of you & rejoice with you, that you are happy that you have so good a husband, & he so good a wife. In the full possession as the poet sings, of the only bliss that has survived the Fall.

Yesterday a rain storm commenced the first for about three months. It continued through the night, - whether it will conclude to-day I know not. I should be rather heart sober but for the blessed privilege of spending the hours in spiritual communication with old home friends. I read a while, then just laid the book away, because I could get more happiness from writing. I hope yr. Sam; is enjoying restored health. I followed you in your Island excursion with much interest. That "woman" was a curiosity shop, really hope her mission ground will be unmistakably pointed out. Oh! Oh! Oh! the startling contrasts & varieties of character in this little world. I've seen more the last two yrs, than my life long, before. Headly says of earth (you know) " that it seems the middle spot between heaven & hell, the song of angels, & the shriek of fiends go up from the same spot". How I did like, loathe the littleness mean, withered soul specimens, U meet & mingle with such, for they are here, & everywhere so that the contact seems unavoidable. My head at this moment aches with memories of such human specimens mid that symetry, beauty and richness of nature in this western valley. I was interested in reading this morning, thoughts emenating from one of the good & great souls. He would fain better the world & his fruitful imagination suggested a great bonfire on a broad prairie. The article was

headed "Earth's Holocaust" do do tell me what holocaust means. The author was a bystander the materials used for the flame were newspapers magazine badges of illustrious families & sovereignities, from the worm-eaten instrument signed by William the Conqueror down to Victoria. Time-honored rubish first - Purple robes, crowns, globes & scepters - rapidly came Father Mother's ? rolling over the prairie all the liquors of the world medicines burned save Homeopathy Politicians deprived of bread from loss of office threwin their teeth, being false Ladies flung in gowns & petticoats to assume the good manners duties offices etc. of the other sex. All weapons & munitions of war melted like wax. The greatest shout  - when all instruments of death like the gallows become first black then a red coal, then ashes. Next came marriage ceremonies, bales of paper money & coin, day books, deeds, ledgers, libraries, the labor of lexicographers commentators encyclopedists poets, lastly the Bible, which instead of being blackened into tinder only assumed a more darrling whiteness. Mid the great conflagration, a dark visaged stranger exultingly said there is one thing forgotten without - which all is just nothing at all, though they burn the earth itself to a cinder, unless they burn the human heart it will be the old world still etc. etc, I cannot give you much idea of the play of the author's genius, but it was a splendid article. "O would the gift the giver gives us" etc. etc. then we'd pratice on the golden rule & be happy because better. 
I have thought of Bell in her loneliness. How does she like Minnesota? Anna dear writes me rather often she seems to have a desirable situation.
You must write by littles at your quiet leisure & send me on the reception of this a closely filled sheet. Every city, neighborhood & home item. By the way your new house, I speak a room for me. My love to all ? friends & do favor me in my loneliness with an early reply.

                                                                                   With love yrs. Elizabeth Doe.

Milo June 2nd 1851

Dear Aunt,

           I have been waiting till the cows went down to fulfil my promise. I believe I shall not call this fulfiling it now for we have been making up the dresses the last week so I have had no time to write. We are all very well only baby is all bit up with meters as Charly calls them he says when baby hand get big he can strike em just so.
       I went to Mr. Linseys funeral yesterday afternoon. He died very suddenly, he had been in his shop about half an hour when some one came in and found him upon his face dead. It appears that an ulcer broke in his throat and it strangled him. He died in Brownville at Mr. Harvey's.
               James is going in a great hurry so I must close.
                     goodbye from your affectionate neice
                                       Lucy Searles

Milo Dec 14 1851

My dear Aunt

                                                                                                             I write to send by
 Uncle Charles tomorrow. I have been to meeting today. The hall was very cold was not opened till eleven? and Mr. Partridge was so cold he could hardly speak. He did not preach but one sermon. We have a very good school this winter. Mr. McLean teaches arithmetic much as Uncle Joseph did. I like the way he has the first classes spell; he has them choose sides for a week. In the other classes he has promised a prize. To Lizzie's class a quarter of a dollar. If she could go constantly I think she would get it without any doubt. 

We are going to have a free singing school begin tomorrow evening Mr. Heath teaches it. James and I are going.   

   Mr. Sargent gave Mother as much wood as Mr. Richer could cut in two days and a half an Mr. Bumps hauled it. The singing school was to begin last Wednesday and the singing master and a lot of the scholars came and when they got there they could not get the key

[left-hand side] tell Jane I do not have time to write to her this time

to either schoolhouse or hall. Mr. Sprague was out of town so they could not have the hall and Mr. Gould would not let them have the key to the schoolhouse. The Universalists have meetings in the hall, half the time so there has been no others. But today there was a notice given of a meeting at our schoolhouse next sabbath so I hope we shall have meetings now. I want to see Charlie awfully. We are all going down to Grandmothers to live while Uncle Charles is gone. Mother wants to write so I must close. My love to Jane.

                                                                                                                                                                from
                                                                                                                                                                  your
                                                                                                                                                               affectionate
                                                                                                                                                                  niece Lucy

I told Lucy I wanted to write a little but it took her so long that my eyes ache too much, for you must know it is 9 oclock, and I have been reading while she wrote.
We had a good long letter from Ann the other day and C. a catalogue from Eliab I am glad he is at school, the best thing he could do. Ellen Sargent is going to live with an aunt while her father is gone to California and she is a girl that needs such treatment as I fear she will not receive I want very much to give her

some book that will do her good, perhaps a little bible might be the best, for I suppose if she has any other book it must be interesting or it would not be read but a neat little bible she would value and read I think. Have you got one (clasp like Isaac's) for 40 cts, of colporter.
If you will confer and consult and some of you get me such an one or some other book, cost not over .50 or .60 I will be much obliged. I feel under considerable obligations to Mr. Sargent for wood confessed and would rather have paid him for some of it if he would receive it, and partly on that account wish to get a present for E that will be valuable and beneficial to her. She would make a noble girl with right training I wish she could have it.

 I have another cheese to sell. Do you want it C says I can sell it at the stores for .10 per lb and if you don't want it, I'll sell it here.

you did not tell me the price of corn so I don't know yet whether it is better for me to buy corn here, or there.

 Please send up Messengers and I think it would be well to take 6 copies for another year Mr. Whelden Mrs. Bumps Mrs. Dolin and we want them and I don't know whether Mrs. Hodgkins or not I want Christian Almanac             
                                                                                                                        good night

Farewell
                                       Farewell, thou loved Foxcroft! farewell to thee now!
                                       For I from thy borders must quickly depart;
                                       My stay here is ended, and hence I must go,
                                       While sad is my bosom and pensive my heart.

                                      Farewell gentle river! thou beautiful stream!
                                      How oft from my window I've gazed upon thee,
                                      Till, joyous, exstatic, e'en wild as a dream,
                                       My spirit has panted like thee to be free.

                                      Unfettered and free do thy waters roll on,
                                       Reflecting the foliage from either green side; -
                                      How charming the sound of their mumering song,
                                       As onward and onward forever they glide.

                                      When sorrowful musings of kindred and home
                                       Have clouded my brow and drawn tears from my eye,
                                       Then, soothing, the sound of thy murmer has come,
                                       Bidding sorrow depart, and comfort draw nigh.

                                      But now I must leave thee! farewell, gentle river!
                                      No more shall I gaze on thy dark foaming waves:
                                      The sound of thy fall in the distance, shall never
                                       Again greet my ear with the music it craves.

Farewell, ye loved haunts, where, when twilight's soft shade
                                                                                   Had spread o'er the earth her deep mantle of gray,
                                                                                   I have oft wandered forth, and thoughtfully strayed.-
                                                                                    While dim in the west, the light faded away.

                                                                                   Farewell, kind instructers: and school-mates farewell:
                                                                                   Here many bright hours we together have passed; -
                                                                                   My fast throbbing heart with emotion doth swell,
                                                                                   While I think of those hours, too happy to last.

                                                                                  But now all those pleasures have vanished away!
                                                                                   Alas! vanished how soon! though dear to my heart;
                                                                                   The joy they afforded is gone when I say
                                                                                   To friends I have ardently loved "we must part."

                                                                                    Farewell, then, ye loved ones! farewell to you all!
                                                                                    My rising emotion and sorrow I'll quell;
                                                                                    Fate summons me hence and I answer the call -
                                                                                    Then again I will bid you farewell! farewell!

Farewell to Foxcroft
Lucy H. Metcalf
